- [ ] Searched for an existing similar issue: https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/issues?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=is%3Aissue%20
   Allow for batch importing multiple CSV files at once using the import CSV dialog

- You can choose to import to separate tables using the filename
- Interactively pick which files you want to import
- Match similar files that share the same columns to import into one table

Fixes #1002 

Code could be a lot slimmer, didn't poke around as much as I could, "first timer" so a bit of reuse and ideally we should be able to fetch headers without running through the entire file (so the last commit was more of a poc) but would make for a more streamlined experience. Suggestions and improvements welcome ofc.

![](http://i.imgur.com/n8vv3hc.gif) @karim 

> How did you add the files? (Did you associate .csv files with DB4S? If so, is there any limit, by the OS, on how many files to open like this?)

The way this feature worked initially and still does with this multiple selection variation is that it fetches the list of names first (that a user can then cherry pick from) then opens a stream, parses and performs actions after in a sequential order over the selected files. The open dialog filters what formats are allowed and the internal parser will warn/skip/err on bad files (invalid csvs). I had a folder with ~7k files with thousands of rows and including decoding and inserting took a little over half hour on a Dell XPS 15 running x64 Win 10.

> What if the user add a file using File > Import > CSV? (Can he add more once this dialog is open?)

I added an (experimental until review) feature to *Match similar* files by checking headers (the green highlight in the gif above) so once you have selected a list of files there is no need to manually sort them before to ensure they are in the same format, hence no need to prompt for more files.

@chrisjlocke Anything below WinXP was hardcoded due to memory constraints and dependent on runtimes. IIRC WinXP itself had a limit of `1024 * 2` and I'd like to think modern OSes limits are more denoted by available memory *(don't quote me on that ;)*. @MKleusberg Ah! Thanks, forgot about that and looking forward to it.  ### Details for the issue
Unexpected behaviour.
Seems like the "Execute SQL" and "Execute current line" buttons are crossed.

I want to run this code
```
SELECT * FROM Transactions 
WHERE [Date] Between '2017-05-23 00:00:00:001' 
AND '2017-05-23 23:59:59'
```
If I select the first line "_SELECT * FROM Transactions_ " and click the Execute SQL arrow >  
`This is the output:  4 rows returned in 0ms from: SELECT * FROM Transactions`

but if I click the Execute Current Line the output is:
```
2 rows returned in 0ms from: SELECT * FROM Transactions 
WHERE [Date] Between '2017-05-23 00:00:00:001' 
AND '2017-05-23 23:59:59'
```

values in them are mixed "False" / "0" etc.  That's why I went looking for
another tool.  It was with the help of your tool that I could see what's
happening.  VS was hiding the problem. Just tried it there.   Highlighting is required.

button.   If nothing is highlighted then it runs the whole script, but if a
selection is highlighted then only the selection gets run.  This, I would
consider to be expected / normal behaviour.  This is how it works in
SSMS or Rapid for Sybase.

job with the bits so not great for a learner.   Also marks against VS it
gives me the usual suspects for field data types; money, double, float,
etc... when SQLite has only 4.

Yes I understand that it concatenates the lines.
Is adding the ; is bogus?  Is that how it's done in the other 'big player'
apps? I know I don't consciously use it when I'm scripting outside of C#.



select * from Transactions (*C1)
where Id <= 3; (*C1)
select * from Transactions  (*C2)
where Id >= 4;  (*C2)

Placing the cursor at (*C1) or (*C2)   Press F5 = results from only second
query every time = OK it just ran through.

Shift+F5 = result from whichever query the cursor resides inside of.


When I highlight some text F5 will just run the highlighted text.



I see it now but I think the app is running as You expect it to. Is that
good to the end user coming from the big players SSMS etc?  I'd be looking
to nullify the learning curve as much as possible.

Personally I'm happy to select / highlight the code I want to run.  That's
what I know.
In the case of Embarcadero Rapid if I run multiple queries like above then
I get multiple result sets (in the same grid). No semi colon required.








On Wed, May 24, 2017 at 11:51 AM, Chris Locke <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> If I put this code in, it will fail
>
> Technically, its not valid SQL. DB4S will 'merge' all lines (as an SQL
> statement can be split over multiple lines, eg:
>
> select *
> from Tags
> where
> Id <= 2
>
> So DB4S is squishing your statements together and forming this:
>
> select * from Tags where Id <= 2 select * from Tags where Id >= 3
>
> Slap a semi colon on the end of each statement, and DB4S will know where
> one statement ends, and another begins.
>
>    1. Again, if you add the semi colon, Shift+F5 will work. Honest.
>
> ‚Äî
> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/issues/1017#issuecomment-303689705>,
> or mute the thread
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AFP7_z1vkxIjGGqmrcdRID2KXntaeDmRks5r9AvKgaJpZM4Njs0I>
> .
>
 "*You can't 'assume' that lines beginning with 'select' is a new statement,
as you can have multiple 'select' statements in a select statement.*"  Yes
- very good.  I don't know how the boffins do it.  I've never put my mind
to it.




Hello fellow .Net-er back!
I grew up in VB6 land which ultimately led me to .Net.  I strongly urge
anyone to cross over to C#.  It's not that hard but it does have extra
features and it becomes much slicker to use.  Right now I want to use C# +
Xamarin to create a mobile app across the 3 platforms.  (That can't be done
with VB.NET)   The mobile dev led me to SQLite as a universal data
solution.  I hope I got that right, will it work on win phone, android and
ios?   VS2017 won't develop for Windows Phone 8, only Win10.  So I'm also
developing in VS2015.  I prototype and develop the backend in my free
time at work on an antique VM using XP and VS2010 using WPF + MVVM that I
can take home for porting out to the other apps.   Fekin nuts!  But when
it's done I'll put it up on git then I'll have another little thing to put
on my CV in case Brexit kills off my job - since it's already giving me all
of this free time right now by causing the markets to panic and hold off
spending.




On Wed, May 24, 2017 at 12:34 PM, Chris Locke <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> Some programs 'detect' where the semi colon should go, others don't. I use
> SQL Studio and that gets confused if I don't add semi colons. You can't
> 'assume' that lines beginning with 'select' is a new statement, as you can
> have multiple 'select' statements in a select statement. The semi colon
> just explicitly defines where you want the ending to be.
>
> when I'm scripting outside of C#

> Welcome fellow .Net-er. I program mainly in VB, but use both SQLite and

 Back on topic.

I would with a reflex CTRL+E to run the script.   I'm sure I got this habit
from SSMS ;)  Open SQL file dialog should default to the same path as the database; instead it opens home folder (tested on Windows). Suit only if you work on a single directory. If you use multiple databases in different places it is still uncomfortable. I would favor an option to open the directory where the active database is.    ### Details for the issue

- An attempt to open the installed DB Browser for SQLite v.3.9.1 in the Windows XP (32 bit) environment returns error "DB Browser for SQLite.exe is not a valid Win32 application"

### Useful extra information

Since the original topic #893 "was locked and limited conversation to collaborators on 27 Feb", but there are still noob users like me and #986 around, that just wish to adopt DB Browser for SQLite 3.9.1 to their beloved Win32 XP machines, hereby I will provide you with easy to understand "entry-level" solutions to this issue.

@h1618 
> if you are able to operate a hexeditor, just changing offset 0x40 and 0x44 of the sqlitebrowser.exe executable from 0x0006 (Vista) to 0x0005 (XP) is all that's needed

- Unfortunately I couldn't figure out how to perform or calculate location for those manipulations, so this link to the image file with the screenshot of hex-code comparison between unpatched (left) and patched (right) files should give you an idea of what exactly is it there to be changed and where it is located within a hex editor: http://www.hadrurus.com/andiutils/DB4S/SQLite3.9.1HexPatch.jpg

or 

@karim

> A quick solution is by editing the .exe file using editbin and change the subsystem right after building it. 

- I didn't want to seek and install all of Microsoft Visual Studio, so for this method you should go to: http://www.hadrurus.com/andiutils/DB4S/EditBinPack.rar and download:
1. EditBinPack.rar

Then extract all files contained in EditBinPack.rar archive to the folder with the installed DB Browser for SQLite (in Windows XP usually at C:\Program Files\DB Browser for SQLite) on your PC. Now [Start] > [Run] > {_type_} **CMD** > [OK] > {_type_} **CD\\** {Enter} > {_type_} **CD PROGRAM FILES\DB BROWSER FOR SQLITE** {Enter} and finally {_type_}:
> **EDITBIN DBBROW~1.EXE /SUBSYSTEM:WINDOWS,5.01 /OSVERSION:5.1** {Enter}

After that manipulation is done, check your "DB Browser for SQLite.exe" for runnability, and if all is OK, you're set to use program as usual. 

At last, just like me, enjoy latest DB Browser for SQLite v.3.9.1 on your Windows XP!

P.S. I could provide here a link to the patched file itself, and this way it would be even easier to just substitute one file with another, but I am not sure whether I am allowed to do so here.

 I am not sure whether during compilations data in the PE header is always written into exactly the same addresses, as yet I have no experience in this at all. But I think with basis given by the screenshot next time it would be easier to spot the location of wanted data (at least I would have an idea about what am I looking for). To the 'Hex' method I actually came from executing 'EditBin' method, and then replicated changes performed by editbin.exe manually in my hex editor. So I agree with you that 'EditBin' method looks more reliable and sounds like the correct one. As I've read further, it looks that there are differences in link.exe files and that newer generations of that file won't let editbin.exe to set a version prior to what was limited in its code by Microsoft, instead saying something like "LINK : warning LNK4241: invalid subsystem version 5.01". Again, I might be wrong. Anyways, the link to the three files I gave in method 2, do allow to write a program's OS compatibility to subsystem 5.01. The correspondent option would be:

`editbin.exe "$(TargetPath)" /SUBSYSTEM:WINDOWS,5.01 /OSVERSION:5.1`

Like I said before, I am totally noob in programming, though sometimes I manage to put some parts of puzzles together, and even in this comment I mostly rely on the information obtained from: https://supportxpdotcom.wordpress.com/2012/03/30/editbins-dirty-little-secret @chrisjlocke, I really don't know where did you get it and why did you use that command shown in your CMD prompt screenshot, i.e:
 
`link "DB Browser for SQlite.exe" /subsystem:windows, 5.01 /osversion:5.1`

as I've never suggested that. It is totally wrong! Though I must agree that my syntax explanation could be a bit complicated...

 I'll try latest nightly this weekend (getting pretty short on time by now, soz), I'll let you know if I'll come with the similar result. )))) Installed both on a 32bit Windows XP box. Good news is, both installed without problem, and both had PE's subsystem set to 5.1. Bad news is both raised an error popup immediately after start: "The application terminated as a result of a CTRL+C." This very error I have seen already with other new Qt apps, and I think it is because qt5core.dll has two missing imports, one being CancelIoEx in kernel32.dll - I think this missing import is misinterpreted as having hit Ctrl+C. The Qt libraries all have version 5.8.0.0, and The Qt Company states that the last version that runs on XP is 5.6 - seems they're right. Hey to everyone!  Personally I am increasingly astounded that people still use XP, many Open Source projects have dropped support for it or provide an old version "as-is". I don't believe we should let XP support stop progress. also confirming that both v5 versions (Qt 5.7) installed and work on my windows xp x86 box without issues. Had medium thorough tests with real world test data, editing/inserting/deleting data, encryption, decryption, and all went smooth and worked as it should. Hello everyone! Since I've started this mess, let me explain my position on the Windows XP. Like many, I've been chasing the progress and had always tried to get most modern things at a time. But later I've got fed up with the fact that everything "latest" is also is the most unreliable. You buy a new latest Supermicro motherboard, and hey, they've just found a problem and made a new revision that as well supports your latest Xeons better... - very disappointing, especially after throwing away a few thousands bucks and instead of receiving the quality expected, you're suddenly losing your time on workarounds, anxiously waiting for a newer BIOS release full of hope that it would solve some of your troubles, and feeling yourself a complete idiot. So I've decided to quit being a corporate tester of their newest devices at my own expense, and now I first wait for others to come up with their comparisons and results, letting time for people to draw up their own conclusions, so that later I'd do a wiser choice based on true user experience rather than on bright, promising ads. How is it related to software? Well, similarly: security updates, software updates, patches, service packs, etc., etc., they've caused so many glitches, halts and screens of death, bringing so much unnecessary headaches and troubles, many of which took whole days to recover. You probably cannot even imagine the other world without the "everyday" updates, which are often a threat to your stable work more than any viruses (in fact in 26 years of my PC experience I've NEVER lost a bit of information because of a virus, but I've lost tones of useful data because of unstable and poorly tested updates). Since Microsoft has dropped updating the Windows XP, it became the perfect machine. All of their updates for my Windows XP are pre-downloaded into separate folder, case there would be a need for reinstall, and my PC is finally set to work for me, as opposed of me constantly servicing my PC instead. Plus, I am also a music production related dude, and much of professional (very long life span) music equipment works perfectly on Window XP, while often there are simply no hardware drivers available for the newer operating systems. Another reason that makes Windows XP still popular are laptops, that are pretty slow with vendor pre-installed software, _but hey, I got an old copy of Windows XP lying around.., that's way better_. Last, but not least. I am Russian, and all of the Russian government is using Windows XP only on their PCs. Why? Because Microsoft has provided the open-source of its Windows XP (including patches) to the Russian government, and Kaspersky Labs have guaranteed that there are no back-doors built in that OS. With today's political agenda, can you be so sure with any other modern OS that NSA is not recording your every step?  Maybe it is not of your concern, but some people do care. Who said that hackers and viruses are the bigger danger than governments, corporations and "updates"? xD
Now seriously, today I am finally very sure, that when I switch my PC on, I won't spend time on updates and recoveries, but would simply do my tasks as was planned. **Am I missing anything? Not yet.** Antivirus and Firewall take care of my security, every software instrument that I need is right here, fine-tuned. Hybrid HDDs make my machine crazy smooth. Would I update to the latest Windows when Windows XP would finally fall? No. I'd go for Windows 7.
Why do I use DB4S? Mm, I regularly edit quite a few SQL .db files from my Android, as Android apps that I need and use mostly lack synchronization availability, or require Cloud services. Thus I edit them on my PC in your DB4S and once edited I synchronize them back to my smartphone, kinda Server/Client scenario.
About the Qt 5.7, Qt 5.8 situation and Windows XP. I suggest, if you wouldn't mind, that you only make **official releases** being compatible with Windows XP, like the case with the 4.9.1 pack that originated this topic. I am pretty sure, that most people that use  Nightlies, probably would be the people of different kind, than those slow-pokes with their Windows XP's. It is very reasonable to dedicate yourself to progress, but also keep an eye on your conservative audience. Well, all this is IMHO, so eventually it is up to you folks to decide on that part, just keep in mind that Windows XP is still 3rd most popular OS.

  ### Details for the issue

Couple of problems encountered with [the instructions:](https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/wiki/Setting-up-a-Win64-development-environment-for-DB4S)
- the `C:\dev\SQLite` folder should apparently be named `C:\dev\SQLite-Win64`
- `vcredist_x64` should apparently be put in `C:\dev\dependencies`, not `C:\git_repos\sqlitebrowser\deps`

While executing large sql scripts from .sql files, the application goes not responding. This work must be done in a seperate thread, to avoid blocking the UI thread.

#### I'm opening this issue because:

- [ ] DB4S is crashing
- [ ] DB4S has a bug

- [ ] DB4S has another problem

#### I'm using DB4S on:

- [ x] Windows: ( _version:_ ___ )

- [ ] Mac OS: ( _version:_ ___ )
- [ ] Other: ___

#### I'm using DB4S version:

- [x ] 3.9.1
- [ ] 3.9.0
- [ ] Other: ___

#### I have also:

- [ ] Tried out the nightly version: https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser#windows
- [ ] Searched for an existing similar issue: https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/issues?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=is%3Aissue%20
 @justinclift  Sorry, I marked the wrong version in the post. I'm using the latest version, 3.9.1, just corrected the same in the post.   Single-line SQL comments cause peculiar behaviour if run in the "Execute SQL" tab.

Say I run the following:
`-- This comment prevents line count working and "changes the database"`
`SELECT * FROM events WHERE logid=81991 AND type='content'`
then 
- I don't get the usual "N rows returned" message
- the database is locked and Write/Revert changes are enabled
- the correct result is returned

Alternatively, if I run:
`SELECT * FROM events WHERE logid=81991 AND type='content'`
`-- This comment causes an error`
then 
- I get an "Error executing query: ..." response
- no result is returned

In this case I can see that the SQL submitted by the application has had the line breaks removed, so the extra `SELECT COUNT(*) ...` that's added to give a line count is syntactically wrong, as the terminating `);` has become commented-out.

Finally (so far), if I try to execute:
`SELECT 40+2 -- get the answer`
`AS answer`
(N.B. `AS` is at the start of the line) then 
- I get an "Error executing query: ..." response
- no result is returned

In this case the comment and newline have been removed completely, with the result that what's executed is `SELECT 40+2AS answer` (no whitespace between `2` and `AS`).

I'd suggest the quick approach is to replace single-line comments with a single space, if you don't mind them being discarded from the submitted SQL. If you want to leave them in then you can't discard the newlines, as they're syntactically significant...

### Useful extra information

<!-- The info below often helps, please fill it out if you're able to. :) -->

#### I'm opening this issue because:

 @justinclift: OK, I've tried the nightly win64 and it fixes the latter two, but not the first one. I'm slightly wrong now in the report title, as the first problem is also caused by a `/* block comment */` at the start, so it's not specific to the `-- line comment`. I've double-checked that the database is locked until I Revert Changes.

I've also found another case:
`SELECT '-- cause error'`
causes an error!  You can have block comments in SQL?! üò≤ 

@justinclift, Surely it is üò¢  But I don't know how to solve other more complex cases like `SELECT 'this -- causes error'`. I don't have the ability to re-compile from source, but I've been playing with regexes a bit in Python, and I think
 `^((?:(?:[^'-]|-(?!-))*|(?:'[^']*'))*)(--.*)$` 
yields two captured groups, the first is the SQL code and the second is the line comment. This relies on NOT concatenating the lines of a multi-line SQL statement (remove the line comments before concatenation, assuming this is being done).

As far as I can tell this is a legal regex in Qt. I tested it against the following:
`SELECT 'string -- not a comment '' - single quote'  -- comment 'not a string' -- not the whole comment`
Note that the regex doesn't match the SQL if there's no comment, e.g.:
`SELECT 'string -- not a comment '' - single quote'  `

@revolter  You can indeed have block comments, see [http://sqlite.org/lang_comment.html](url). I haven't played with removing those but I suspect one could construct similar tricky cases there, too! From what I remember, it doesn't concatenate the lines prior to removing comments.

I hoped for QScintilla to have something to remove comments, knowing it already detects and highlights them, but I didn't find any function that does this.

And, nice regex you have there, could you please explain it a bit? As I only understand them best when I write them. Here you go, @revolter - like any code, regexes are pretty much write-only! I think there are ways to comment them, but I'm too lazy usually...
```
^((?:(?:[^'-]|-(?!-))*|(?:'[^']*'))*)(--.*)$
^                                          $ # anchor beginning and end of string so we use it all
 (                                  )(    )  # two separate capture groups for code and comment
                                      --.*   # comment starts with -- and consumes everything afterwards
  (?:                 |           )*         # code is none or many strings alternating with non-strings
                       (?:'[^']*')           # a string is a quote, followed by none or more non-quotes, followed by a quote
     (?:[^'-]|-(?!-))*                       # non-string is a sequence of characters which aren't quotes or hyphens, 
                                               OR if they are hyphens then they can't be followed immediately by another hyphen
```

Thanks!  ### Details for the issue

Sqlitebrowser crashes when viewing an SQL view in the Browse Data tab.

Background: This crash happens when viewing an SQL view in the browser tab.  I can reproduce the crash with a large database but not with a small test DB. To cause the crash, I just open the view, then idle. After a short time (varies), sqlitebrowser will crash.

```
Thread 1 "sqlitebrowser" received signal SIGSEGV, Segmentation fault.
0x00000000005ad826 in QString::size (this=0x8) at /usr/include/qt5/QtCore/qstring.h:231
231         inline int size() const { return d->size; }
```

The crash appears to be occurring in `SqliteTableModel::getForeignKeyClause()`
 (`sqlitetablemodel.cpp:276`)

**Has `obj` or `obj->name` has been freed then accessed?**.

```
#1  0x000000000063a327 in SqliteTableModel::getForeignKeyClause (this=0xd1e6c0, column=2) at /sqlitebrowser/src/sqlitetablemodel.cpp:276
276         if(obj->name().size() && (column >= 0 && column < obj->fields().count()))
```

```
(gdb) print obj
$12 = {value = 0x0, d = 0x0}
```

```
(gdb) print obj->name().size()

Thread 1 "sqlitebrowser" received signal SIGSEGV, Segmentation fault.
0x00000000005ad826 in QString::size (this=0x8) at /usr/include/qt5/QtCore/qstring.h:231
231         inline int size() const { return d->size; }
The program being debugged was signaled while in a function called from GDB.
GDB remains in the frame where the signal was received.
To change this behavior use "set unwindonsignal on".
Evaluation of the expression containing the function
(QString::size() const) will be abandoned.
When the function is done executing, GDB will silently stop.
```

 I've attached the dataset. Try browsing `TRIPS_STOPS_EXT`.

It looks like the code causing the crash is:

```
#2  0x000000000063a0d1 in SqliteTableModel::data (this=0xd23420, index=..., role=3) at /sqlitebrowser/src/sqlitetablemodel.cpp:258
258             sqlb::ForeignKeyClause fk = getForeignKeyClause(index.column()-1);
```

commenting out lines 258-261 seems to resolve the crash at the expense of a missing tooltip.

from:
```
        sqlb::ForeignKeyClause fk = getForeignKeyClause(index.column()-1);
        if(fk.isSet())
            return tr("References %1(%2)\nHold Ctrl+Shift and click to jump there").arg(fk.table()).arg(fk.columns().join(","));
        else
            return QString();
```
to
```
        // sqlb::ForeignKeyClause fk = getForeignKeyClause(index.column()-1);
        // if(fk.isSet())
        //     return tr("References %1(%2)\nHold Ctrl+Shift and click to jump there").arg(fk.table()).arg(fk.columns().join(","));
        // else
            return QString();
```

On Apr 10, 2017 7:27 AM, "Martin Kleusberg" <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> This is probably because of the Qt version. The QVector::removeAll()
> method was introduced in Qt 5.4 (see https://doc.qt.io/qt-5/
> qvector.html#removeAll), so when trying to compile with any version <5.4
> this error will occur. In theory we could work around that but I vaguely
> remember there being more features from newer Qt version that we're using...
>
> ‚Äî
> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/issues/994#issuecomment-292934620>,
> or mute the thread
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AHVA8paMe5xlO1p-D_d6kzIU9rMdAH-rks5ruiAhgaJpZM4M4atc>
> .

 No, I hadn't. Using DB4S version 3.9.99 (2017-03-30-win64) from the nightly builds does fix the font issue, however, it seems like that bottom log is using the same font as the "SQL Log" but a separate size setting whereas the right-side log is using the same font size as the editor.

- "SQL *editor* font" - affects all 3 locations
- "SQL *editor* font size - affects the editor and right-side log
- "SQL *log* font size" - affects just the bottom log

The naming scheme for the options is very unclear as to what they actually edit. There likely needs to be separate options for each location or a change in the naming scheme.  ### Details for the issue

On german UI under "Hilfe" there is a "SQL Ciper FAQ" item, which should be "SQL Cipher" I guess. The same "SQLCiper-Version" text also shows up in the about dialog for the version (3.11.0)

me where that setting is.  Promote Qt and add sqlitebrowser into https://showroom.qt.io/   This PR, when merged, will compile sqlitebrowser Travis CI upon each git push, and upload an [AppImage](http://appimage.org/) to a temporary download URL on transfer.sh (available for 14 days). The download URL is toward the end of each Travis CI build log of each build.

![screenshot from 2017-02-26 14-28-24](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2480569/23340063/fb904556-fc2f-11e6-9c44-5a7a278e223f.png)

Providing an [AppImage](http://appimage.org/) would have, among others, these advantages:
- Works for most Linux distributions (including Ubuntu, Fedora, openSUSE, CentOS, elementaryOS, Linux Mint, and others)
- One app = one file = super simple for users: just download one AppImage file, [make it executable](http://discourse.appimage.org/t/how-to-make-an-appimage-executable/80), and run
- No unpacking or installation necessary
- No root needed
- No system libraries changed
- Just one format for all major distributions
- Works out of the box, no installation of runtimes needed
- Optional(!) desktop integration with `appimaged`
- Binary delta updates, e.g., for continuous builds (only download the binary diff) using AppImageUpdate
- Can GPG2-sign your AppImages (inside the file)

[Here is an overview](https://github.com/probonopd/AppImageKit/wiki/AppImages) of projects that are already distributing upstream-provided, official AppImages.

An example AppImage can be downloaded from here:
https://transfer.sh/UiNPi/sqlitebrowser-git.021f836-x86-64.appimage (available for 14 days)  I would suggest to create an AppImage for Linux. 
Several Qt application does it by using https://github.com/probonopd/linuxdeployqt/ 
Personnaly I prefere compile myself or getting application from the PPA. But for some people appImage would be greate. See http://appimage.org/ Started working on it [here](https://github.com/probonopd/sqlitebrowser/blob/patch-1/.travis.yml). Sent Pull Request https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/pull/969. Instead of storing AppImage builds temporarily for 14 days each on transfer.sh, you could use GitHub Releases to store the binaries permanently. This way, they would be visible on the [Releases](https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/releases) page of your project. This is what I recommend. See https://docs.travis-ci.com/user/deployment/releases/. If you want to do this for continuous builds, also see https://github.com/probonopd/uploadtool. > We have a server for nightly releases, which could hold those kind of development centred builds.

Excellent. Indeed, https://nightlies.sqlitebrowser.org/ is badly missing Linux builds right now.

By the way, uploadtool deletes the prior continuous build and then uploads the latest one, so that there is always only one "continuous" tag on GitHub Releases.   Fix #965   ### Details for the issue

I cant define pragmas on the run-sql tab. E. g. if I type and execute "pragma auto_vacuum = 1;" and choose the tab "edit pragmas" i cant see my changes.

Its also not working when i modify the options directly on the "edit pragmas" tab, also if i hit the "save" button hundrets of times.

But i found a workaround, if i type and execute this:
end transaction;
pragma auto_vacuum = 1;

and after that I clicked the "compact database" option on the menu strip, then changes were accepted.

 Sorry - tested its works :)  ### Details for the issue

When running `sqlitebrowser` built from source, I am seeing a SIGSEGV on application start. The backtrace in `gdb` looks like:

```
(gdb) bt
#0  0x00007ffff303f72c in _GLOBAL__sub_I_qprinterinfo.cpp () from /lib64/libQtGui.so.4
#1  0x00007ffff7dec1e3 in _dl_init_internal () from /lib64/ld-linux-x86-64.so.2
#2  0x00007ffff7dde21a in _dl_start_user () from /lib64/ld-linux-x86-64.so.2
#3  0x0000000000000001 in ?? ()
#4  0x00007fffffffdf58 in ?? ()
#5  0x0000000000000000 in ?? ()
```

Given I know that `sqlitebrowser` used to work under RHEL 7.2, I used `git bisect` to find where the problem was introduced:

* `git checkout c0d2e9131ea1bf9eded26f4c3de868d0fbad000a && git clean -f -d x . && cmake . && make -j12 && ./sqlitebrowser` -- fails

* `git checkout c0d2e9131ea1bf9eded26f4c3de868d0fbad000a~1 && git clean -f -d x . && cmake . && make -j12 && ./sqlitebrowser` -- succeeds

So it seems that the offending commit is:

* https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/commit/c0d2e9131ea1bf9eded26f4c3de868d0fbad000a

 @MKleusberg: -- not sure if this helps:

* `git checkout c0d2e9131ea1bf9eded26f4c3de868d0fbad000a && git clean -f -d x . && cmake . && make -j12`
* `ldd sqlitebrowser | grep scintilla2` == `/lib64/libqscintilla2.so.11`
* `ldd /lib64/libqscintilla2.so.11 | grep -i qtcore` == `/lib64/libQtCore.so.4`
* `strings /lib64/libQtCore.so.4 | grep "4\." | grep "QtCore"` (as per https://kb.froglogic.com/display/KB/Article+-+Getting+the+version+of+Qt+libraries) == `This is the QtCore library version 4.8.5` @MKleusberg: yup `cmake -DFORCE_INTERNAL_QSCINTILLA=ON .` makes it work on master! Worst comes to the worst, I can create a pull request that just adds some words to `BUILDING.md` stating "if your system-wide version of QScintilla isn't built to support Qt5, please build using `-DFORCE_INTERNAL_QSCINTILLA=ON`".  I am working with Arabic Language saved in UNICODE Format in SQLite. I want to implement a search. But there's a problem.

Let's say the text is

```
<html>
  <head>
    <style>
      @font-face {
        font-family: "Al_Mushaf";
        src: url('fonts/al_mushaf.ttf');
      }
      @font-face {
        font-family: "Jameel Noori Nastaleeq";
        src: url('fonts/jameel_noori.ttf');
      }
    </style>
  </head>
  <body>
    <h3 style='font-family:"Al_Mushaf"'>
            ŸàŸéÿß€°ŸÖŸèÿ±Ÿí 
    </h3>
  </body>
</html>
```

And it is stored in SQLite Database. Now I want to search `html`, it will return the result and if I search  `ŸàÿßŸÖÿ±` it won't return a result because in actual text, it is `ŸàŸéÿßŸíŸÖŸèÿ±Ÿí` (with these extra UNICODE).

I want to ignore all HTML tags and these extra UNICODE Characters while searching so that `html` shouldn't return a result while `ŸàÿßŸÖÿ±` should return a result.

What I found so far;

1. Make extra column and put stripped text into it and then search (I can't do it because there are thousands of books and they will take a lot of memory)
2. UDF Like SQL (I couldn't find any suitable example/tutorial to implement it)
3. Using REGEXP (I couldn't figure it out yet how to do this, I just know that I've to implement it myself)
4. SQL query using LIKE and GLOB operators and wildcard characters.

I'm stuck for two days and couldn't find a working solution. Option#4 is desirable but any working solution will do the charm.

Meanwhile, I've to keep application memory efficient and optimized searching.

Any help is highly appreciated.

What I've done so far
1. I've made regex to ignore html tags and text between style tag and used it in query with REGEXP.
Now there are two problems,
    - I want to ignore these extra characters too. I know their UNICODEs, just need to know how to append it in the regex. This is my regex;
`(?![^<]*>)(?!<style[^>]*?>)(TEXT)(?![^<]*?<\/style>)`
    - I've used it in query like
`SELECT text FROM dummy WHERE text REGEXP <myregex>`
It's not giving an error but not returning the desired result too.

2. I've compiled `sqlite3` library in my project. I am now looking for anyone to help me with writing a function for my regex, attach it to database and call it from query.
 Thank you for guiding me. I will definitely do so.  ### Details for the issue

I dont know if one of there tables has some lost data because only the "chat_list" and "messages" tables are  important for that merging and I only tried to export and import these. @justinclift, still not enough data to understand what is going on in a particular case, but it seems to me that the problem is that at the time of import, while inserting rows with existing PK's doesn't output any error messages.

For example, lets create a table and add the 3 rows:

    CREATE TABLE `table` (`pk` INTEGER, `text` TEXT, PRIMARY KEY(`pk`));
    INSERT INTO `table` (`pk`, `text`) VALUES (1, 'a'), (2, 'b'), (3, 'c');

trying to import:

    BEGIN TRANSACTION;
    INSERT INTO `table` (`pk`, `text`) VALUES (1, 'X'), (2, 'Y'), (3, 'Z');
    COMMIT;

The import process will take place without any error messages, although it should be an error:

    UNIQUE constraint failed: table.pk: INSERT INTO `table` (`pk`, `text`) VALUES (1, 'X'), (2, 'Y'), (3, 'Z');

  I have the following sql script which when I load it, it successfully commits.
There should be an error. The first INSERT INTO fails with a check constraint and the record is ignored.
Expected result is for the transaction to fail.

BEGIN TRANSCTION;
CREATE TABLE `types` (
	`uuid`	TEXT DEFAULT (lower(hex(randomblob(4))||'-'||hex(randomblob(2))||'-'||hex(randomblob(2))||'-'||hex(randomblob(2))||'-'||hex(randomblob(6)))) CHECK(uuid regexp '^[a-f0-9]{8}-[a-f0-9]{4}-[a-f0-9]{4}-[a-f0-9]{4}-[a-f0-9]{12}$'),
	`description`	TEXT NOT NULL,
	PRIMARY KEY(`uuid`)
);
INSERT INTO `types` (uuid,description) VALUES ('6d15a5615-0000-43ff-b4f2-762b0dbfb4e6', 'Substitution');
INSERT INTO `types` (uuid,description) VALUES ('615a5615-0001-43ff-b4f2-762b0dbfb4e6', 'URL');
INSERT INTO `types` (uuid,description) VALUES ('615a5615-0002-43ff-b4f2-762b0dbfb4e6', 'Date');
COMMIT;

	`id`	TEXT NOT NULL DEFAULT (randomblob(6)),
	`name`	INTEGER,
	PRIMARY KEY(`id`)
);

I was able to run a create table statement on the database after opening it so a database is getting created but not the one I am trying to install.     In appcelerator the Ti.Database.install(dbfilename) method will create an empty database if it fails to install the one given as dbfilename.  So if the file format is somehow not compatible or if the file is not found it will create the empty db.
    i want save text in right side! but when i click Apply ,text save in left side!
i can not save it right side!
please see video,how can i  save in right side!?help me please
https://youtu.be/LmHSJrNqi6c @justinclift   same problem in  nightly build!  i can not save in right side! The problem is actually that sqlitebrowser doesn't set the direction for that textbox to LTR automaticly. It should do that as all other widgets. I'll check. I think it's because of the text formatting (It's a richtext widget).

And for the bug, it is not. This is the right and correct behaviour. You can't save in "Right side", because you started the text with a LTR direction letter.
It doesn't matter really for the database, but visually, it matters.
You can force the text direction to be RTL when viewing the page (seems to be a webpage). @awi1369 Can you please write the information of your system locale? I tested it in Windows 10 with both English and Arabic locales, and the text in the edit box was aligned to left (And it's direction is LTR).
Appeared as:
<div dir="ltr">
H5:
</div>
and not (as you have):
<div dir="rtl">
H5:
</div>  #945  ### Details for the issue
Export cvs files don't use utf-8 as character settings so my Swedish letters are being translated to something else.

 This is a duplicate of #781 as far as I can tell Hm. Maybe I‚Äôll fork the project then. Is the issue still related to SQLCipher? Yes line 41 is exactly where it is (and line 80 for x64).

All you should need to do is define the preprocessor flag SQLITE_ENABLE_FTS5.

I‚Äôm a little unclear as to why FTS4 is even working in your current build since you don‚Äôt define those preprocessor flags anywhere, and FTS3 and FTS4 are not enabled by default either. But wherever you‚Äôre compiling SQLite, as long as you make sure SQLITE_ENABLE_FTS5 (and ‚Ä¶_FTS3 and ‚Ä¶_FTS4) are defined, that should be all you need to do. Agreed. Although again I‚Äôm not sure why FTS is working at all in DB Browser without those flags ‚Äì and it does work - so I‚Äôm curious if this makes a difference. It should though. In the version that has SQLCipher, are you using SQLCipher‚Äôs implementation of SQLite even for non-encrypted databases? That would explain why FTS works in the official Windows build. And if so we would need to use the non-SQLCipher version. Both copies can work for me.
I was able to create, rebuild, search and delete the fts5 table(s).

This is great! Thanks. Also confirmed, it‚Äôs working great. Thanks so much for getting this done so quickly. And for the great piece of software; it‚Äôs a huge time saver for me in optimizing queries for my application. Oh great. Sure would be happy to.

(Incidentally I wish I knew SQLCipher existed two years ago because I would up making a custom SQLite VFS for encrypted databases in Windows. Works great but man was that painful‚Ä¶). Sorry for the lag. Yeah FTS5 is working perfectly! I haven‚Äôt tried out more advanced features like ranking or highlighting but I have no reason to doubt they‚Äôll work (or if they don‚Äôt it‚Äôs an SQLite problem and nothing to do with your code).

Thanks again, seriously.  #941  ### Details for the issue

 Are you able to recreate this issue? (if you still have your Mate VM from the last issue I filed) :) Fair enough.  Like I said, it's probably a bug in VirtualBox but figured
you might have some good insight into it  Support of operator 'BETWEEN'. For example for column with filter '400~500' will be generated WHERE statement 'BETWEEN 400 AND 500'.

Example of wrong filters:
```
500~400
a~b
1~a
```

#935 @justinclift, not sure why its so much commits in PR. How to remove merge commits? @justinclift I thought to do so, but it didnt happened. How am I going to create a second PR?
New commit is adding to already existing one. @justinclift added to bookmarks. Thank you so much.  ### Details for the issue
Query tabs can be closed without any prompt to save or warning about lost data. 

I had several queries open for a coding test.  Each query corresponded to an answer to a test question.  I had saved the queries to SQL files, but i needed to close the database.  I closed out of all the open query tabs, not realizing i had made changes to each of them after I had last saved.  To my dismay, when I opened the files again all my changes were lost.  It cost me a couple hours of lost work.  

In other database management GUI, when the user clicks to close out a query they are presented with a prompt like "You have unsaved changes.  Do you want to save before closing?" to prevent lost work.  DB Browser should add this for unsaved query tabs.

Pls help  If I have an INTEGER column I can filter the numbers in it using the supported operators from this page https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/wiki/Using-the-Filters.

Is it possible to have a filter for **range** (- or \~)? Something like _min-max_ (or _min~max_) to show only the numbers in this range. For example, If I want to filter a column with numbers between 1 and 5 I can type in filter something like **1-5** (or **1~5**). It is like combining _Equal to or greater_ and _Equal to or less_ together.

Also, maybe we can have an **and** (,) operator? To show only specific numbers we can type something like **1,2,5**.

Trying to view and modify an existing database. The viewing and modifying work fine with SQLite Database Browser 2.0 b1 (which I believe is an "ancestor" of DB Browser for SQLite), but with DB Browser for SQLite, things do not work as expected.

The database opens, but using "Browse Data", if certain tables are selected (but not all), the list of fields of that table is not anything like what is shown with DB Browser for SQLite. Selecting some tables produces the expected result, but then if certain other tables are selected, the field descriptions from the previous table are retained instead of being updated to the new table.

A Quick question about licensing with SQLCipher - am I able to use its encryption abilities in my application as I want to release it as a commercial product (shareware) and would really like to have the data encrypted - Im not too good at reading licenses, its like reading a contract and it completes loses me :S

[dbs.zip](https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/files/682145/dbs.zip)
 Ah right. Ok. Here's some info I used to do the password - it looks like the .NET components use RSA to encrypt it with a password:

You can password protect SQLite3 DB. For the first time before doing any operations, set password as follows.

SQLiteConnection conn = new SQLiteConnection("Data Source=MyDatabase.sqlite;Version=3;");
conn.SetPassword("password");
conn.open();
then next time you can access it like

conn = new SQLiteConnection("Data Source=MyDatabase.sqlite;Version=3;Password=password;");
conn.Open();
**This wont allow any GUI editor to view your data. Some editors can decrypt the DB if you provide the password. The algorithm used is RSA.**

Later if you wish to change the password, use

conn.ChangePassword("new_password");
To reset or remove password, use

conn.ChangePassword(String.Empty);

I guess I will probably have to either
(1) use unprotected DB until I do a release (as it works fine through VS2015)
or
(2) wait for a possible update as this will affect all .NET users who use sqlite browser.

I'll stick with number 1 and occasionally check it with (2) on builds in case its something that is in the pipework (or has been broken). Im assuming at one point it did work, Sqlite is a great desktop database (much better than access mdb's).

Thanks for your help anyway - at least i have learned something more about Sqlite today :)
 I use VS Community Edition 2015.

The .net SQLite component is the general one (I assume), downloaded via github, using the NuGet package manager for solution, I type in SQLite and the search term, System.Data.SQLite by SQLite Development Team 1.12M downloads "The Official SQLite database engine for both x86 and x64 along with the ADO.NET providers" is in the description.

From what I have discovered, is the switching on a password protected database, encrypts it with RSA as per this link: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/5669905/sqlite-with-encryption-password-protection  ### Useful extra information

Similarly to #505, it looks like Sqlite has an issue when opening a database with VIRTUAL tables:

```
Sqlite parse error:  "line 1:8: unexpected token: VIRTUAL" ( "CREATE VIRTUAL TABLE TokenizerTable USING fts3tokenize(\n                    unicodesn,\n                    \"stemmer=french\"\n                )" )
Sqlite parse error:  "line 1:8: unexpected token: VIRTUAL" ( "CREATE VIRTUAL TABLE MessageSearchTable USING fts4(\n    body,\n    attachment,\n    subject,\n    from_field,\n    receivers,\n    cc,\n    bcc,\n    \n    tokenize=simple,\n    prefix=\"2,4,6,8,10\"\n)" )
```

This seems to have no effect though except of this in logs. This is a [Geary](https://github.com/GNOME/geary) mail-client database, if needed.

 Hi! I can see that the word VIRTUAL is not part of the list of tokens in sqlite3.g. This probably (have a bit of work to do until I understand things fully) is the reason it is not understood.

To the people that has coded this: is this a conscious design decision, or simply a missed detail? I can do a bit of testing to see if I can update the grammar with the full language description in the next few days (have a little bit of time available). Thank you.
I agree that the grammar thing seems the least difficult, had something in place (probably not as good as your solution).

Modules for creating virtual tables seems to each have their own grammar: the fts5 module as example has quite a few extras. So in order to be simple to use, the db Browser should know the standard modules grammars. Additionally, perhaps, the support tables created by a module could be treated somewhat differently from ‚Äúnormal‚Äù tables.

A bit of fun, and a long road for me get up to speed in things I haven¬¥t done for a long time.
/Gunnar

  ### Details for the issue
When using SQLiteBrowser on a Win10 system with multiple displays, for instance where two are FullHD and one is 4k (with different scaling settings), it doesn't scale down to the correct FHD ratio when the application is dragged onto one of the FHD displays.

### Useful extra information

But the only way to see those changes is to close the database and to re-open it. It would be great if there was a menu option to reload the complete database. Yes that seems to do the trick, exactly what I needed!  Would be really cool to have profiler feature.

There is no SQLite profiler out there, so would be a first.
 I think SQLite has profiling built-in, like you said, but it's text-based and not easy to use. No SQLite tool right now has proper GUI profiling.

I don't know if SQLite would support that though, because a profiler, when listening, will automatically list queries sent to the db. You don't need to interact with it, just keep the window open and see what is happening.

Can SQLite do such a thing, that is listen for events? @MKleusberg I see what you mean. I guess it's not possible. What a pity!

Not being able to see what commands are sent to the database, makes development and debugging a real pain. @justinclift Unless I'm using it wrongly, I don't think that the log tab does it. What I do: 

  - load sqlitebrowser, open my SQLite database file
  - run my app, perform some operation which hits that database
  - observe the log tab

...and nothing is logged there. Not under "Application" or "User".  Does the SQLiteBrowser support [a-z] and _  wildcards? I have been unsuccessful in getting any results from the following queries, despite the face that my table (Keywords) has the word 'hello' in the Keyword field:

SELECT * FROM Keywords WHERE (Keyword LIKE '[h]%' )

SELECT * FROM Keywords WHERE (Keyword LIKE '_ello' )

The link on the "edit pragmas' tab for the "User Version" pragma is wrong

Clicking it takes you to `http://www.sqlite.org/pragma.html#pragma_schema_version` when it should take you to `http://www.sqlite.org/pragma.html#pragma_user_version` instead

  ### Details for the issue

Tried to install the new DB Browser for SQLite on my win32 XP Prof. SP3 machine, but:
- refuses to load: no valid win32 application, uninstall, reinstall: no change
- load into debugger: windbg/ollydgb: cannot stat, no valid win32 ...

### Useful extra information

- look on PE32 header, and find: optional PE32 has os-version major set to 6 = Vista (minor to 0)
- googled and found: VC2012 SP0 (not SP1) dropped XP support by setting os-version to 6

#### I'm opening this issue because:

- [X] DB4S is crashing
- [ ] DB4S has a bug
- [ ] DB4S needs a feature
- [X] DB4S has another problem

#### I'm using DB4S on:

- [X] Windows: (XP Prof SP3 version: 5.1)
- [ ] Linux: ( _distro:_ ___ )
- [ ] Mac OS: ( _version:_ ___ )
- [ ] Other: ___

#### I'm using DB4S version:

- [X] 3.9.1
- [ ] 3.9.0
- [ ] Other: ___

#### I have also:

- [ ] Tried out the nightly version: https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser#windows
- [X] Searched for an existing similar issue: https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/issues?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=is%3Aissue%20
 and BTW: patching offset 40/44 of the PE Header from 0006 to 0005 allows the program to run flawlessly, so it is no technical limitation, only a political - was this a deliberate decision? there is an easy way, see here:
https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/jj851139(v=vs.120).aspx
and if switching to VS 2015, there still is:
https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/jj851139(v=vs.140).aspx
it's just a setting ... and BTW:
> XP has practically no users

netmarketshare 11/2016: 8.63%, more than 8.1 and more than all MacOS together, and way more than Linux:
that's "practically no" for you?!? So what version runs on XP or what shall be done to run it on XP? @iRybin: as I said already in comment 2, if you are able to operate a hexeditor, just changing offset 0x40 and 0x44 of the sqlitebrowser.exe executable from 0x0006 (Vista) to 0x0005 (XP) is all that's needed - it is not a technical reason, just a restrictive labeling that alienates XP users ... @h1618 @iRybin ~If that helps, the [nighly builds](https://nightlies.sqlitebrowser.org/win32/) run fine on XP SP3, even on CPUs without SSE2. There is a note in the project front page to test them in case of trouble. :smile:~ @justinclift @h1618 @iRybin Hmmm. Unfortunately seems that the new nigthly builds available don't work with XP SP3 anymore. :sob:

The latest version that can confirm that works with XP SP3 is 2016-10-01, but is not available to download anymore.

In my case if I'm doing it right, patching the PE header in the binary as @h1618 suggest doesn't help: the program then loads but crashes immediately with an exception. :confused: @h1618 If patching the PE header fixed the "not a valid Win32 application" error and allowed you to run DB4S without problems, then I believe the fix is very simple.

Microsoft dropped support for Windows XP on newer versions of Visual Studio by setting *SystemVersion* (offset 0x0040) in the PE header for all generated .exe to version 6 (Windows Vista) by the linker. MinGW on the other hand set this value to 4 (Windows 95/NT).

DB4S is built using MSVC (2013) without setting the minimum operating system to 5 (XP) so the .exe gets the default one 6 (Vista). I believe changing `/SUBSYSTEM:WINDOWS` (version not set, defaults to 6.00) to `/SUBSYSTEM:WINDOWS,5.01` (for Windows XP, and 5.02 for Windows XP 64-bit) in [CMakeLists.txt](https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/blob/master/CMakeLists.txt#L323) will make the .exe run on Windows XP without problems. This will just change the minimum *operating system/subsystem version* that are set by the linker. More information on [MSDN](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/fcc1zstk(v=vs.120).aspx).

@justinclift I think DB4S used to work on Windows XP when using the old build system because it was **not** using MSVC. @justinclift Unfortunately I don't have much experience with CMake.

`devenv.exe` (Visual Studio) works with `.vcxproj` XML project files, and will not accept that /SUBSYSTEM switch. It is a linker switch and should be added to CMake so it can generate a working `.vcxproj` file for `devenv` to use.

Try editing the `CMakeList.txt` and add the switch there, then look at the generated `.vcxproj` file. You should find something like..

    <ItemDefinitionGroup Condition="'$(Configuration)|$(Platform)'=='Release|Win32'">
        <Link>
            <SubSystem>Windows</SubSystem>
            <MinimumRequiredVersion>5.01</MinimumRequiredVersion>
        </Link>
    </ItemDefinitionGroup>

If you found `<MinimumRequiredVersion>5.01</MinimumRequiredVersion>` then it should work.

Another solution is by editing the source files. Something like..

    #ifdef _MSC_VER
    #    pragma comment(linker, "/subsystem:windows,5.01")
    #endif

Finally, a quick solution is by editing the .exe file using [`editbin`](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/d25ddyfc(v=vs.120).aspx) and change the subsystem right after building it. Something like..

    editbin DB4S.exe /SUBSYSTEM:WINDOWS,5.01
    editbin DB4S_x64.exe /SUBSYSTEM:WINDOWS,5.02 

**NOTE:** Windows XP 64-bit was introduced later than the 32-bit version so it got a different version. Personally I don't think the editbin solution is ideal. If something else changes in Qt or elsewhere and we actually drop XP support but then use this to "add it back" then we could be covering up a multitude of issues. So, we should do this with the linker really.

However I would vote for dropping XP support completely. @glawrence `editbin` will not add/remove support for XP. It will just set the minimum operating system version in the PE header so the OS can load it. This is exactly what the linker will do after combining all the object codes into an executable.

It is perfectly fine to set it to a lower value too. The latest version of MinGW set it to 4 (Windows 95/NT), even if you are targeting newer OS like Windows 7 or higher. An application will not work of course if it cannot find the newer Win32 APIs.

Judging by @h1618 solution (patching the exe) that worked for him then I guess DB4S is not using any newer APIs higher than Windows XP, and I don't see a reason to *drop* XP support. In fact, building the same source and using the same build system but with a different compiler other than MSVC will make it work.

I know supporting and maintaining older OS versions is hard, if you have to write code like this a lot..

```cpp
#if (_WIN32_WINNT >= 0x0601)
    // Windows 7 or higher
#else
    // Windows XP and lower
#endif
```
But this is not the case here. It is just changing a couple of bytes in DB4S executable. Using the linker switch, `#pragma` in the source code, or `editbin` will accomplish that. To be honest, I think `editbin` is the best solution since almost everyone here wants to drop XP support.

How about making a new installer just for XP? So, after the build system make windows packages, it copies them, patch them using `editbin` then release as Windows XP only. Even better, make a new release for *older* versions of windows by using 4.00 (Windows 95/98/ME/2000/XP) instead of 5.01.

As long as DB4S is not using newer Windows APIs it should work fine on older versions, without making any changes to the source code. If DB4S started using newer APIs then you can immediately stop releasing the older versions package and drop support for it, but not before that I hope.

@chrisjlocke I don't use Windows XP and yes I know it is old but I also know it is still has a large user base. Microsoft tried to drop support (stop making exe that will run on XP) for it in VS 2012 and failed. They were *forced*, by the huge user base, to add support for it in VS 2012, 2013, 2015.

I use Windows 7 and I continue to use it even after Microsoft [dropped support for it](https://support.microsoft.com/en-us/help/13853/windows-lifecycle-fact-sheet) about a year ago and I think most of DB4S windows users are on Windows 7.

If you don't want to support older OS then be ready in 3 years to find a way to make DB4S work on Windows 7 when its *extended support* ends in 2020, and Microsoft raises the minimum operating system version to Windows 8/10 in MSVC. @justinclift I agree with you, and that's why I prefer the `editbin` way, since it doesn't mess with the project build system or source code, and no files need to be changed. You can add it in the batch file that create the windows builds, and make a new installer for *legacy* windows.

Anyway, no one can support XP forever while every project is dropping support for it. According to this [comment](http://blog.qt.io/blog/2016/04/21/qt-5-7-beta-released/#comment-1197572) in Qt blog, Qt 5.6 LTS is the latest version to support XP. So keep that in mind when upgrading Qt. No support for XP? Too hard? Yeah, I hear ya. Too hard to use your product as well when there are so many other choices that do work...SQL Server, Oracle, MySQL, PostgreSQL, Redis, MongoDB. Wasn't too hard for them apparently ; )  ### Details for the issue

When SQL is executed in sqlitebrowser, the resulting table can be exportet to csv.
Generated csv-files are difficult to import into e.g. MS Excel, because for each datarow, the trailing separator is missing. When importing, the last column value of the first datarow is not ending with the desired separating character. The next datarow does not start with a separator, so at this point things get messed up.

  ### Details for the issue

If you open a database in DB4S that is also open in another process, then if you make changes to the database and click "Write Changes", the changes are not written to the database.  The journal file goes away and the changes remain in DB4S in memory, but as soon as the database is closed and reopened, the changes are gone.  There is no warning or error displayed.

  This tool is pretty useful for exploring the Core Data database for iOS apps, so I decided to add a display format for Apple NSDates  ### Details for the issue
At the end of an install, the installer asks if you would like to run the program.  If you leave that checkbox ticked yes, then the installer doesn't drop its own administrative priveleges before running DB Browser.  DB Browser, thus, gets run with those priveleges.

The Reg-key is located at `HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\Applications\sqlite_auto_file\shell\open\command` and there exists a key (REG_SZ) with name `(Default)` with the value of `"C:\Program Files\DB Browser for SQLite\3.9.0\bin\DB Browser for SQLite.exe" "%1"` (which i will now update)  When using the modify table option, adding a field (new column) you can select all SQLite types except BOOLEAN. Hard to believe that the author added the right click menu items then 
didn't test them.:-)  My suggestions: when a field is just created, it gets a name like `FieldN` and then after you rename it upon creation, [`bool DBBrowserDB::renameColumn`](https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/blob/17369b66a62f748aba6106ce59554096dec38667/src/sqlitedb.cpp#L957) method gets called. However, this method obtains the version of a table which still has the old name of the field because table schemas are loaded [directly from database](https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/blob/17369b66a62f748aba6106ce59554096dec38667/src/sqlitedb.cpp#L1186-L1201), therefore [the membership check](https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/blob/17369b66a62f748aba6106ce59554096dec38667/src/sqlitedb.cpp#L982) fails. If you move field up, the same [`bool DBBrowserDB::renameColumn`](https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/blob/17369b66a62f748aba6106ce59554096dec38667/src/sqlitedb.cpp#L957) method gets called.

Currently I have no idea how to make this right. Here is my traceback when moving a field (truncated for short):

- [x ] Searched for an existing similar issue: https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/issues?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=is%3Aissue%20 Sorry Martin,  This was a misunderstanding with me and Apple‚Äôs CoreData.  CoreData ‚Äîno matter what I tried, showed up an error that my  table did not exist, when it did and I could see it by using SB. 

I was trying to pre-population a store and put it in my app bundle.

Once I got my head on straight and read their technical bulletin for the hundredth time, I figure out all I have to do was open their store with SB and fill it in with my data make a copy of that store and put it in my bundle, done.

  ### Details for the issue

Clicking on the 'Browse Data' tab always loads the first table or view alphabetically. After selecting the correct table, going to another tab and then coming back to 'Browse Data', it's the first table again. And if it's a big one, it takes time loading data you _weren't_ trying to browse.

So Feature request: 'Browse Data' should remember the last table/view you were on before having switched to another tab. (For that session.)

I'd consider this a bug - not remembering the last table/view in the Data Browser - but if it was never planned/intended, then it's a feature request.


#### I'm opening this issue because:

- [ ] DB4S is crashing
- [x] DB4S has a bug
- [x] DB4S needs a feature
- [ ] DB4S has another problem

#### I'm using DB4S on:

- [x] Windows: ( _version:_ _7_ )
- [ ] Linux: ( _distro:_ ___ )
- [ ] Mac OS: ( _version:_ ___ )

  ### Details for the issue

<!--

Thanks for coming here to report an issue. :)

Please describe it in this section, fill out the correct check boxes
below with an "x", then click the "Submit new issue" button at the bottom

-->
STEPS TO REPRODUCE:

On the tab "Execute SQL", create a new SQL file and save it to your local drive.
Make a change to the document.
Click CTRL-S.
GET: File is not saved.
EXPECT: File to save.

Click "Save" button on toolbar.
GET EXPECTED: File is saved.

REASON: Every windows user in the world expects CTRL-S to save the current file regardless of the application (e.g. Notepad++, etc.). It is built into our fingers. Thank Microsoft for that. CTRL-SHIFT-S often saves all documents.

  When trying to delete all records or large number of
them (~5000) (selecting them and pressing Delete Record on Data tab), it
takes too much time to execute this operation due to large number of
queries like `DELETE * FROM 'table' WHERE '_rowid_' = id`.  ### Details for the issue

<!--

Some multi-line queries having comments at the end of a line do not work.
For example, this one:

    SELECT
        ID,
        label -- fails
    FROM example;

I get the following message in the lower part of the window:
```
Error executing query: SELECT
	ID,
	shortName -- fails
FROM example;
```
However, this one is OK:

    SELECT
        ID,
        label -- doesn't fail
    FROM example;

Could it be related to the apostrophe?

  Hi, I was working with version 3.7.0 but now it's not working on MacOs.. Just FYI.  ### Details for the issue

I had Windows configured to associate the .db extension with DB4S in version 3.9.0.  When I upgraded to 3.9.1, I removed 3.9.0 and had to reassociate the extension.  To do this I:
1. Double click the .db file
2. In the "Open With" dialog, browse to C:\Program Files\DB Browser for SQLite and double click the exe

At this point the dialog doesn't recognize that an application was selected.

If I replace the spaces in the executable name with with underscores (i.e. DB_Browser_for_SQLite), the association works correctly.

I reinstalled 3.9.0 and found that it has the same executable naming convention as 3.9.1, so I have a feeling that the underscore solution may be a red herring.

 That tool sure spits out a lot of noise,

Here's my procedure:
1. Open process monitor, disabled capturing and cleared the output
2. Got to the Open With dialog, browsed to the path (C:\Program Files\DB Browser for SQLite), and selected the exe (didn't click open yet).  
3. Started capturing in the process monitor, quickly switched over and clicked Open in the dialog, then back to turn off capturing.

I've attached the PML log.  If you want it as CSV or XML let me know.  Here's what I see that's interesting with the Registry and File System Activity enabled.
1. 4:55:13.9534235 - Looks like the first time DB4S is accessed. 
2. There are then a lot of registry hits, some of which look like they may be looking for EXEs
3. 4:55:13.9751138 - It looks like there are a series of registry accesses for DB4S
4. 4:55:13.9767010 - I see an access for the 3.9.0 path that I used to have

I imagine that something is still pointing to the 3.9.0 path in registry, Windows gets confused and just punts.
[Logfile.zip](https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/files/570186/Logfile.zip)

On a hunch, I jumped into regedit and looked at HKCU\Software\Classes\Applications\DB Browser for SQLite.exe\shell\open\command, and that looks like the culprit.  It has a value of "C:\Program Files\DB Browser for SQLite\3.9.0\bin\DB Browser for SQLite.exe" "%1" 

So it looks to me that either the 3.9.0 uninstall didn't clean this up or the 3.9.1 install didn't overwrite it.  Also, the reason that adding the underscores worked is that it pointed it to a new registry key.

Let me know if you need anything else from me.
 In windows 10 is't super simple, but .sqlite and .db association would be a great addition to the installer.  ### Details for the issue

It would be helpful to (have the option to) always have a blank row ready at the bottom of a table for new data entry. This would save the steps of clicking "new record" and then selecting which value to enter.

My use case is for relatively rapid manual data entry during an athletic event. The data will be used for displaying current results. I am using `DEFAULT CURRENT_TIME` in order to match the entry time to the racer bib number that is entered. Processing and display will be handled in R/Shiny.

- [ ] Searched for an existing similar issue: https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/issues?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=is%3Aissue%20
 @chrisjlocke, I'm considering a custom application, but I figured I would try an existing database interface first. My main sticking point is to be able to change "bad" data in table form; this seems more complicated to code than just accepting a series of bib numbers.

@justinclift, I was thinking of a row that wouldn't actually be written until non-default values were entered, which if possible would mean no rows full of keys or timestamps but nothing else. I don't know how much harder that is to do, though.
    What about using `DELETE FROM `table` WHERE `_rowid_` IN ( ... )` here https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/blob/60e4cb758ed58db3a8d01cb13e82d79cf2d3ef33/src/sqlitedb.cpp#L873-L876 in all cases regardless of whether one or multiple records should be deleted?
 It turns out that the method `removeRow` of `SqliteTableModel` object gets invoked [here](https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/blob/982e4c4d346e066b72e8a8df2d47fa00c0075269/src/MainWindow.cpp#L589), and since [`SqliteTableModel`](https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/blob/982e4c4d346e066b72e8a8df2d47fa00c0075269/src/sqlitetablemodel.h#L11) is a subclass of [`QAbstractTableModel`](https://github.com/qt/qt/blob/0a2f2382541424726168804be2c90b91381608c6/src/corelib/kernel/qabstractitemmodel.h#L345) which is, in turn, a subclass of `QAbstractItemModel`, the following code from Qt library is executed:

``` c++
inline bool QAbstractItemModel::removeRow(int arow, const QModelIndex &aparent)
{ return removeRows(arow, 1, aparent); }
```

that is, it forces us to have only 1 row deleted.
My backtrace on deletion looks like this:

``` gdb
(gdb) backtrace
#0  DBBrowserDB::deleteRecord (this=0xba25c8, table=..., rowid=...)
    at /home/oleg/–î–æ–∫—É–º–µ–Ω—Ç—ã/–ø—Ä–æ–≥—Ä–∞–º–º–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ/Sources/sqlitebrowser/src/sqlitedb.cpp:870
#1  0x00000000005ee5cf in SqliteTableModel::removeRows (this=0xb949d0, row=40, count=1, parent=...)
    at /home/oleg/–î–æ–∫—É–º–µ–Ω—Ç—ã/–ø—Ä–æ–≥—Ä–∞–º–º–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ/Sources/sqlitebrowser/src/sqlitetablemodel.cpp:415

    at /home/oleg/–î–æ–∫—É–º–µ–Ω—Ç—ã/–ø—Ä–æ–≥—Ä–∞–º–º–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ/Sources/sqlitebrowser/build/moc_MainWindow.cpp:438

   from /opt/qt57/lib/libQt5Gui.so.5

#24 0x00007ffff4755e04 in g_main_context_dispatch () from /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libglib-2.0.so.0

#27 0x00007ffff6d2329c in QEventDispatcherGlib::processEvents(QFlags<QEventLoop::ProcessEventsFlag>) () from /opt/qt57/lib/libQt5Core.so.5
#28 0x00007ffff6cd2bbb in QEventLoop::exec(QFlags<QEventLoop::ProcessEventsFlag>) () from /opt/qt57/lib/libQt5Core.so.5
#29 0x00007ffff6cda9b6 in QCoreApplication::exec() () from /opt/qt57/lib/libQt5Core.so.5
#30 0x0000000000634f58 in main (argc=2, argv=0x7fffffffe3b8)
    at /home/oleg/–î–æ–∫—É–º–µ–Ω—Ç—ã/–ø—Ä–æ–≥—Ä–∞–º–º–∏—Ä–æ–≤–∞–Ω–∏–µ/Sources/sqlitebrowser/src/main.cpp:13
(gdb) 
```

It seems to me that we cannot delete multiple records at once if we rely on table model of Qt. 
Should we bypass the `inline bool QAbstractItemModel::removeRow` method call?
  ### Details for the issue

I find it interesting to find out that mac's build of the latest app lacks fts4 support. I use the same app on windows and it has fts4.

So I'm opening this ticket as a feature request.

I also want to refer to already closed ticket https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/issues/762 which is not clear if the feature is already added or not.
#### I'm opening this issue because:
- [ ] DB4S is crashing
- [ ] DB4S has a bug
- [x] DB4S needs a feature
- [ ] DB4S has another problem
#### I'm using DB4S on:
- [ ] Windows: ( _version:_ ___ )
- [ ] Linux: ( _distro:_ ___ )
- [x] Mac OS: ( _version: 10.12.1 )
- [ ] Other: ___
#### I'm using DB4S version:
- [x] 3.9.1
- [ ] 3.9.0
- [ ] Other: ___
#### I have also:
- [ ] Tried out the nightly version: https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser#windows
- [x] Searched for an existing similar issue: https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/issues?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=is%3Aissue%20
 I don't mind supporting FTS5 as it seems to be a more mature version of previous efforts. It seems though like FTS3/4 and FTS5 can coexist.

xerial's JDBC driver at least have both.

Here's the make file https://github.com/xerial/sqlite-jdbc/blob/master/Makefile

Hope it helps.
 -DSQLITE_ENABLE_FTS3
-DSQLITE_ENABLE_FTS3_PARENTHESIS

Enables both FTS3 and FTS4

see https://www.sqlite.org/fts3.html section "2. Compiling and Enabling FTS3 and FTS4"
 I'd be glad to.
 Done.
