  It seems like it has to do with these lines https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/blob/60e4cb758ed58db3a8d01cb13e82d79cf2d3ef33/src/ExportDataDialog.cpp#L92 and https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/blob/60e4cb758ed58db3a8d01cb13e82d79cf2d3ef33/src/ExportDataDialog.cpp#L113-L116, that is, it quotes the contents of a field only if there are characters to be escaped. For example, if you have the following data:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6525383/19951659/a2dced20-a170-11e6-83f8-acd018e4c9e3.png)
you can export like this:

``` csv
id,flag
a,"E""E"
b,D D
c,C C
d,B B
e,A A
```

 So maybe we should introduce something like `chars_to_quote` alongside with `special_chars`?
  ### SqliteBrowser support for **_extensions:_** "intrinsic (JSON1)" and "externals", and _compiler-toolchain options_: "Windows/`clang`"

_The following is a effectively a direct re-post of the e-mail I sent yesterday to Justin Clift, which I am posting here at his most kind e-mail suggestion._

Hi Justin,

Apologies for directly pinging you, I can't find any other means to inquire on a "posting-board" of some kind.

**SqliteBrowser** is a great project and a valuable community asset.

**QUESTION-1**: I was looking to see whether the _intrinsic_ **JSON1** _extension_ could be turned on _by-default_ in the nightly builds _(at least the **Windows** version)_ of **SqliteBrowser**?

_Side-note on non-intrinsic **Sqlite** extensions_: Given that **SqliteBrowser** is a great and openly available tool specifically for **Sqlite**, it makes sense to me that it also would be a hosting location for obtaining **Sqlite _extension libraries_** that are binary-compatible with its various platform versions. _Which, leads me to the more detailed second question..._

_First, some contextual background_: I do development work on **afm-scm** (afm-scm.org) _[which is a compatible variant of **fossil-scm**]_ and its integrated **TSL** language-engine and its hosting **AOS** object-system-engine. The **T**ext-**S**cripting-**L**anguage (ts-lang.org) is, for the most part, a superset of TCL blended with JavaScript, Smalltalk, Lisp/Scheme and intrinsically supports and integrates **Sqlite**.

**QUESTION-2**: Would it make sense to enable seamless `make` of **SqliteBrowser** _(on any platform, but especially **Windows**)_ using `clang` as a supported _(possibly-default)_ choice for a fully cross-platform compiler build tool for **SqliteBrowser**?

If one wants cross-platform source build compatibility at the C/C++ language and toolchain level there are few natively compatible options; and only one _(_`clang`_)_ that is also _gnu-compatible_.  As it stand now, building **SqliteBrowser** for **_Windows_** is a _non-trivial distraction_ since it requires variations of the _gnu-based_ toolchain to build quasi-compatible **_Windows_** binaries _(or an apparently complex setup of components to build via **VisualStudio** or_ `cmake` _or_ `nmake` _etc)_.

Not having some solution to these questions, in practice, _cripples_ **SqliteBrowser** use with "optional" Sqlite features and extensions. 

The **SqliteBrowser** _default_ releases do not link to a **Sqlite** _(coff)_ library so one has to **_recompile_** the whole **SqliteBrowser** app. I.e., it doesn't reference **Sqlite** via a `shared-library` and its binary depends on the _gnu-toolchain_. Thus, things like the **_intrinsic JSON1 extension_** are "apparently-hard" to build as a **Sqlite** _discrete extension_. This is **quite** "problematic".

_Point in case_: I have various databases with **TRIGGERS** that use and depend on **JSON1** _(an invaluable extension to **Sqlite**)_. The **SqliteBrowser** is _unusable_ with those database tables that have such triggers.

I don't have any _obvious solution_ other than to take the time and effort to create an _alternative_ to **SqliteBrowser** built-on the **_afm/fossil_** toolset. 

But, my real hope and desire is that the **SqliteBrowser** team might be open to a path to enable _intrinsic_ **Sqlite** _extensions_ such as **JSON1** to become accessible via **SqliteBrowser** either by it being built to reference **Sqlite** via a `shared-library`, or making various _intrinsic extensions_, such as **JSON1**, enabled _by-default_ in the **SqliteBrowser** app builds. 

This would be further aided in its simplicity and flexibility with cross-platform support for `clang` as a standardly supported build-chain tool. I assert this would eliminate _(most, if not all)_ special case platform issues for **Windows**.

A bit of other _background_ on `clang` availability: The current **Windows** `clang-tools` are available _freely_, and _natively_ integrated and supported within **Visual Studio** from **Microsoft**; as well as being _freely_  available from the `primary clang team` for use as `standalone` **Windows** based _gnu-compatible_ compiler tools. 

It might _(and probably would)_ be easier to configure the **Window's** builds to use either the _free_ `native` **Window's** **Visual Studio** `clang` tools or the _freely_ downloaded **Windows** `standalone` command-line `clang-tools` from the _official_ `clang` website. 

**SqliteBrowser** supporting a standard model of `clang` based build configuration would allow building on almost every platform with the same _gnu-compatible_ compiler. _This is what I use for building my code on all processors (Arm, Intel, ...) and platforms (BSD, Linux, Windows, OSX, ...); and worthy of mention, is that this also enables the **option** to build **for-all** platforms simultaneously on  single machine - although that is a bit more work :-) to set up._

Thanks for listening,

David Simmons
#### I'm opening this issue because:
- [X] DB4S needs a feature
- [X] DB4S has another problem
 I spent some 4 hours on this and the CMAKE file is difficult in terms of 
the dependency list and what needs to be configured. I am pretty sure 
that doing this right is many days of work to revise the build process, 
easier to start from scratch.

During the 4 hours or so I spent, it required polluting a dev-box with 
superfluous tools and libraries and language runtimes.

I.e., The build steps are fragile. QT is a beast. I ran out of time with 
ANTLR and QT issues and configuring CMAKE_PREFIX_PATH, ...

It has hard-coded paths, version information ...

The CMake file assumed explicit versions of many of its dependencies on 
binaries and particular libraries. QT is onerous for many reasons 
including the managerial aspects introduced by their marketing approach 
to make money.

It assumes various tools and libraries are installed that are not called 
out in the material listed on:

https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/wiki/Setting-up-a-Win64-development-environment-for-DB4S

I found the CMake code process complicated with dependencies.

I understand it is portable-UI (around the scintilla-core editor) over 
the portable and easy to build SqLite engine.

For the windows components there is no-need for the redist files, just 
link them into the binary. The libs could be linked in or provided as 
so/dll's and on windows use delay-loaded dlls.

# Could it not be built as: (cmd line for 32/6 bit build)

a) SqLite lib reference (binary download - or discrete C-compiler build)
b) Translation tool for localization of code (perhaps directly invoking 
Linguist tool if that is best option)
c) OpenSSL lib reference (binary download - or discrete C/C++ build) 

## [why is SSL required?]

d) Qt lib reference (binary download - or discrete build)
e) Drag-install with self-installation/uninstallation in Main to avoid 
need for NSIS

The ANTLR reference does not make clear if it is using Java, Python, C#, 
etc; or how it is expecting to access ANTLR.

If ANTLR2 is not available, it is unclear what the code will need or 
will try to do...

# I assume it is just a build:
1. Compile SqLite or use a existing LIB or SO/DLL
2. Compile OpenSSL or use a existing LIB or SO/DLL [which of the 
   components needs this, is unclear]
3. Provide a portable UI using some framework, support locales for 
   globalization
   3.1 QT Chosen, locale support provided by Linguist
   3.1.2 QT compilation (if not using pre-built binaries) requires 
   Scintilla compilation
4. Package the resulting binary/resources into an installer (better if 
   bundled straight into coff-binary)
   4.1 Let app be it's own installer [it does not need to register 
   anything complicated with any of its host-platforms]

I think it might be easier to build and enrich as a Chromium/Electron 
app, or just see if the Linux cross-platform build steps are somehow 
simpler.

-- David Awesome!  fix translations
 Sure, I'm glad to help.
  translate and fix
 Thanks for your screenshots. Looks like I missed a few lines. I'll try later.

  ### Details for the issue

Axis? Axes?

Well, my point is, it would be awesome to be able to change the limits of the axis window.
Right now it uses the current max/min for X and Ys, which is a little bit inconvenient. (Remember I can¬¥t plot lines? So dots get cut in half)

Also, by adding that we would have a "zooming" tool. (I think this feature seems very easy to implement, whereas a true zooming thing seems much more complicated)

e.g. When I plot this:
![axis limits](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/18152095/19496875/9286c574-9557-11e6-91d5-f976cbbf0a4e.png)

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/18152095/19496919/d4c1d4ce-9557-11e6-94f9-daa53691ca0a.png)

Or in this occasion:
![axis limits 2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/18152095/19496994/198e81ec-9558-11e6-8f09-a8c88f223261.png)

Lev Ok. Just a note. Should the cmake/qmake system take care about dependencies? So it shall detect Qt5.7, and refuse to configure the code if it is older. I tried on Debian testing, with recent Qt and compiler. qmake doesn't
complained about my obvious missing dependency:

In file included from sqlitedb.cpp:2:0:

     #include <sqlite3.h>

After installing the required packages, it installed fine. I suggest using
cmake as the code configuration tool.

Levente One of the major user case of cmake is to detect installed packages. .configure (autotool) did the same thing, but it isn't portable (eg. it is a PITA on Windows). I personally use cmake it to detect SQLite. Here is what I do.

[CMakeLists.txt](https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/files/991259/CMakeLists.txt)

I use the same CMakeLists.txt on Linux and FreeBSD, so this is cross platform. I was lazy, and I just detect presence of libsqlite3, but with a small tweak, you can even detect, and require specific major/minor/patch version too.

I'm sorry if this is not the right place to suggest things. And I think we can close this issue, since the original problem is solved now. Thanks.  ...and if you could include  package dependencies for a generic Linux system to use QT5, that would be nice too. It now insists on using QT4. This is just a wish.

Thanks,
Lev
 Okay. I was too fast typing that wish. I read the documentation again, and there is a package list there. After installing those, it does build fine using QT5. I'm so sorry about the former message.
 An documentation update would be very much welcome. I tried to build sqlitebrowser with sqlcipher support longer that I liked using [building.md](https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/blob/master/BUILDING.md) on a (K)ubuntu 16.04.1. I could not build the master no matter what I used (cmake, make, qmake -> _/usr/include/x86_64-linux-gnu/qt5/QtCore/qhash.h:103:5: error: no matching function for call to ‚ÄòqHash(const QVector<QSharedPointer<sqlb::Field> >&)‚Äô_)._ The only combination that worked was to use the v3.9.1 Tag, install _qt4-default_ and use _qmake CONFIG+=sqlcipher ._ and then _make_.
Once built sqlitebrowser works flawlessly! Thx for this awesome tool.

 Guys, cmake is broken at the moment.

After struggling an hour to get 3.9.1 build with cmake, I found this issue, and switched to qmake.
FWIW, my builds are public: https://build.opensuse.org/package/show/home:frispete:PyQt5/sqlitebrowser

The problem with cmake starts with the first line of CMakeLists.txt:
`project("DB Browser for SQLite")`

Urgh, blanks in projects name. We all know, that build systems are troublemakers, but this is just a way to **beg** for it... ;)

Next hurdle is missing `C++11` support, that is needed by newer Qt versions.
Fixed this by adding:
`set(CMAKE_CXX_FLAGS "-std=c++11" CACHE STRING "compile flags" FORCE)`
to CMakeLists.txt.

Next, it generated gems like this in `CMakeFiles/DB Browser for SQLite.dir/build.make`:
```
# Object files for target DB Browser for SQLite
DB Browser for SQLite_OBJECTS = \
"CMakeFiles/DB Browser for SQLite.dir/src/AboutDialog.cpp.o" \
```
Note the macro name. Guess, what make says to such expressions... <spit>
Fixed it with a sed script.

After that, I realized, that you creates files, based on this name:
```
if(UNIX AND NOT APPLE)
        install(FILES src/icons/${PROJECT_NAME}.png
                DESTINATION share/icons/hicolor/256x256/apps/)

        install(FILES distri/${PROJECT_NAME}.desktop
                DESTINATION share/applications/)

        install(FILES distri/${PROJECT_NAME}.desktop.appdata.xml
                DESTINATION share/appdata/)
```

At this point, I went to qmake, which got it to build at least, and *thankfully* kept the old, but sane name. 

I still have a few things, that I don't like: the build system should allow to use the platform qscintilla lib. I tried that with qmake, but failed, since openSUSE uses -lqscintilla2-qt5 to distinguish it from qt4 builds, and qmake just removes -qt5. Oh well..

It's up and running, but... I think it is not cmake what is broken. It is sqlitebrowser that miss uses
cmake. Correct?

 @justinclift Well, to be honest, I'm glad to have it running "nearly" current. The rename of the binary and all is a real PITA for packagers like me. So even with cmake fixed, I'm inclined to keep the qmake build, because I'm lazy, and sqlitebrowser would be the very first app, that contain spaces in the name (we only have a few thousand other binaries @openSUSE...). Be assured, that this will lead to headaches for about every Linux packager of your package out there. 

It's not a question of "if it breaks", it's a question of where. 

@leventelist: I don't think, that cmake is a beautiful piece of software, but as noted before, the project name alone is a receipt for trouble. You can call your program as you like, but I would refrain from using any spaces in it, at least not in those parts, that face a file system. @justinclift I see, the CMakeLists.txt looks better now. Let's make a deal, you provide some way of using the system qscintilla, and I test, help to fix the fallout, and push the result to openSUSE official.. 

Hmm the qscintilla version is tweaked, but that is flagged as needed from MacOS only, hence it should be fine. Deal? @justinclift BTW, the separate Qt packages are available here: http://download.qt.io/official_releases/qt/5.7/5.7.1/submodules/ Good news for [openSUSE:](https://build.opensuse.org/request/show/451660)

   ### Details for the issue

Since version 3.9.0 it came to my attention that tables are sorted during save of the database. In version 3.9.0 it was only sorted when you did a refresh of the table, but since version 3.9.1 it always sort the table prior it is saved.

This is very annoying, because I have a config table in the database, which contains configuration parameters for my application which should be saved in the order it was written in the table. Now the table is sorted when saved, I can not read the table anymore, because al configuration items are out of order and my application behaves bad.

Please tell me that this sort option can be switched off somewhere, because I use tables which should not be sorted, but stay in the order the were written.
### Useful extra information

 Hello,
What I use is:
Select \* from adapter;
If rs <> nil then
Do until rs.eof
¬† cgf=cfg+1
¬† Config(cfg)=rs.field("ConfData").stringvalue
¬† rs.MoveNext
Loop
End if
The config array will be used to configure the application.
These entries in the db should stay unchanged as I wrote them in the db, but the last 2 versions of sqlitebrowser sort them ascending before writing the changes.
That is my problem. 
With kind regards,
Rob
 chrisjlocke, I am sure it is not only the view. If I restart the application after I saved the db changes, the application goes nuts. When I pause th eapplication and check its config, all the values are in the wrong places. This was not the case with the version prior 3.9.0. With 3.9.0 I really also thought that it was only the view, because I saw that refreshing the records sorted the records in the table, but as far as I know it did not save that sorted order. Now with 3.9.1 I am faced with a changed table. Before upgrading to 3.9.1 I never saw my application going nuts.

I dont want an order in this table, I know how to order the table ascending or descending on a certain field, but I want this table unsorted in the order that I wrote the records into the table. Unchanged.
That is the way I do read the table when I start the application, in the order I did write th erecords in the table.
 Justin, I dont want my table sorted. I only want it in the way I did write the records to the table. These are only 14 records and it is read in the way it was saved when setup was used of my application.
 hmmm...ok, then I will use an index from 1 to 14 to keep the table in the order I want it to be.

No, just one field. I use it this way to have just 1 database containing all the files I need and not all kind of seperate files on disk. With only one field I can make changes in the setup of my application without a need to adjust the database fields. If I change something one day and have a config item more, I delete the contents of the table and write 15 records to that table. When something else goes out, I delete the contents of the table again and write 14 records in the table. You see my point, I do not need to add or delete fields in the table. This is by the way the only table I use this way, all other tables are used as you would expect a database is used and do not give any problem. :-)
 Ok, that is what I thought already.
Fyi, Justin, sqlitebrowser is a great application, I use it during development of my application to check if the info is stored in the tables as I want it and also ti flip bits to see how my application responds on the change.

   @justinclift: I can see that you just found the two links I was going to send you. So, as you may have seen, the latest version of QScintilla that contains the GPL exception is version 2.8.4, which was released in September 2014 (!!). The author of QScintilla has been considering switching to LGPL+commercial for more than a year now, but still hasn't made up his mind.

For my project, we can't afford going back to 2.8.4, so we discussed it internally and we have decided to switch to GPLv3 (see issue opencor/opencor#1301). > @agarny Thoughts? Does the latest qscintilla release solve the problem properly? üòÑ

FWIW, QScintilla 2.8.10 does indeed solve the problem.  ### Details for the issue

 @revolter It kind of makes sense that somewhere in the code there is a line that says, order the rows by X.
Because if not, given the definition of a relational query, the order doesn't matter, so it could be that the results would appear like this:
![wrong](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/18152095/19350645/9a3e31b0-9126-11e6-923d-78c6308c47ec.png)
Instead of like this:
![right](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/18152095/19350673/b1283998-9126-11e6-974d-42d0aa17e94e.png)

It's the exact same plot, but the order of the rows is switched.
  ### Details for the issue

I usualy plot x vs y, but what happens when you only want to plot y? Let me put my example:

In this image, I want to see, visually, how the variable "Total Volume" is distributed, Using only what is available:
![series](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/18152095/19331568/690a583a-90b3-11e6-826d-14bdd1ba67ac.PNG)

![series2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/18152095/19331716/ea788626-90b3-11e6-9347-dc7f80b4f0fe.PNG)

Which would be solved if this was added:
![result](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/18152095/19331799/affaf0be-90b4-11e6-939d-dcf81f2fa581.png)

 Hey @MKleusberg !
I have to say that I found other issues with that nighlty build. For example that between queries that had as an output the same columns, it did not remember the ones that were being plotted.
Before I had column1 as X and column2 as Y and after running a new query the graph got updated. With the nightly I had to select the columns to be plotted again.
Also I remember (it's been a month without playing with it), a significant decrease in performance when selecting the columns to plot. I don't know if that was a consequence of the feature I wished it had, or by some other addition..

And those where PV loops. Pressure-Volume loops of the left ventricle of a simulation of a human heart!
90% of what I was plotting were Pressure vs Time or Pressure vs Volume of all different heart chambers; the most iconic being the left ventricle.

Best regards and merry xmas!  ### Details for the issue

In the latest version (3.9.1) for Mac, the font on the SQL Editor is very small and I can't see a way to change it.

I have a very large monitor, but it isn't a HiDPI display. On the built-in retina display, the font is more readable, but still tiny.

    // editor/fontsize or log/fontsize?
    if((group == "editor" || group == "log") && name == "fontsize")

        return 12;

        return 9;

  Not sure if I understand how this should work to correctly follow Mac-OS conventions.. I get the following behaviour from 3.9.1v2 on my Macbook Pro.

 cmd backspace = deletes a word (i.e. anithing surrounded by whitespace)
 alt backspace = deletes the whole line

 but here is a bit of special behaviour:
if you first do cmd backspace (i.e. deleting words), the alt backspace changes behaviour to undoing the cmd backspace until all changes have been undone - then it deletes the full line.

I believe all of this is built in to the QT framework. My suggestion is to close this issue.
/gunnar

<!--

Thanks for coming here to report an issue. :)

Please describe it in this section, fill out the correct check boxes
below with an "x", then click the "Submit new issue" button at the bottom

-->

Make table view's column widths persistent for each database so that when the database is closed and re-opened, the browser view displays table columns in the same width as they were before closing, instead of the default column widths.
### Useful extra information

<!-- The info below often helps, please fill it out if you're able to. :) -->

Maybe the widths can be stored in ~/sqlitebrowser.conf as part of recentFileList or additional entries for each recent file, containing the file name, table name, and a series of column widths. Only those with the column widths that have increased or decreased from default should be saved. There is no need to keep track of all databases, just the ones in the recent list.

  ### Details for the issue

There are two related issues:
1) the name was changed to ‚ÄúDB Browser for SQLite‚Äù (in 2014, I think) but the spaces (with cmake version 3.6.1) cause a ‚Äúmissing separator‚Äù problem when make is run.
2) After a local correction to 1), later. 
sudo make install 
failed because src/icons/DB_Browser_for_SQLite.png, distri/DB_Browser_for_SQLite.desktop and distri/DB_Browser_for_SQLite. .appdata.xml don't exist.
### Useful extra information

For me, the solution for 1) was to simply vi into CMakeLists.txt and 
1,$s/DB Browser for QLite/DB_Browser_for_SQLite/g

For 2) there is a sqlitebrowser.\* for each of them ‚Äì so I replaced them, after which the make install worked.
#### I'm opening this issue because:
- [X] DB4S won't build per its instructions.
#### I'm using DB4S on:
- [X] Linux: ( _distro: Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server release 7.2 (Maipo) )
#### I'm using DB4S version:

  Here is the solution:
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/33728905/qt-creator-project-error-xcode-not-set-up-properly-you-may-need-to-confirm-t
 @justinclift 
I followed the steps then Qt Creator can create & compile GUI project on OSX 10.11.6 and Qt5.7.0.

> = Xcode 8

In Xcode 8, as Bruce said, this happens when Qt tries to find xcrun when it should be looking for xcodebuild.

Step 1:

Open the file:

Qt_install_folder/5.7/clang_64/mkspecs/features/mac/default_pre.prf
Step 2:

Replace:

isEmpty($$list($$system("/usr/bin/xcrun -find xcrun 2>/dev/null"))))
With:

isEmpty($$list($$system("/usr/bin/xcrun -find xcodebuild 2>/dev/null")))
 @justinclift That steps only makes Qt5.7.0 works with XCode8 on helloworld like applications, QScintilla still cannot compile. I got errors like:

```
/Users/joshua/programs/Qt5.7.0/5.7/clang_64/lib/QtCore.framework/Headers/qbasicatomic.h:61:4: error: 
      "Qt requires C++11 support"
#  error "Qt requires C++11 support"
   ^
/Users/joshua/programs/Qt5.7.0/5.7/clang_64/lib/QtCore.framework/Headers/qbasicatomic.h:90:13: error: 
      unknown type name 'QAtomicOps'
    typedef QAtomicOps<T> Ops;
            ^
/Users/joshua/programs/Qt5.7.0/5.7/clang_64/lib/QtCore.framework/Headers/qbasicatomic.h:90:23: error: 
      expected member name or ';' after declaration specifiers
    typedef QAtomicOps<T> Ops;

```
 @justinclift Mind giving this patch to qscintilla2 a try?
https://gist.github.com/ilovezfs/dff9d68264e513419e8830a804acb0b5
 Thanks!!!
 Yes, it got me all the way to the Octave GUI built under 10.12 with Xcode 8 and Qt 5.6.1 and 5.7.0 (with relevant Qt patches too).
 Nope, I've not poked qscintilla2 upstream yet with my patch. I'm easily confused when upstreams aren't on GitHub :smiling_imp:

The "revelation" was that all Qt5 reverse dependencies seemed fine except for qscintilla2 so it was actually a C++ issue not a Qt5 issue at all.
 It's most assuredly an Xcode 8 issue (happens on 10.11 and 10.12 with Xcode 8), but it's not a Qt5 issue other than incidentally.
 @justinclift yes that sounds like a good idea. For instance, Xcode 8 supports more of the c++11 standard.
 It would be good to verify the patch doesn't break anything that was working on <= Xcode 7 x <= 10.11, so that we know whether it has to be constrained in any way, but ultimately that's qscintilla2's burden to bear. (e.g., does the patch break Yosemite + Xcode 6 or 7, etc.)
 You're welcome :)
 @justinclift that would be awesome. There's little I like less than "reporting upstream"
 In case this helps: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/15583604/implicit-instantiation-of-undefined-template
 I think someone may keep it printed out in binders under their mattress.
 @justinclift Thank you so much :bowing_man: You're great :)
 @ilovezfs @justinclift 

This patch builds ok but cause a serious bug of QScintilla.

Make `QPointer<QsciLexer> lex;` global instead of QsciScintilla's memeber would make lexer be singleton.

If you build an Application with multi-docs, different doc need to have different lexers (for different languages/apis/calltips), not share a global one. So lexer should always be a member of QsciScintilla's.

I made some changes based on this patch and it works fine without damage QScintilla's logic.

Here's the [LINK](https://github.com/joshua-meng/Lunar/commit/751e3f015ecbefe7fcb90f02092574711b6cec3d).
 @agarny do you mind reviewing joshua-meng's patch (https://github.com/joshua-meng/Lunar/commit/751e3f015ecbefe7fcb90f02092574711b6cec3d) vs. yours?

@joshua-meng please test @agarny's patch and see if it works for you equally well.

> Not sure which approach to go with.

@justinclift if both patches work equally well

```
 24 additions and 0 deletions. 
```

vs.

```
78 additions and 67 deletions
```

...
 @ilovezfs 

Surely it works, I reviewed @agarny 's patch and found it totally same solution as mine. 

The only difference is I use std::unique_ptr to wrap the raw pointer of implementation struct.

Use `#define lex (lexerStruct->object)` is a good idea to avoid too much addtions/deletions.
 @ilovezfs, @joshua-meng said it all.
 @joshua-meng @agarny so whose patch are we recommending to upstream, assuming upstream is even remotely paying attention? :see_no_evil: 
 @joshua-meng's patch requires C++11, which might be a problem for Phil Thompson (the person behind `QScintilla`), I don't know.

Anyway, Phil should already be aware of my patch since I posted a message on his mailing list (see https://www.riverbankcomputing.com/pipermail/qscintilla/2016-October/001167.html).
 @agarny @justinclift @ilovezfs 
I found this bug basically caused by `extern "C++"`, when we remove `extern "C++"` from QsciScintilla.h, and move `QPointer<QsciLexer>` to cpp (because in QsciLexer.h, there is still `extern "C++"`, so we should move it out of .h file), it compiles ok.

Then I tried to remove all `#ifdef __APPLE__ extern "C++" { #endif` and `#ifdef __APPLE__ } #endif`  from QScintilla project (which appears in nearly all header files), compiles ok. links the output libraries to my App, works well too.

The conclusion is: This is all `extern "C++"` caused problem, it may be useful in early versions of XCode, but XCode 8 does not need that. I think QScintilla would not adopt PIMP patch to fix this bug because actually that was a magic skill of C++ to hide things to implementaion, temporary solution which just jump over the problem, not a perfect solution. I suppose QScintilla may remove `extern "C++"` later for the newest XCode.

John  ### Details for the issue

As of https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/commit/7deeb02889e170752bba2aa9ed367fcdb9912cdf, DB4S fails to delete some indexes it creates.
### Useful extra information

If one was to create an index starting or ending with trimmable characters (such as an ASCII whitespace ` `), one would create an index which the browser cannot delete by itself.

This is the type of bug you find when you make typos (such as trailing whitespaces), but I don't think such behavior is acceptable anyway.
#### I'm opening this issue because:
- [ ] DB4S is crashing
- [X] DB4S has a bug
- [ ] DB4S needs a feature
- [ ] DB4S has another problem
#### I'm using DB4S on:
- [ ] Windows
- [X] Linux: (distro: Fedora 23 4.6.6-200.fc23.x86_64)
- [ ] Mac OS
- [ ] Other: ___
#### I'm using DB4S version:

https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/commit/7deeb02889e170752bba2aa9ed367fcdb9912cdf
#### I have also:
- [ ] Tried out the nightly version: https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser#windows
- [X] Searched for an existing similar issue: https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/issues?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=is%3Aissue%20
#### How to reproduce

In the interface, create an index called "Index " on any table. Then try to delete it using the interface. It will issue

```
DROP INDEX `Index`; -- No whitespace
```

and fail.

Executing 

```
DROP INDEX `Index `; -- With the trailing whitespace
```

works as expected.
 The right mindset to find failures. Similar attempts reveal problems in several non-mature terminal utilities. These problems, however, never happen to an end user until they happen, which may take a few years, or may never happen.

  ### Details for the issue

I am attempting to design a DB using foreign keys.  It has already been discussed that there are deficiencies if a column has a FK as well as a non-null, since you cannot add a row.  I thought I might be able to work around it, and discovered (I think) another bug.  I attempted to make my FK "DEFERRABLE INITIALLY DEFERRED" (https://www.sqlite.org/foreignkeys.html#fk_deferred)

So my test schema is (create this DB using sqlite3):

```
CREATE TABLE one ( pk INTEGER PRIMARY KEY AUTOINCREMENT, name TEXT );
INSERT INTO "one" VALUES(1,'test');
CREATE TABLE two( pk INTEGER PRIMARY KEY AUTOINCREMENT, fk INTEGER NOT NULL, FOREIGN KEY( fk ) REFERENCES one(pk) DEFERRABLE INITIALLY DEFERRED );
```

After that, if you open the DB inside sqlitebrowser, turn on the foreign key pragma, click save, then enter a row in table "two" that violates the FK, not only does it not report an error, but the UI and the database get out of sync.  The UI shows the row entered, but if you quit sqlitebrowser and open the DB in sqlite3, it is clearly not there.
### Useful extra information

<!-- The info below often helps, please fill it out if you're able to. :) -->
#### I'm opening this issue because:
- [ ] DB4S is crashing
- [x] DB4S has a bug
- [ ] DB4S needs a feature
- [ ] DB4S has another problem
#### I'm using DB4S on:
- [ ] Windows
- [x] Linux: ( gentoo )
- [ ] Mac OS
- [ ] Other: ___
#### I'm using DB4S version:
- [x] 3.9.0
- [x] 3.8.0
- [ ] Other: ___
#### I have also:
- [ ] Tried out the nightly version: https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser#windows
- [ ] Searched for an existing similar issue: https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/issues?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=is%3Aissue%20
 Arrg I don't know where the text I just typed went.  OK again,

I tried to work around the fact that sqlitebrowser doesn't work when you have a foreign key with NOT NULL. 
Using sqlite3, create the following schema (note the DEFERRABLE INITIALLY DEFERRED, see https://www.sqlite.org/foreignkeys.html#fk_deferred):

CREATE TABLE one ( pk INTEGER PRIMARY KEY AUTOINCREMENT, name TEXT );
INSERT INTO "one" VALUES(1,'test');
CREATE TABLE two( pk INTEGER PRIMARY KEY AUTOINCREMENT, fk INTEGER NOT NULL, FOREIGN KEY( fk ) REFERENCES one(pk) DEFERRABLE INITIALLY DEFERRED );

Then open that DB in sqlitebrowser, enable foreign keys pragma, click save.

Now, add a row to the "two" table that violates the FK.  Sqlitebrowser lets you add it, doesn't complain, and shows it added in the UI, but if you quit and look at the DB in sqlite3, it is (correctly) not there.

If you do this without the DEFERRABLE INITIALLY DEFERRED, you just plain cannot add any data to the table (as discussed in #638).
 Thanks Justin (re the missing text), I thought that might have been the case :) oops.

I just tried master, and it is slightly workable. It seems now new rows are inserted with 1 in the FK column, instead of 0.  That works, as long as I have a 1 in the column the FK refers to, which may or may not be the case :)

If the idea suggested in other tickets to have a manual BEGIN/COMMIT process was workable, and this bug regarding DEFERRABLE FKs was fixed, then I think that would achieve a desirable result.  Users could click BEGIN, add a row, doctor it to taste even if its initial state violates the FK, then find out if it is accepted when they hit COMMIT.

I totally understand though that such a (seemingly) simple task might be very disruptive under the hood.
 IMHO that's better than silently letting the UI and the DB diverge.  If the user is using foreign keys, they should understand what "FOREIGN KEY constraint failed" implies.
 Seems to work at e76e5b3241af5e79474ae32fda393da921696d96 for the test described in the first comment wrt deferred foreign keys.  Thanks!
 Hey Martin, thanks for addressing it!  Closing.

  ### Details for the issue

Add support for Delphi FireDAC's SQLite encryption, if it's not too complicated :)
It uses aes-256 by default (and it alone will be enough), but supported ciphers are:
_aes-128, aes-192, aes-256, aes-ctr-128, aes-ctr-192, aes-ctr-256, aes-ecb-128, aes-ecb-192, aes-ecb-256_

> The encrypted database format is not compatible with other similar SQLite encryption extensions. This means that you cannot use an encrypted database, encrypted with non-FireDAC libraries. If you need to do this, then you have to decrypt a database with an original tool and encrypt it with FireDAC.
> 
> The encryption is provided through the officially supported SQLite approach - custom codec code and compilation with SQLITE_HAS_CODEC defined. All encryption routines are implemented on Delphi and embedded into the sqlite3 code.
> 
> http://docwiki.embarcadero.com/RADStudio/Seattle/en/Using_SQLite_with_FireDAC#SQLite_Encrypted_Database

Actually, encryption is based on SQLCipher as stated in [sources](https://gist.github.com/Mikanoshi/a7b92e807967b3af602ee527dfccee0e):

> // FireDAC SQLite driver encryption feature is derived from the following work:
> (*
> *\* SQLCipher
> *\* crypto.c developed by Stephen Lombardo (Zetetic LLC)
> *\* sjlombardo at zetetic dot net
> *\* http://zetetic.net
> **
> *\* Copyright (c) 2009, ZETETIC LLC
> *\* All rights reserved.

 I use static linking, because encryption is only available there)
 > Static linking -- the following client libraries are statically linked into the application:
>     Win32 - x86 sqlite3_x86.obj
>     Win64 - x64 sqlite3_x64.obj 
>    Note: SQLite database encryption is supported only for static linking.

>    Dynamic linking -- the following client libraries must be available in order to open a SQLite database:
>        Win32 - x86 SQLITE3.DLL
>        Win64 - x64 SQLITE3.DLL 

http://docwiki.embarcadero.com/RADStudio/Berlin/en/Connect_to_SQLite_database_(FireDAC)

...or make a DLL out of it, somehow :)
 You mean in C++?) No, I can only provide libs, and maybe create a DLL, but it wouldn't be any different, if the above obj can be linked already.
  ### Details for the issue

This is more a feature request/suggestion and is specific to .NET

If you define a column as 'DATETIME', the ("official") .NET DB provider objects can be configured to return actual .NET DateTime Types via SQLiteDataAdapter and SQLiteDataReader.

The "issue" is that DB Browser tends to ignore/discard "DateTime" and use INTEGER (or sometimes the last legal base type selected).  The only way is to use a CREATE TABLE statement in a SQL window.  Once the table is created, 'DateTime' shows in the column type list but **only** for those columns already defined that way.

This would likely be confusing for other platforms, so it might be useful to display 'NetDate` or similar to the user but use 'DateTime' in the CREATE statement.  Another option would be to enable it via a Preference.
### Useful extra information
#### I'm opening this issue because:
- [ ] DB4S is crashing
- [ ] DB4S has a bug
- [x] DB4S needs a feature
- [ ] DB4S has another problem
#### I'm using DB4S on:
- [x] Windows
- [ ] Linux: ( _distro:_ ___ )
- [ ] Mac OS
- [ ] Other: ___
#### I'm using DB4S version:
- [ ] 3.9.0
- [x] 3.8.0
- [ ] Other: ___
#### I have also:
- [ ] Tried out the nightly version: https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser#windows
- [ ] Searched for an existing similar issue: https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/issues?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=is%3Aissue%20
 The NET Provider is fully capable of creating/returning NET DateTime variables/DataTable columns.  **In spite of** DATETIME not being listed, it can be used in the table definition and the official NET provider will use it to do so.

It is a DB Browser issue because it wont allow/use DATETIME when creating a table.
 ![sqlitedates](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12514284/18286901/70ac8a1c-743a-11e6-82ea-7f7e20d4d538.gif)

(its a bit snappier run locally)

It relates to when defining a table.  The first part shows how even when I type in `DATETIME` it uses whatever - something from the dropdown list.  The second part shows how it acts with a table which was created in a SQL window. 

I _believe_ "DATETIME" acts like meta-data for the NET Provider.  The actual data format for dates is defined by connection string options.  The default stores an ISO8601 string.  The NET Provider sees "DATETIME" and returns DateTime objects - **only if that column is defined as DATETIME**.  

The NET provider knows to store date data  to an appropriate string which it will be able to parse **back** into a DATETIME type.  

The official DB Provider only does this for columns defined as DateTime **and** data which matches the DateTimeFormat setting in the connection string. Add this '...;DateTimeFormat=Ticks;...' to the connection string and the Provider will automatically save the ticks value for DateTime vars (thus saving the data integer/Int64).  Ticks also convert back to DateTime types (variables, datatable columns etc) provided the column is defined as DATETIME (ticks is less useful because it cannot distinguish UTC from local).

About Type Affinity

From that page: "_The type affinity of a column is the **recommended** type for data stored in that column.  The important idea here is that the type is recommended, not required. Any column can still store any type of data._"   Without check constraints anything goes.  In the case of DATETIME, as I said, I think the Provider is doing all the magic based on the column info and the connection string option.  

As I said in the original posting, this is probably something that only .NET devs would want/need (no one seems to know that it works). Other platforms may well choke on it, so it might be something that is enabled as an option.

I have a working demo and decent explanation, but I cannot find a recent, applicable StackOverflow post to attach it to.

Hope this helps
 I think using something from the list is generally a good idea, since the list is complete except for this one (?) case.   There might be other types allowed - who knows,  I cant find this latent ability documented anywhere.  

Since other platforms might choke on it, is the reason I suggested an option.  When _Enable NET DateTime_ is on, add DateTime and Date to the list (I am not sure it actually treats Date differently).

[Obsolete]
Here is a reason this could be very valuable:  if you execute a CREATE TABLE statement from your NET app, Type Affinity apparently kicks in and also changes **DATETIME** to **TEXT**.  That means for NET devs they **need some sort of tool** like this to create tables that support DATETIME types.  The Execute SQL tab works perfectly.

It is also probably why so few know the capability exists.
[/Obsolete]

  ### Details for the issue

<!--

Thanks for coming here to report an issue. :)

Please describe it in this section, fill out the correct check boxes
below with an "x", then click the "Submit new issue" button at the bottom

-->

Hoping to get a nice new feature/capability.  Routinely when I am working on writing complex SQL queries, I use the 'Execute SQL' tab to refine them as I like being able to type and hit ctrl-enter to see the results.  Even better, doing so with a specific selection only executes that code making it a joy to use.

However, many times I have to routinely go back to the 'Browse Data' tab to check on some things, and every time I do, not only do I hate being switched away from my code (making a lot of tabbing back and forth) but on every return to the 'Browse Data' tab, it's reset and I have to go looking for what I was after all over again.

Now one solution would be to somehow persist the state of the Browse Data tabs, but from other bugs here, I see the coding pattern has been a dump-and-reload model, making that a non-trivial task.  BUT... if we could somehow float the SQL windows (and their results) into new windows, we could look at the data side-by-side with the SQL code.  Actually, being able to float multiple windows would be the best so I can look at several result sets all at once.

For instance, this would come in handy when I'm trying to see the results of a temp table and the results of a join on that temp table.  I'd like to select out the results, leave them on screen for reference, then execute other code against it.

As an alternate to floating windows, and for that matter, preferable to them, I'd actually love to see a truly tabbed interface, similar to how VS Code handles its tabs.  You can open groups of tabs, then split them horizontally or vertically as you see fit. If you could then save these as workspaces, perhaps with your open SQL statements in a metadata file alongside the open database, that would be epic!!

But heck... I'd even settle for simple side-by-side tiling of what's already there.  Point being, being able to see both your code, its results, and the Browse Data feature all at the same time is IMHO a sorely-needed feature.
### Useful extra information

<!-- The info below often helps, please fill it out if you're able to. :) -->
#### I'm opening this issue because:
- [ ] DB4S is crashing
- [ ] DB4S has a bug
- [X] DB4S needs a feature
- [ ] DB4S has another problem
#### I'm using DB4S on:
- [X] Windows
- [ ] Linux: ( _distro:_ ___ )
- [X] Mac OS
- [ ] Other: ___
#### I'm using DB4S version:
- [X] 3.9.0
- [ ] 3.8.0
- [ ] Other: ___
#### I have also:
- [ ] Tried out the nightly version: https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser#windows
- [ ] Searched for an existing similar issue: https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/issues?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=is%3Aissue%20
 @chrisjlocke, that's not really a feasible option as when you change the structure in one side, you can't tell the other to easily refresh.  That and two different instances would be two different transaction scopes too (i.e. where you have to commit or revert your changes with the buttons on the toolbar.)  In a perfect world, it would work like Visual Studio (or VS Code) where you can create tabs and do whatever you want in each... browse the schema, run SQL, whatever.  You could split them, stack them, group them... you decide.  Honestly, if it had that feature alone, I'd gladly pay $50+ for it just thinking of how productive it would make me.
 Sounds like an excellent plan to get started.  One-each of the main windows is fine for now. That would solve my personal problem/desire to browse the data while editing SQL in another window.  
 Here's another thought... to keep things simple, pre-load the 'tabs' with the four main areas you have now.  Let us close them, move them, etc.  Then, have a 'New Tab' button that when you click it asks you do you want a new schema view, browse view, SQL view, etc.  A simple drop-down prompt under the button would work.  Point being if you design it so each 'tab' is its own thing, but which can post notifications that other tabs could listen to (i.e. for schema changes, etc.) then you'd have both a very easy interface for newcomers, and a powerful interface for pros.

This could also simplify what's already there.  For instance, currently in the SQL tab, it allows 'sub-tabs' if you will to open additional SQL windows.  That entire thing can be removed since if you want another SQL window, just open a new SQL tab.  Cleans up the interface even more.

Anyway, just ruminating on the designs.  I'd be happy to mock them up in Sketch/Photoshop to better show what I'm thinking if it would help.

### Useful extra information

<!-- The info below often helps, please fill it out if you're able to. :) -->
#### I'm opening this issue because:
- [ ] DB4S is crashing
- [X] DB4S has a bug

  Hi Justin! This was the same issue I described to you earlier.  As mentioned, while in QT4 you can see all the data, the paging controls are wonky there too (i.e. I don't know of _any_ version where they work correctly.)
 [OddPagingInDbBrowser.mov.zip](https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/files/446295/OddPagingInDbBrowser.mov.zip)
Movie attached.  You can see that while only eight rows are shown (sizing changes this amount), it's still paging by up to 100 places, meaning if you want to see anything between 9 and 90, you can't use the paging controls.  Paging size should match the shown number of rows, always.
 Yes, different than the QT5 issue of not seeing all the rows, which I did see as well. This issue exists in both QT4 and QT5 versions.
 Just jumping in here with zero experience with this code, but reading the thread so far, could it be an issue of an internal window's frame not being properly constrained by the outer 'viewport' window (and by 'window' I mean control, whatever).  I've seen cases where people have tried implementing their own scrolling mechanism and the math has gotten mixed up between what you're seeing, what you're supposed to see, and what was actually going on behind the scenes, but was obscured visually.

Again, just a complete guess, but based on something similar I'd seen in the past, so again, check the actual bounds of the various windows/frames.
 So is the fact that the other bug was closed also saying this one is now too?  If so, when are the next binaries going to be made available?
 No, no rush. Just wondering! :)

  ### Details for the issue

DB4S has a default font that it is using for the "Browse Data" tab. You can see it in the next image.

![db4s_1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8761081/18008694/6887ef3c-6ba9-11e6-87dc-b8876c7d2cff.jpg)

However, if you open the "Preference" window to change anything, or simply opened it and closed it without changing anything, it will change the default font and make it look like this..

![db4s_2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8761081/18008733/a15a8298-6ba9-11e6-91c7-92a5bbc72a9d.jpg)

This only happens if you click OK, whether you changed settings or not, but not if you click Cancel.

In both cases, there is no font selected in the "Preference" window. It is empty like this..

![db4s_3](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8761081/18008945/71a00748-6baa-11e6-8ba2-c8531b220222.jpg)

To go back to the font I want in the first image, I have to edit the registry and delete `font` value from `HKCU\Software\sqlitebrowser\sqlitebrowser\databrowser` key, then restart DB4S.

What is the default font that is used in the first image? I think this will be fixed if I set it manually.

 @justinclift Windows 10 Anniversary Update, 64-bit

  Could be considered an installation bug, especially for 'regular' user.
Windows 7 Ultimate SP 1
DB Browser for SQLite 3.9.0, 64-bit

There is no "uninstall" entry in Windows 7 "Programs and Features" Control Panel item. (There was one for v. 3.8.0.)

Workaround is to directly use the "Uninstall.exe" program in the installation folder (the one above the "bin" folder where the program's executable file is located).

![screenshot - 24-08-16 14_47_19](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/454810/17943541/d693f0d0-6a09-11e6-9cfe-8c1aea86270c.png)
 Yep!  The program now shows up in the Uninstall list as expected.

Minor glitch when _uninstalling_ the program : It doesn't check if program is currently in use.  The uninstall goes through without any errors, but leaves the program executable and DLLs in place.
 That's totally fine.  :-)

I found this, which seems to do both the checking and the aborting : http://nsis.sourceforge.net/Check_whether_your_application_is_running

Not sure if it's any help in your case though, I have no idea how NSIS works.
  Not sure if this is related, but when modifying an existing table, adding a primary key to it, even after confirming that the data should support a primary key on the selected fields (i.e. no nulls and when running a group-by with a count on the fields, I never get anything but a '1') it just silently fails and doesn't add the key.  But System.Data.SQLite is not a part of Microsoft.. that come from SQLite DLLs
 Yeah, that is what i mean :)
 I mean.. whit this dll you can set a password to database, but you can only open it again whit the same dll.. not but other SQLite browser.. and.. in internet exists only 1 browser that can open encrypted database with this dlls, but is a very only software (2009), now is pretty bugged.
If i try to open a encrypted database with your browser, i get an error. Becase this dll encrypt files using RSA (not RS, like i write in the first post, was a keyboard error)
Hope you understand what i mean :)
 No, the enrcryption use a personal security system, that is already writed in the System.Data.SQLite.
For set a password you can simply add this dll to a project and use a command:
Connection.SetPassword("MyPass");

I have read something online, and im sure that use not SEE (external plugin) but RSA (internal function).
 That will be awesome, but i dont know C++ language, so... i can't give you a big help.
Anyway.. i think (and is just my opinion).. i think that you will have good benefit if you add the ability to open database that are encrypted with System.Data.SQLite. Because there are many users that use this dll with .Net Framework, by programming in VB.Net; C#, F, etc.. and many of them will use this internal protection to encrypt thier database. I mean.. why use an external dll or plugin if you can protect your database with the same dll that you use for read/write it?

Example:
I made a "Database.db" with System.Data.SQLite.dll and i use it in my app, then i use also your browser for open my databse and watch what contains. But is i set a password to this database, i cannot open it anymore (with your browser).
I (and other users like me) must CREATE a new app that will use only for watch the content of the encrypted database.

Remember that just one browser can open database encrypted with System.Data.SQLite.dll (SQLite2009 Pro) but is not good as your browser :)

With this more function you will have more users.
 My idea was to use the integrated protection, not another external dll. :)
Anyway.. i dont know what i must ask on this forum, so.. i think i will pass :)
  ### Details for the issue

<!--

Thanks for coming here to report an issue. :)

Please describe it in this section, fill out the correct check boxes
below with an "x", then click the "Submit new issue" button at the bottom

-->

When running SQLiteBrowser (now renamed to DB Browser for SQLite) on macOS Sierra beta, because the app is unsigned, it can not find its preferences file and as such, the colors in the data browser tab are all black, meaning black text on black background.  Even if you change them, while they will work for that session, closing and reopening the app resets all of your settings.

My suspicion is this has to do with the new way macOS Sierra handles unsigned applications.  It stores them in a 'random, secure' portion on disk, not simply the application folder even though it _looks_ like that's where it is.  This is part of their new security.  My guess is this is the cause of the app not being able to find the preferences.

That said, even if the preference file isn't found, the defaults should not be black on black.  At least set them to black on white, possibly making nulls gray on white.

All of the above is also pure speculation and I could be completely wrong, but I am not seeing this behavior on earlier versions of OS X, including El Capitan, only macOS Sierra.

 Yeah, just came out today I think.  I'm installing it on my machine too if you want another tester.
 The DMG worked fine for me. As for the app, it worked after I disabled the security prompt.

Even so, there was another issue... if you say 'run it this time' from sys prefs security, it doesn't actually open but instead prompts you again. You have to completely disable the security, run the app, then reenable.

My guess is you're using a boot strap mech which would cause that as the boot strapped part runs, but then the main app gets blocked.  But that's purely a guess.

Again, disabling it temporarily solves the issue.

One thing though, signing, sierra and the rest aside, you should still change the defaults to black on white instead of black on black when prefs aren't found.  At least it's a temporary work-around rather than making a user have to change it every start as I do now.  Of course this goes away with signing, but still... it's a good practice regardless.

 Ha! Found the cause of the issue!

Using your above references to the prefs, I nuked them, and as I had hoped, the colors appeared as normal even after closing, then reopening the app.

However, as soon as I went and changed from the default colors to match my liking (for reference, I set nulls to 'Moss' and binary to 'Lavender', both under 'Crayons'), while they displayed correctly for that session, closing and opening the app went back to the black-on-black colors I was seeing.  Deleting the prefs again got things back to normal.  Setting the colors broke it again, etc.

Trying to determine if it was a 'color prefs' thing or a 'prefs in general' thing, this time I nuked the prefs file, confirmed the colors were at their defaults, then opened up 'Preferences' and toggled 'Remove Line Breaks in Schema View' (i.e. a pref _not_ related to color). I closed and restarted and sure enough, the colors went wonky again back to black-on-black.  Ironically, the 'Remove breaks' setting _did_ stick.

So... that's how to get to see what I was seeing.  Apparently the prefs for the colors are either being written, or read incorrectly even though the other prefs seem to be persisting and being read just fine.

Hope this helps!  More importantly, I hope it's a quick fix so I can finally use my custom preferences with your app. :)

  ### Details for the issue

Reproduction (it should be reproducible w/o Python, but that's what I exactly did):
1. In Python (2.7, 32-bit):

```
import sqlite3 as db
dbcon = db.connect("base.db")
dbcur = dbcon.cursor()
dbcur.execute("DROP TABLE IF EXISTS people")
dbcur.execute("""
    CREATE TABLE `people` (
        `id` INTEGER NOT NULL PRIMARY KEY AUTOINCREMENT UNIQUE,
        `name` TEXT NOT NULL,
        `member` INTEGER DEFAULT 0
    )""")
dbcur.execute("""
    INSERT INTO people VALUES (NULL, 'John Appleseed', 0)
""")
dbcon.commit()
```

\2. Open `base.db` in SQLiteBrowser
\3. Switch to "Browse Data" tab
\4. In Python:

```
...
dbcur.execute("""
    CREATE TABLE `people` (
        `id` INTEGER NOT NULL PRIMARY KEY AUTOINCREMENT UNIQUE,
        `name` TEXT NOT NULL,
        `rank` INTEGER,
        `member` INTEGER DEFAULT 0
    )""")
dbcur.execute("""
    INSERT INTO people VALUES (NULL, 'John Appleseed', 100, 0)
""")
...
```

\5. Hit refresh button in "Browse Data"

Result: Table "people" has 3 attributes, and John's membership flag is "100"
Expected: Table "people" has 4 attributes, and John's rank is "100"

  ### Details for the issue

as topic says. My procedure:
- opening the database
- fireing an sql-statement updating the table
- browsing the table
- leaving the database without saving

Unfortunately DB4S is changing the writedate of the db file, despite saying "don't save".

I could understand if it is changing the accessdate, and leaving creationdate and writedate untouched.

  ### Details for the issue

Database file that start with "." (hidden by default on OSX) are not selectable by the file picker when you click "Open Database". The following screenshot shows the open dialogue side-by-side with the same window in the finder. You see there are several hidden files that don't appear in the sqlitebrowser window.
<img width="1277" alt="screen shot 2016-08-07 at 6 34 03 pm" src="https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1728139/17467020/3b53a3ec-5cce-11e6-9ee6-070edcdca304.png">

Version 3.8.0
Qt Version 4.8.7
SQLite Version 3.9.2
### Useful extra information

The workaround is to rename the file, but this is a hassle and gets even more inconvenient when dealing with frameworks that expect the file to have a specific name.

    Hello,

 @justinclift Cool, knowing how much Apple loves breaking things I just assumed üî•

Yes that makes sense!
 Link for reference: https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/wiki/Notes-for-setting-up-your-build-environment-on-OSX
  The filter input row isn't mirrored in RTL locales.
That is because Qt draws from left to right, and the painting wasn't recognizing RTL locales.
This fix does change the position of the inputs to be drawn from right to left (Using `width() - ..`).

According to Qt documentation:

> The position is measured in pixels from the first visible item's top-left corner to the top-left corner of the item with logicalIndex.

For that the size of the column is added to the postion so that it's measured from the top-right corner to the top-right corner.

Fixes #631

   > If we remove the & signs from all of our strings

Accelerators are triggered by `Alt+E` not `Ctrl+E`. They are different than shortcuts :)
Shortcuts are like `Ctrl+C` `Ctrl+V`..
 What you need is `QKeySequenceEdit`. That will make it easier to check weather the shortcut is used or not (Signals/Slots..). You can get it from designer and see how it works :)
  It would be great to be able to run SQL that uses functions from the [JSON extension](https://www.sqlite.org/json1.html).

 Absolutely! Their (sqlite) extension docs seemed pretty sparse and I wasn't sure where to start. Thanks @justinclift @revolter 
 The JSON1 functions (https://www.sqlite.org/json1.html) will be available in this nightly build?
 @justinclift Looks good so far:

```
SELECT json_object('ex','[52,3.14159]'),
  json_array(1,2,'3',4),
  json_array_length('[1,2,3,4]'),
  json_extract('{"a":2,"c":[4,5,{"f":7}]}', '$'),
  json_insert('{"a":2,"c":4}', '$.a', 99),
  json_replace('{"a":2,"c":4}', '$.a', 99),
  json_object('a',2,'c',json_object('e',5)),
  json_remove('[0,1,2,3,4]','$[2]'),
  json_type('{"a":[2,3.5,true,false,null,"x"]}'),
  json_valid('{"x":35}')
```

outputs

`␀{"ex":"[52,3.14159]"}␀,␀[1,2,"3",4]␀,4,␀{"a":2,"c":[4,5,{"f":7}]}␀,␀{"a":2,"c":4}␀,␀{"a":99,"c":4}␀,␀{"a":2,"c":{"e":5}}␀,␀[0,1,3,4]␀,object,1`

Thanks, hopefully flipping on support for other platforms isn't too hard!
 Appreciate it @justinclift - people will probably want a JSON browser too, heh... One step at a time :wink:
 Is any plans to release with the JSON1 enabled by default?
(json1 is a core extension - sqlite should be recompiled with the json1 extension enabled.) It's very easy to to add JSON1 support to sqlitebrowser. Only "-DSQLITE_ENABLE_JSON1=1" is required when building sqlite.  @justinclift, apologies for not replying back. Thanks for fixing the issue. :)
  Qt expects a RTL text, so it sets the text direction to RTL.
An easy fix is to add a "LRM" character to the end of the string, it acts as an English letter and would move the bracket to the right :)
Or forcing the combobox direction not to mirror by using `setLayoutDirection`.

 @revolter, I think I just solved it. I disabled simPholder's use of simPhuse, and now it seems to be working fine.

simPholders finds your simulator images and exposes them in a menu bar window. simPhuse provides yet another convenient way to access them, via a mounted filesystem. In either cases, you can select based on device, version, running app name, etc. instead of an obscure udid.

I rarely actually use the simPhuse mounted filesystem, though.

It's strange it worked until today. 
 I can confirm same issue with the nightly. And once I turned off simPhuse, then no problem with refresh.

So, I have my workaround. But you still have your odd behavior, when using it with an odd filesystem. ;)

Perhaps, though, this will give you a clue as to related issues.

  When opening the "Browse Data" tab the first time, then selecting a table from the drop down, it automatically shows the data for the table in ascending order by '_rowid_'.

I can tell by watching the SQL log window, it shows these SQL statements:
SELECT COUNT(_) FROM (SELECT `_rowid_`,_ FROM `ConfigInfo` ORDER BY `_rowid_` ASC);
SELECT `_rowid_`,\* FROM `ConfigInfo` ORDER BY `_rowid_` ASC LIMIT 0, 50000;

If I then click on the "Execute SQL" tab, then click back to the "Browse Data" tab, it shows the data for the table in descending order by '_rowid_'

The SQL log window now shows these five new statements:

SELECT type,name,sql,tbl_name FROM sqlite_master UNION SELECT type,name,sql,tbl_name FROM sqlite_temp_master;
SELECT COUNT(_) FROM (SELECT `_rowid_`,_ FROM `ConfigInfo` ORDER BY `_rowid_` ASC);
SELECT `_rowid_`,\* FROM `ConfigInfo` ORDER BY `_rowid_` ASC LIMIT 0, 50000;
SELECT COUNT(_) FROM (SELECT `_rowid_`,_ FROM `ConfigInfo` ORDER BY `_rowid_` DESC);
SELECT `_rowid_`,\* FROM `ConfigInfo` ORDER BY `_rowid_` DESC LIMIT 0, 50000;

You can see the last one was ordering 'DESC'.

I believe it should not be changing the order like this, and just use 'ASC' order.
 It was with version 3.8.0, 64 bit version for Windows.  Sorry I haven't tried any nightly build.
 Hi I just tried these two nightly versions.

The Win64 version from http://nightlies.sqlitebrowser.org/win64-onceoffs/  still has this issue occur.
The Win32 version from http://sqlitebrowser.oldsch00l.com/sqlitebrowser.exe.zip seems to work fine.

Again I can see it changing the order by to DESC in the SQL log window.

SELECT type,name,sql,tbl_name FROM sqlite_master UNION SELECT type,name,sql,tbl_name FROM sqlite_temp_master;
SELECT COUNT(_) FROM (SELECT `_rowid_`,_ FROM `BinaryFile` ORDER BY `_rowid_` ASC);
SELECT `_rowid_`,\* FROM `BinaryFile` ORDER BY `_rowid_` ASC LIMIT 0, 50000;
SELECT COUNT(_) FROM (SELECT `_rowid_`,_ FROM `BinaryFile` ORDER BY `_rowid_` DESC);
SELECT `_rowid_`,\* FROM `BinaryFile` ORDER BY `_rowid_` DESC LIMIT 0, 50000;

The Win32 version just does not execute these last two SQL statements, but the Win64 version does.
  That's because of: https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/blob/b773e77a0c17317c9096728876e2b3c0f29be559/src/MainWindow.cpp#L2487
which leads to deleting all the current fillter inputs: https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/blob/master/src/FilterTableHeader.cpp#L30

Data should be saved somewhere and then called when repainting..

 Hi

I'm so sorry, I have been terribly busy in the last couple of weeks and I had an operation two weeks ago and have been recovering since then.

I did find out however that the reason I got the segfaults was not my RAM or debian buildchain. Some time ago I installed linuxbrew because I wanted to test something. linuxbrew compiled a glibc, gcc and other packages on its own and put them at the front of PATH. I haven't realized that until I was compiling something for one client of ours and I constantly got segfaults. That's when I executed gcc --version and I got a segfault as well. Then I realized that I was executing the gcc from linuxbrew the whole time.

Since then I haven't had the time to experiment with that. But I haven't forgotten it :)

 I don't know Qt or c++ very well (I'm a Delphi Pascal guy) but I took a quick look around the source code and I imagine something like this would work:

On show (or initialization) of edit dialog
restoreGeometry(PreferencesDialog::getSettingsValue("EditDialog", "geometry").toByteArray());
restoreState(PreferencesDialog::getSettingsValue("EditDialog", "windowState").toByteArray());

On close of edit dialog
PreferencesDialog::setSettingsValue("EditDialog", "geometry", saveGeometry());
PreferencesDialog::setSettingsValue("EditDialog", "windowState", saveState());

This is taken from "MainWindow.cpp" and I just altered a part of the lines to say "EditDialog" instead. I'm not sure the setting for "windowState" is necessary to save and restore though. Can someone more knowledgable please say that it might work or that I'm totally wrong. :-)
I'm willing to try a nightly build with this (or correction of this) code to help testing.
 Thanks @justinclift I'll take a look at the guide and see if I can set up a working build environment during the weekend.
 I've been experimenting a little.
Altering the event below works for me on Windows to keep the dialog opening centered over the main window. But I have no idea about other platforms, multiple monitor setups and other possible special cases.

``` cpp
void EditDialog::showEvent(QShowEvent*)
{
    // Whenever the dialog is shown, position it at the center of the parent dialog
    QMainWindow* parentDialog = qobject_cast<QMainWindow*>(parent());
    if(parentDialog)
    {
        move(parentDialog->x() + parentDialog->width() / 2 - width() / 2,
            parentDialog->y() + parentDialog->height() / 2 - height() / 2);
    }
}
```
 This works great for me on Linux. the edit cell box stays centered each time on all cells.
 I've had the opportunity to try my Windows build on a computer with two monitors, and I'm happy to say it works great there too. :smile: 

For information, the current official build has problems there which can cause the dialog to appear on wrong monitor,
 A pull request has been made. :smile: 
 You're welcome @justinclift.
Tackling other things.... sure, do you have more dialogs that needs to be centered? :wink: But seriously, do you have anything particular in mind? I'm still new to Visual Studio, C++, Qt, yeah basically everything in your brilliant Windows Build Guide. :smile: 
 @justinclift  If I can find the piece of code that performs the launch I should be able to fix the security issue. Right now I don't know where to start looking, so any hints are welcome. :smile:

  Hi,

I need export my SQLite database to sql file with MySQL compatibility, hence I want to use always backtick (`) for CREATE TABLE syntax. For example:

```
CREATE TABLE `Table1` (`ID` INTEGER,`Name` TEXT);
```

however, in the exported sql, the create statement contains backtick (`) as well as double quote (") and single quote (') , which seems to be a random behavior.

for example I have a table with schema:

```
CREATE TABLE `Source` (`Source_ID` INTEGER, `Name_Source` TEXT);
```

if I export this table, it become to: 

```
CREATE TABLE "Source" (`Source_ID`  INTEGER, `Name_Source` TEXT)
```

or

```
CREATE TABLE 'Source' ('Source_ID' INTEGER, 'Name_Source' TEXT);
```

And it's also unpredictable in the CREATE INDEX statements:
in this case I want no quote around the columns like:

```
CREATE INDEX Source_Source_ID ON Source (Source_ID);
```

but the exported sql is:  

```
CREATE INDEX 'Source_Source_ID' ON 'Source' ('Source_ID' );
```

So when I import the sql to MYSQL database, I got syntax errors
 @justinclift it would be great to have user defined quote character for export
 @MKleusberg it would be great if you can implement this feature(tables and indices are enough for me), however I am not able to test the nightly build this week, I will check later ASAP, thank you. @justinclift @MKleusberg thanks, it's now working! I guess it's a non-issue then other than it's not obvious to the user why this is happening.

1. one could have `test.db` and `test.sqlite3` files, encrypted differently
2. you, instinctively inserted the name with the file extension too, so there's a chance that that will other users do

I send them without any modification to the [`setSettingsValue`](https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/blob/master/src/PreferencesDialog.cpp#L183) method, which uses `QSettings`. (_I have spotted that odd "DEFAULT ASC" part on my side._)
 Yea, that `DEFAULT ASC` was the trigger of the problems on this side (_an edit error from me that slipped by_). After changing it to a more appropriate and intended `DEFAULT 0`. sqlitebrowser (_the nightly and the last final version_) went back to behaving as expected/normal.

You can't use it (the attach keyword) in the SQL window, as that uses transactions and you can't use ATTACH in a transaction.

  This is a suggestion for an optional feature to make the whole experience somewhat better.

If the user turns this global option on, any database specific configuration could be saved inside the database itself in a specially named table (e.g., _sqlitebrowser_config_ or whatever -- maybe ever user defined table name).

What do I mean by database specific?

For example, I always resize the column widths in the browser because the default usually truncates data in a way that I can't be sure what the field contains.

These new column sizes could be saved inside the database itself (in that special congifuration table).

When opening a database, sqlitebrowser could check for the existence of that table, and if the needed settings are there, use them, else revert to the default ones.

This configuration table could be used for all sorts of current or future database specific options, not only column sizes.  For example, it could even save the contents of the 'Execute SQL' tab to be remembered across sessions.

What do you think?
 I wasn't aware of that!  I'll give it a try, and report back if I have problems with it.  Thanks.

However, why does the project file have to be a separate file?  (For example, backing up databases now one has to remember to take along all those extra files.)

One of the great things about SQLite3 is that all you need in relation to the database is contained in the same single file.
 Regarding the way this works now, an immediate issue I see is that the related project is not automatically loaded upon loading the database.  I would expect if I load xxx.db that xxx.sqbpro (or xxx.db.sqbpro) would also be loaded to save typing / operator steps.

Even if I tell it to load xxx.db.sqlbpro it works as far as loading the database, but again the settings are not automatically applied.  (Unless, it actually ignores the .sqlbpro final part, and simply loads xxx.db)

A second issue, when I try to save the project, it defaults to the name of the database itself including the extension.  So, one has to manually edit the filename.  I don't like my filenames to have double extensions (e.g., xxx.db.sqbpro).

It's even simpler on MSVC, it comes out-of-box.

> don't want to rush this.

IMO, there's really no need to rush this, but lots of boilerplate code could be optimized. What about Qt4 - it  just stinks as 11 year old stuff. It's just outdated, lots of stuff had been fixed and added/removed over this time. Upstream developers do it for a reason.

My suggestion is to start working on Qt5 in another branch, and continue distributing current(Qt4) version until Qt5 version is polished and perfect. More than that,  Qt5.7 is upcoming soon, in that version Qt devs introduce full vice versa C++11 support. More info [here](https://blog.qt.io/blog/2016/04/21/qt-5-7-beta-released/)

```
dyld: Symbol not found: __cg_jpeg_resync_to_restart
  Referenced from: /System/Library/Frameworks/ImageIO.framework/Versions/A/ImageIO
  Expected in: /usr/local/lib/libJPEG.dylib
 in /System/Library/Frameworks/ImageIO.framework/Versions/A/ImageIO
The program has unexpectedly finished.
```

Does [this](https://github.com/Homebrew/legacy-homebrew/issues/34302) help you to help me solve the problem? :D I don't understand much.
 Well, I didn't remove anything else on purpose. But it seems I do have that file:

```
lrwxr-xr-x    1 revolt  admin    35B Mar 26 17:26 libjpeg.dylib@ -> ../Cellar/jpeg/8d/lib/libjpeg.dylib
```
 I found this possible solution:

> `sudo ln -sf /System/Library/Frameworks/ApplicationServices.framework/Versions/A/Frameworks/ImageIO.framework/Versions/A/Resources/libJPEG.dylib /opt/local/lib/libjpeg.dylib`
> 
> Why does this work? Because for whatever reason, when Apple requests libJPEG.dyld, whatever system searches for it finds /opt/local/lib/libjpeg.dyld because the search is case insensitive. For a Unix operating system. Go figure. The lines above will force any program looking for libjpeg.dyld to be redirected to Apple's libJPEG.dyld.
> 
> But wait, what if you WANT Macport's libjpeg.dyld? Sorry, not possible unless you statically link your program to libjpeg.a. And since I've never done that before, I can't help you if you want to do that :(

Do you think it's ok?
 I managed to get it (finally) working by actually running all the command from [here](https://lists.macosforge.org/pipermail/macports-users/2010-November/022663.html), not only the jpeg one, but replaced `/opt/local/lib/lib*.dylib` with `/usr/local/lib/lib*.dylib`

CREATE TABLE "words" (
    `groupid`   INTEGER NOT NULL DEFAULT 1,
    `word`  TEXT NOT NULL,

    PRIMARY KEY(groupid,word),
    FOREIGN KEY(`groupid`) REFERENCES `groups`(`groupid`) ON DELETE CASCADE
);

    `name`  TEXT NOT NULL,
    `description`   TEXT,
    `enabled`   INTEGER NOT NULL DEFAULT 1,
    `canedit`   INTEGER NOT NULL DEFAULT 1,
    PRIMARY KEY(groupid)
);
COMMIT;`

  I'm using Windows OS and Qt 5.4.1 (but also happens in Qt 4.8.7 ... laptop here has 5.4.1 but work PC which has a newer build of SB has an older Qt...)
When modifying a table, there are checkboxes for primary key, not null, etc.  If these are double-clicked, text can be entered into the cell.
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7872218/15438228/09ab1a62-1ec3-11e6-98de-8685ce4c5b3c.png)

Obviously its only a cosmetic issue as the text is ignored, and I presume you don't want to bloat the code with 'cleanup' code on the off-chance some muppet will enter text, but didn't know if the table cell allowed editing, but disabled text entering for particular columns.
 Yes, the 'a', 'b', 'c' and 'd' can be entered by double clicking in the cell where the checkbox is.  Interestingly, when editing an existing table, because its a change in the row, the usual 'modify table' SQL process is run (but obviously ignored).
In the 'real world', I can't see anyone double-clicking in the cells, and if they did, they wouldn't enter text...
I presume its because the cell is empty and can contain checkboxes, rather than being solely a checkbox.  Again, on my Windows version, the column can be resized out, but cannot be resized back down to the original size ... as if it 'should' contain text...
 No-one would do it + and it has no bearing on the program + and entirely cosmetic = waste of time!
