  Summary about this patch:
1. One can duplicate record via:
   - context popup menu over the record in table 
   - shortcut Ctrl-" 
2. The very first _copied_ value in new row is focused. Primary keys are ignored.
3. Copied alues aren't written to db instantly until "Write changes"

In #577 there was suggestion to provide "duplicate field". I find this feature ambiguous tho, _especially_ for user. So much depends on which row is currently selected, which row should be copied where and so on. I guess, in this case one should really just Ctrl-C Ctrl-V. 
So, since original feature request was about duplicating _records_, this closes #577 . We can discuss better design for ditto field separately.
 @justinclift all right, I am looking forward to it.
 @MKleusberg I am not sure what view you are speaking about. 
 @innermous, I think that he's referring to [this](https://www.sqlite.org/lang_createview.html).
 Patch updated.
Frankly, I wanna say 2 things about code. Firstly, it's sad not having C++11 support. Lots of boilerplate code could be avoided with use of lambdas to connect signals and slots. More than that, check [docs](http://doc.qt.io/qt-5/signalsandslots.html), you are using outdated slot interface (I guess it's only for Qt4 support, which has dinged 7 years already IIRC).
 @justinclift everything is done as others requested. Why not closing issue?
 @justinclift okay, I guess we'll make browser even better together :ghost: 
 Cheers.
  Hi,

I really like the feature where you can export various tables in a database to a csv file as it's a quick way to get data out; however, exporting on a linux machine, the file is actually ASCII text, with CRLF line terminators.

That means the export inserts ^M at the end of the line:

```
trip_id,date,dayOfWeek,pickup_time,duration,distance,total,beginning_zip,ending_zip^M$
3b5a4966-f6ce-45e5-a659-448715344dbf,2016-04-18,monday,18:42,1036.8,3.17,6.7,89119,89109^M$
0915dd1f-86cc-440a-ae72-0f12ae0aaef1,2016-04-18,monday,19:05,816.0,3.35,6.31,89109,89109^M$
```

On anything other than windows, these ^M are annoying and difficult to deal with. Fortunately they're easily removed with a sed string. 

Can sqlitebrowser be updated to export to a strictly ASCII file?

You can observe the new line characters (^M) on linux with `cat -e file.csv`
 > @jungle-boogie Would you be ok to compile the latest master code, and verify the fix on Linux?

Wow, that was a super fast commit!

I built it successfully on my linux machine and I'll test it when I'm at home.

```

 Thank you so much for your answers.

I have cloned and built yesterday's git master, because previously I had tried to use very old Ubuntu's version built from [launchpad.net](https://launchpad.net/~linuxgndu/+archive/ubuntu/sqlitebrowser) Seems, that it was the version 3.8.0. Result was similar for any versions - sqlitebrowser freezes.

Today morning I have built sqlitebrowser up to commit 484206b60c5f57ea8259031af67b3c0f28944e5 Fri May 6 01:23:15 2016 +0200

Unfortunately it did not fix my problem - sqlitebrowser still freezes immediately when "Browse Data" tab pressed.
 Now I know what had happened. Sqlitebrowser does not freeze. Every time when I clicked on "Browse Data" tab It had been waiting when following SQL request would finish execution:
SELECT COUNT(*_) FROM (SELECT `_rowid_`,_ FROM `EURJPY` ORDER BY `_rowid_` ASC);

Perhaps you have reasons to make this request so strange.

Of course it is not solve the issue, but I have made some experiments to get duration of similar requests to that big DB:

$ sqlite3 ./DATA.db 
SQLite version 3.8.2 2013-12-06 14:53:30
sqlite> .timer ON
SELECT COUNT(_) FROM (SELECT `_rowid_`,_ FROM `EURJPY` ORDER BY `_rowid_` ASC);
296000329
Run Time: real 340.013 user 136.504500 sys 18.499167

sqlite> SELECT COUNT(`_rowid_`) FROM `DATA`;
296000329
Run Time: real 267.229 user 51.368474 sys 13.184472

sqlite> SELECT COUNT(*) FROM `DATA`;
296000329
Run Time: real 298.312 user 6.519477 sys 17.093569

sqlite> SELECT COUNT(ROWID) FROM `DATA`;
296000329
Run Time: real 262.883 user 52.967703 sys 14.101523
sqlite>

  A 'ditto' function!  I second!  And don't forget keyboard fans (CTRL-" or something, like in some spreadsheets).

Actually, it'd be nice to have two 'ditto' functions.  One to copy just the cell above, and one to copy the whole row.  (OK, maybe the whole row can be done with the mouse only as one can repeat the keyboard way for each cell of interest.)
 @tonypdmtr are you sure Ctrl-" is common shortcut for that?
I picked up the task btw.
 Yes, Excel uses it, for one (see official link below).  The actual combination is CTRL together with a single quote (no SHIFT is needed to get the double quote) but it's referred to as CTRL-" (double-quote).  This is supposedly easy to remember as it resembles the '' (two short vertical bars) used for a 'ditto' notation.  Have a look here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ditto_mark and here: https://support.office.com/en-us/article/Excel-shortcut-and-function-keys-1798d9d5-842a-42b8-9c99-9b7213f0040f (look down the page for the CTRL-'  single quote, and its description).  Actually, for Excel it works with both single and double-quote but in one case it copies the value and the other the formula.
 @tonypdmtr 
Thanks for explanation of Ctrl-", that was the thing I never knew.
What about UNIQUE fields? 
I am thinking about UX design of that feature. Should button be greyed out in those cases?
@justinclift how do you think, maybe this should be positioned near "Add record" and "Delete record" instead?
 The unique fields issue is irrelevant in the sense that the ditto operation simply copies the cell (or row) above to this one.  This is either an allowed thing or not.

What I mean is the operation is no different from someone trying to actually type in the respective field values.  This will be either allowed, or not.  How it displays an error is no different in either case.

Regarding the UI issue: (I'm a keyboard person so the CTRL-' covers me).  My idea about it, however, would be to have a right click on the row/field you want to copy and a popup window to give two options: 'Copy Row' and 'Copy Field'.  No special buttons.  What do you think?  This is actually more powerful than the keyboard shortcut in that you can 'ditto' any row/field, not just the one above.
 Just to add a couple more details of how I envision this:
1. CTRL-' (single quote) can be for cell/field copy, and CTRL-" (double quote) for row copy.  Easy to remember: One quote does less than two quotes.
2. Once the 'ditto' operation is complete, the cursor could automatically move to:

(a) the cell/field to the right, when a single cell/field is copied.  (If on last column, go to first column -- i.e., wrap around.)  This will allow repeated CTRL-' to very quickly copy multiple fields, even when not the whole row is needed.

-- or --

(b) the first cell/field, when a whole row is copied, to allow possible edits.

What do you think?
 @tonypdmtr you can ditto field one time. After that it's ambiguous where to ditto another field, cuz new row is already created.
IMO only ditto row matters.
 Ambiguous?  Ditto always works in relation to the field above.  So, wherever the cursor is, that's where (the column) you get your value from.

IMO, if you have to keep only one, then only ditto single field matters.  Because, it will never be the case that a new row is needed that has the exact same information for each and every column.  On the other hand, it's quite common to have the same values repeated for one or more columns in different rows.
 @tonypdmtr ow...
I thought this option should duplicate current row in the end of table... Now I see I imagined everything wrong, sorry.
I wish everyone could have same seeing of the problem  :confounded:
 @innermous You thought right except that it doesn't necessarily have to be the whole row.  If you also take into account the current column (where the cursor is, or mouse click happens), it's the same thing.  You just use both grid coordinates, not just the row, from where to get the source data.

Copying the whole row is convenient when someone wants to keep all but one or a few fields the same (happens less often).

Copying a single field is convenient when one wants to clone one or few fields only (happens more often).

Once the copy is done, the user will most certainly need to work on the fields that need to be different, so it'd be nice to stay on that new row and be allowed to continue editing as usual.
 @tonypdmtr u don't understand what mean. Everything you say is right. But real thing is, what happens when we have K rows and we ditto row N? There are 3 possible outcomes:
1. Some data from N (column or whole row whaaatever it doesn't matter now) is copied to K + 1
2. Data from N copies to N + 1 (following item)
3. Data from previous item (N - 1) dittos to N.
You see how ambiguous the whole thing is? We must consider which one of these we need, then we can proceed further to details and implementation.
 Let's make it simple then.

You press 'New Record' in browser, and a new row appears ready to accept your data.
You position the cursor to some cell in that new row.
You do DITTO function.
The contents of the immediately above row for the same column is copied into the current cell as if typed in by hand.
Then, ideally, the cursor on the current (new record) row, moves to the next column.

This covers the keyboard way, at least.

Now, with the mouse you can be more creative.
Wherever you right-click the mouse, you copy the data from that row instead of the last one to the corresponding column in the new record.

Did I answer your question?
 @tonypdmtr well, at least I see whole picture now.
 I too got lost in this discussion. My initial feature request and actual use case scenario was to duplicate any table row, and, of course, every column value, except, unique fields.

 @tonypdmtr, I may have got it wrong, sorry. Not a native english‚Äã speaker.‚Äã
 So ditto field always dittos current field into the very last record (created with "New record"), right? So it can be called for several fields.
 @justinclift was speaking about Ctrl-' (ditto single field). Everything is clear with ditto row.
 I have ditto row working, not sure implementation is good though.
Working on ditto field.
UPD: In my opinion, duplicate row should create new record with same data, rather than changing it for already created one with 'Add record'.
@tonypdmtr what you think about that? See the bright side of it:you can duplicate row several times with just pressing Ctrl-" several times, no 'Add record' step is needed anymore. I believe this use case appears much more often than that you described.
 @innermous I agree about the CTRL-" ('ditto' for row) that it appears to be simpler when done directly (i.e., without having to do Add Record first).

As for copying the same row several times by repeated CTRL-" presses, I would think that in most cases, it would be practically impossible.  A correctly designed database would not expect the exact same row to be repeated without any changes in (at least) one field.  So, some editing (automatic or manual) has to happen for each new record before going to the next one.  If the change is automatic (like an auto-increment field) then that's not an issue.  But I would think this to be the exception rather than the rule for most tables, which IMO would require manual changes.
 @tonypdmtr i'd stick to @revolter picture, cuz I understand this use case in the same way.
 @MKleusberg Sure thing :D

  Updating from version 3.7.0 32-bit to 3.8.0 64-bit does not update the file handler registry in: 
HKEY_CURRENT_USER/Software/Classes/Applications/sqlitebrowser.exe/shell/open/command

The path after update was still 'C:/Program Files (x86)/..' and should be 'C:/Program Files/..'

This breaks the "Open with" dialog such that it ignores your choice.
 It's exactly the same issue :)
 It should be taken care of during install-time.

  I added column titles '_id' and 'data' to the end of the first row of a csv file (no data in any row) hoping to make the '_id' column the primary key after importing the file.

The 'PK' status does not stick when modifying the table, unless I fill the column with numbers first.

Adding the column manually works fine (and the column is filled with numbers - perfect).
 When modifying the table and the PK status doesn't stick, is the database reporting any error?  I presume the SQL log would show the commands sent and the errors (if any) returned?
 There are no errors shown in the log page.

However I think I have found the cause.

The file was created by saving from Excel so while there may be no data in the cells there are trailing commas on each row giving an 'empty' cell not a 'NULL' one. 

If I remove these commas the 'PK' status sticks and the column gets filled as expected.

Any chance of a "Add 'Primary Key' column" option in the csv import box?

Should I add a make separate request for this?

```
CMake Error: The following variables are used in this project, but they are set to NOTFOUND.
Please set them or make sure they are set and tested correctly in the CMake files:
LIBSQLITE
    linked by target "sqlitebrowser" in directory /home/maxim/software/sqlitebrowser-3.8.0

  This patch allows to view result data from the _Execute SQL_ tab in the EditDialog.

This patch is lightweight and already useful to me - and hopefully other people

Ideally, I'd like to be able to edit the data too, but I couldn't get it to work, because when the user enters freeform SQL, it is nontrivial to determine what the underlying table is (see http://www.sqlite.org/sessions/lang_select.html).
 Ah. I think there is a double-click action missing, so I have to admit it is nonobvious:

To see what I am trying to accomplish:
- open a database
- enable _View -> Edit Cell_
- Go to _Execute SQL_ and enter a select statement suitable for your db.
- In the result table view, click on an item and watch the Edit Cell update the data.

I use this for a db that has lots of JSON blobs that I need to inspect.

  Awesome. 
   According to [SQLite documentation](https://www.sqlite.org/syntax/table-constraint.html), a foreign key constraint could include multiple columns separated by  a ','.

If I execute:

```
CREATE TABLE to_reference_multi
(
  id1 INTEGER NOT NULL,
  id2 INTEGER NOT NULL,
  CONSTRAINT Identifier1 PRIMARY KEY (id1, id2)
);

CREATE TABLE to_reference_single
(
  single_id INTEGER NOT NULL,
  CONSTRAINT Identifier1 PRIMARY KEY (single_id)
);

CREATE TABLE test_reference
(
  id1 INTEGER NOT NULL,
  id2 INTEGER NOT NULL,
  id3 INTEGER NOT NULL,
  CONSTRAINT Identifier1 PRIMARY KEY (id1, id2, id3),
  CONSTRAINT fk_multi FOREIGN KEY (id1, id2) REFERENCES to_reference_multi (id1, id2),
  CONSTRAINT fk_single FOREIGN KEY (id3) REFERENCES to_reference_single (single_id)
);
```

The resulting test_reference table ignores fk_multi and looks like:

```
CREATE TABLE `test_reference` (
    `id1`   INTEGER NOT NULL,
    `id2`   INTEGER NOT NULL,
    `id3`   INTEGER NOT NULL,
    PRIMARY KEY(id1,id2,id3),
    FOREIGN KEY(`id3`) REFERENCES `to_reference_single`(`single_id`)
);
```
 I can confirm FKs with multiple columns aren't completely ignored anymore. However, adding two FK constraints with multiple columns leads to only one mixed constraint.
I downloaded the nightly build from sqlitebrowser.oldsch00l.com and executed the same commands in the original post.
<details>
<summary>

The resulting test_reference table confirms that one constraint isn't ignored:</summary>



``` sql
CREATE TABLE `test_reference` (
    `id1`   INTEGER NOT NULL,
    `id2`   INTEGER NOT NULL,
    `id3`   INTEGER NOT NULL,
    PRIMARY KEY(`id1`,`id2`,`id3`),
    FOREIGN KEY(`id3`) REFERENCES `to_reference_single`(`single_id`),
    FOREIGN KEY(`id1`,`id2`) REFERENCES `to_reference_multi`(`id1`,`id2`)
);
```

</details>
<details>
<summary>

To test two FK constraints with multiple columns I executed:</summary>



``` sql
CREATE TABLE table1
(
  id1 INTEGER NOT NULL,
  id2 INTEGER NOT NULL,
  CONSTRAINT Identifier1 PRIMARY KEY (id1, id2)
);

CREATE TABLE table2
(
  id3 INTEGER NOT NULL,
  id4 INTEGER NOT NULL,
  CONSTRAINT Identifier1 PRIMARY KEY (id3, id4)
);

CREATE TABLE test_reference
(
  id1 INTEGER NOT NULL,
  id2 INTEGER NOT NULL,
  id3 INTEGER NOT NULL,
  id4 INTEGER NOT NULL,
  CONSTRAINT Identifier1 PRIMARY KEY (id1, id2, id3),
  CONSTRAINT fk_multi1 FOREIGN KEY (id1, id2) REFERENCES table1 (id1, id2),
  CONSTRAINT fk_multi2 FOREIGN KEY (id3, id4) REFERENCES table2 (id3, id4)
);
```

</details>
<details>
<summary>

Resulting in a test_reference table with one mixed FK constraint as follows:</summary>



``` sql
CREATE TABLE `test_reference` (
    `id1`   INTEGER NOT NULL,
    `id2`   INTEGER NOT NULL,
    `id3`   INTEGER NOT NULL,
    `id4`   INTEGER NOT NULL,
    PRIMARY KEY(`id1`,`id2`,`id3`),
    FOREIGN KEY(`id1`,`id2`) REFERENCES `table2`(`id3`,`id4`)
);
```

</details>
Of course, the rules aren't enforced unless I enable foreign keys. That's the expected behavior according to [sqlite documentation](https://www.sqlite.org/foreignkeys.html#fk_enable) but a warning message might be useful.
 Windows 10 Home 64-bit - Version 1511 - Build 10586.545
sqlitebrowser version 3.9.99 - Qt version 4.8.7 - sqlite version 3.13.0
 It works! :smile:
Output for multiple FK constraints is as expected (I also tested a single constraint and it still works fine).

``` sql
CREATE TABLE `test_reference` (
    `id1`   INTEGER NOT NULL,
    `id2`   INTEGER NOT NULL,
    `id3`   INTEGER NOT NULL,
    `id4`   INTEGER NOT NULL,
    PRIMARY KEY(`id1`,`id2`,`id3`),
    CONSTRAINT `fk_multi2` FOREIGN KEY(`id3`,`id4`) REFERENCES `table2`(`id3`,`id4`),
    CONSTRAINT `fk_multi1` FOREIGN KEY(`id1`,`id2`) REFERENCES `table1`(`id1`,`id2`)
);
```

 Hi Kumar,

I posted a similar issue yesterday, and it's been posted a few times before. I'm assuming you're using Windows 7-10?

Here are the previous threads: 
[Issue #552](https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/issues/552)
[Issue #543](https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/issues/543)
[Issue #495](https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/issues/495)

It appears this is a somewhat uncommon issue with no current fix. However, there is one current workaround using the Nightly Builds [Located here](http://rp.oldsch00l.com/sqlitebrowser/). Using the nightly build worked just fine for me and others. I hope this helps you move forward, and hopefully they are able to track to the cause of this crash soon!
  When on the "Browse Data" tab, clicking "New Record" immediately inserts a new row containing default values into the database.  This causes the validation logic to run against those defaults, even though it is reasonable for a client to want to edit the values prior to inserting them.  It would be preferable to create a new UI element upon pressing the "New Record" button, but defer the insert statement until:

1) the row is deselected by the client, or
2) enter is pressed when not editing a cell value, or
3) the client attempts to change the table being browsed

Upon any of these user-initiated actions, if validation fails, show a dialog explaining the error and re-select the offending row.  To continue, the user must either click "Delete Record" or fix the offending data.  This enhancement is hinted at from #294, #463, and #514.
 I double this and #463 , very irritating bug.
This would be so much easier if QSqlTableModel was used :cry: QEditStrategy::onRowChange could be a cure but...

  Wondering if there Is there a limit on the number of records imported? 
Querying the new imported table to count the row also returns a row count of 40001.
 How certain are you that there are 42224 records? Is it possible there are extra line breaks, blank lines, etc? Can you share your .csv file?
 ![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17833200/14290322/7ce830a4-fb56-11e5-96e8-6639da68e753.png)

I've managed to isolate the problem, and I believe it is a bug...
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/17833200/14290602/87bc8998-fb57-11e5-9ce3-be5975079fa5.png)

In one of the fields being imported called Summary, is from a system that users have typed in a summary of an issue or problem raised in system testing, , and when the numpty users type some thing like

Exception raised in 'Ease of Use" API when blah blah etc has been done.....

In this instance, the user has opened Ease of Use with a single quote ' , but has close off with a double quote " . It appears the file import isn't escaping these properly. And then eats up all the characters across multiple rows, until there is another occurrence of this unmatched quoting! - which also occurred in the data dump I was using.
I proved the issue by 1) Exporting the newly imported  table back out as sql, into a text file, and could see multiple rows rolled up in one insert. and 2), Removing all the single & double quote characters from the data that was being imported, after which the row count corrected displayed 42224 rows as shown on the browse data tab in the GUI.

Regards, AL.
Great app BTW, it has helped me implement some data analysis code in excel, using the DB Browser as a tool to get data into a db. Hope this helps.
  When copying a single cell (CTRL-C) that contains multi-line text, and then pasting it (CTRL-V) on another single cell, each line from the multi-line text fills another row of the table in the database.

This is totally wrong behavior.
 But it already works correctly when multiple (multi-line) source cells are copy-pasted,  So, why have a different behavior for the single source cell in the first place?  To me this seems counter-productive.

There could be (like it is done in spreadsheets) a 'Special Copy' menu bar (e.g., Edit/SpecialCopy) option where the copy is performed in an alternate or user-defined way.

But don't you think the default behavior should be identical for either single or multi-cell source?
 IMO behavior we can see now is quite convenient. Definitely it should be kept as default one to avoid confusion of users that are used to it.
I think the best way to handle pending change would be "Multiline text copy" switch with "line per entry" and "all to one entry" values possible.
I would put it under View -> Preferences -> Data browser menu
 Agree, it will be better. 
Are you meaning some kind of radio setting in menu bar which will change behavior until switched to other option  or actually option for one time paste?

In first case if user will set option to all-to-one, pasting of multiline text will always lead to adding of one field per paste, while in second case it will only paste one entry for multiline text if user will click, let's say, Edit -> Paste -> Buffer to one entry. 

Also, I'm confident setting name should be about pasting data, not copying. And it might be good to use Ctrl+v for entry-per-line paste and Ctrl+Shift+v for all-text-to-one (as in other programs, where Ctrl+V used for formatted input, while Ctrl+Shift+V for plain text entry)
 But what about Mac OS users? Do they have menu bar? Have asked two people and they gave me different answers 
  Lets have table like this:

    `Id`    INTEGER,
    `Name`  TEXT NOT NULL,
    `Bar`   INTEGER NOT NULL,
    `Baz`   TEXT,
    PRIMARY KEY(Id),
    UNIQUE (`Bar`, `Baz`)
);

If you edit it within the app, unique constraint is not read from the DB and after edit it is gone completely.

  My code is this

```
static void Main()
        {
            NewMethod();
            NewMethod1();
        }

        private static void NewMethod()
        {
            System.Data.SQLite.SQLiteConnection.CreateFile("test");
            SQLiteConnectionStringBuilder sb = new SQLiteConnectionStringBuilder();
            sb.DataSource = "test";
            sb.Version = 3;
            System.Data.SQLite.SQLiteConnection c = new System.Data.SQLite.SQLiteConnection(sb.ConnectionString);
            c.SetPassword( "123");
            c.Open();
            c.Close();
        }

        private static void NewMethod1()
        {
            SQLiteConnectionStringBuilder sb = new SQLiteConnectionStringBuilder();
            sb.DataSource = "test";
            sb.Password = "hjk";
            sb.Version = 3;
            System.Data.SQLite.SQLiteConnection c = new System.Data.SQLite.SQLiteConnection(sb.ConnectionString);
            c.Open();
        }
```

And i have no exception at end!
  I'm having difficulty adding a record when a check constraint is defined. I can provide a db example offline if anyone can help me?
 I just came across a concrete example for this:

```
CREATE TABLE "AAA" (
    "FIELD" TEXT,
    CONSTRAINT "AAA-FIELD-EVEN_LENGTH_CHECK"
        CHECK(LENGTH("FIELD") % 2 = 0)
)
```

The fix for issue #505 seemed to fix some of these (check constraints with logical connectives such as AND/OR before that fix also exhibited this behavior), but the constraint parser clearly has some unresolved issues. Onto the Dock icon, or onto the application icon inside a Finder window (in the first msg you mentioned the app, but I like to double check with you).

(Similarly, @justinclift, you cannot really drop a file onto an instance because an instance is not a GUI element. Did you mean to have dropped the file onto the app's open window or did you mean its Dock icon?)

Also, which version are you using? ... Oh crap, the OSX app does not even show a version in the Get Info window. That should be fixed (I guess the Qt system is responsible for missing out on that?) Anyway, my About window shows 3.8.99 for me, and there D&D works on 10.11.3 for me.

 Oh, BTW, the way the file extensions are declared in the Info.plist do not seem to be correct because the "Open With" operation on a .sqlite file does not offer the app as it should.  Still don't understand, how it could happen that dragging a file over the app's window can lead to opening a window from the Finder.

The Finder can indeed open new windows during D&D, but only if you target a folder shown by the Finder, e.g. a folder icon on the desktop or in another Finder window, and when you then hover your dragged file for 2s over it (can be turned on/off in the Finder prefs, or at least used to be so).

  Ported over from this issue: https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/issues/428#issuecomment-147124785

Not sure if this is a bug or not, but the output panel font remains unchanged despite changing the **SQL Log Font Size**:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/121520/13150645/74d88c0c-d61b-11e5-814d-d98956c1b73f.png)

Is the output pane _the_ considered the "log"? if not, then obviously it's not a bug. But would love to have the option to configure it.

The other perhaps orthogonal suggestion is that the output pane have some kind of visual cue to show that something has happened when a query executes. Even as a moderate "power" user of SQL and of DB Browser, I sometimes forget I have to look down there to see if my query had an error or if I just wrote a query that returned a nonsensical empty set (it varies depending on which monitor I'm using and how large the editor is currently stretched out to...). 

A cue that an **error** happened would be especially useful. Not for people like me, but perhaps for the Excel-to-SQLite users who are used to have Alert Boxes thrown in their faces when an error happens. But don't make it an alert box...a little red highlight around the output pane (or error text) is good enough :)
  v. 3.8.0 for Windows (64 bit)
1. Create new sqlite database.
2. When prompted to create table, hit cancel.
3. Go to File > Import > Table from CSV file...
4. Select a CSV file where the column names are in the first row.
5. Check option for "Column names in first line".
6. Click "OK".

Table will be created but the column names will still be in the first row. Columns will be named "field[n]...". 

Perhaps this is intentional but most other db GUIs I've worked with would take that first row and name the columns based on the text in that column's cell. That's the expectation I have when I select that option. If I don't select that option, I still get the column names in one of the rows but I now get a blank line above that row at row #1.
 I've followed those same exact steps and could not re-create this bug. The columns are named as expected. Is there anything else you did not mention in your test case? (Using windows 7 x64)
 I forgot to post back a follow-up. The problem wasn't with the sqlitebrowser, it is with the CSV. If the tool that generates the file has white space before your first row, probably a line break, then you get the effect mentioned. 
  I'm using 3.8 on Windows 10. When I am entering text in a cell I press the Enter key to save the cell/row. In 3.7 that simply did what I expected. It saved the changes. But in 3.8 it saves the changes then pops up the cell editor window, but the contents of the editor are the old value of the cell BEFORE my last entry change. I have to remember hit Esc or Cancel the dialog each time. This is unexpected and confusing behavior, and causes extra steps and potential data loss. I don't mind that the Enter key pops up the cell editor window, but only when I was NOT editing a field. Popping up the editor dialog should be the behavior only when I am navigating cells. And if/when it does pop up it must contain the latest version of the cell, not some previous version.
 I'm getting this too, on Windows 7. I notice it when attempting in-place editing.

 That still doesn't help getting to a specific table, though I agree it does seem to be a sensible default.
 Right, and your suggestion only specified the db file, not the table.

Maybe you meant something like
sqlitebrowser some.db --browse sometable

Then, I would suggest, the browser again to be the default, and on the command line to simply say:
sqlitebrowser some.db -t sometable

(-t for table)
 Oops, yes, you're right.  I didn't make it clear that I want to go direct to a specific table.
 I agree an option is possibly the best approach.  (Preferably a command-line one, and a short one like -t to avoid typing too much all the time that specifies directly the table to browse.)

As for the 'intelligent' behavior I don't think it will actually work in practice because (for me, at least) most databases have more than one table/view, so I would end up back in the original (current) behavior, which I don't enjoy very much.  Unless, of course, it is in addition to having an option as described above.

So, if there is a single table, yes, go to browse that one table, but if there are more tables, check if the option says which one, else (no option) go to datastucture tab.

(BTW, why does opening a big table cause a delay?  Is the whole table read in all at once instead of pages as they are displayed -- you know with the LIMIT ... OFFSET clause?)

Sqlite parse error:  "line 5:72: unexpected token: NULL"

( "CREATE TABLE \"anime\" (
    `id`    INTEGER,
    `name`  text NOT NULL,
    `type`  TEXT NOT NULL,
    `ep_watched`    integer NOT NULL DEFAULT 0 CHECK(`ep_total` is NULL or `ep_watched` <= `ep_total`),
    `ep_total`  integer DEFAULT NULL,
    `status`    TEXT NOT NULL,
    `date_started`  text DEFAULT NULL,
    `date_finished` text DEFAULT NULL,
    `animedb_id`    integer NOT NULL UNIQUE,
    `anidb_id`  INTEGER UNIQUE,
    PRIMARY KEY(id),
    FOREIGN KEY(`type`) REFERENCES anime_types ( type ) on delete restrict on update cascade,
    FOREIGN KEY(`status`) REFERENCES anime_statuses ( status ) on delete restrict on update cascade
)" )

  Hello Sqlitebrowser team!

I've been using Sqlite + SqliteBrowser to replace a very expensive only MongoDB service. It's been working great for me, but most of my work consists of 'dumping' data and retrieving it, without a lot of complex queries. Thus, I've been using @piskvorksky's SqliteDict (for python), which 'pickles' the values and stores them in the table. 

While I am not particularly connected to 'pickling', it would be really great if there were a 'decoding' of most common encodings in the fields. For example, one might dump entire ProtoBuf (google's)  objects into the database, and be able to see 'real-time' changes, as it is decoded by the viewer.

In a verry related note, would there be a possibility of creating an extension environment from other languages? I could write the extension I'm suggesting in Python, but would have a hard time in c++.

Thank you!
 Now that you mention, I might try to get my hands on trying to implement my request. The things that I learn, I'll document, it'll be useful as a foundation for other extension-makers.

I just need onee hint to get started. I'm trying to figure out the point between the query returning results, and the results being displayed, but have been unable to do so. Any idea what file/lines I should be looking at?

Somewhat related, perhaps it might be a good idea for someone more knowledgeable to add a little bit of documentation, if only in the header files, and at a file level? _That_ would definitely be a great first step towards starting a healthy extension environment.

 ËãπÊñπ-ÁÆÄ‰Ωì‰∏≠Êñá  my font
 Hello, I seem to have a fix for this issue.

It's my first time submitting code to a community project, so if this is the wrong channel, I am sorry.

I use sqlitebrowser in a course at my university, and noticed the problem.  The cause of this issue was the Scintilla Editor output being drawn to a buffer which as it seems was not being scaled correctly. (Source: http://scintilla-interest.narkive.com/Yb4Qbh9h/scintilla-gtk-on-retina-displays)

I managed to fix the issue by setting `bufferedDraw = false` in `EditView.cpp`, in the Scintilla library.  I'm unsure if modifying the bundled library is this is within this project's constraints though.  (The modification to the app.plist file does not affect rendering or buffering within Scintilla).

In my fork, I also made some other changes to the default font size, bumped from 8 to 13 in the editor, and up to 12 in the data view.  Perhaps we could add a menu item for "High DPI mode" or some such so it's not the default for people on machines that lack high dpi support?

The before/after images are at the top of this, including the unit tests, which all passed.  I do hope this can be added, as I've seen a couple of other people reporting this issue.

https://github.com/nickberry17/sqlbrowser_with_Retina_support

Before:
<img width="1328" alt="screen shot 2016-04-25 at 5 11 32 pm" src="https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/18670565/14804675/cba472fe-0ba8-11e6-8350-3954c48d7a55.png">
After:
<img width="1328" alt="screen shot 2016-04-25 at 5 11 59 pm" src="https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/18670565/14804678/d052c274-0ba8-11e6-9868-b9ab0cf3d3db.png">
Unit Tests:
<img width="542" alt="unittests" src="https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/18670565/14804684/dacde5f8-0ba8-11e6-933d-708085cf5647.png">
 That's awesome!  :smile:

I am working on the pull request, just going to try and squash my git commit history first, per the developer wiki.  For this commit, I'll just disable the `bufferedDraw`, so the rest of the settings stay the original defaults (they are more of a personal preference, and I wouldn't want to impose).

I'd be delighted to test out the nightlies for the next builds as well. :smile:

Cheers!

``` SQL
CREATE TABLE `SOME_names` (
    `id`    INTEGER NOT NULL PRIMARY KEY AUTOINCREMENT,
    `username`  TEXT UNIQUE
);
```

Then add a few records:

``` SQL
INSERT INTO SOME_names (username) VALUES
('Billybob'),
('SuzyQ'),
('Janey');
```

Now using the Add Record button for that table, try to input 'SuzyQ' again. It will throw an error detecting that SuzyQ already exists, but once you click 'OK' then try to head back to the main app. Here it crashes and burns.

 Hi @glawrence 

I would love to contribute for your community. But I don't know what to write much about, it's pretty straightforward in fact. I just hesitated to choose the build tools (qmake or cmake, gcc or MSVC...)

So my build set is : MSVC + cmake, in Microsoft Visual Studio 2013

 In general you guys all setup already all .vcproj file, config & build step. All that I have to modify is the paths to dependancies (sqlcipher, Qt for MSVC 32 bits) in CMakeLists.txt file (which for now is not generic, but point to local path of your build, I think for the future you can setup some find[Package] with CMake for those dependancies). 

The roughest part must be figuring out which sqlcipher .dll I have to link with, because I have differents builds from differents sources, but I choosed a C/C++ DLL for Windows pre-compiled that I order a trial from SQLCipher main site web.

Rather than make the package generic, I just modify it to make it work on my local build. I don't know if it's useful to improve your work?
 > Does anyone know where to set that?

You set this in cmake-gui by selecting a 64 bit generator. All 64 bit generators for Visual Studio will have Win64 at the end.

> So, I'm unsure where it's getting x86 from. ???

The default generator is 32 bit
 BTW, You can also set the generator on the command line via cmake -G "generator" 

cmake --help 

will list the options.

  To reproduce:

Type some SELECT into the SQL and execute it (BTW, CTRL-ENTER does not work for that, only F5 -- this is another issue).

The result will show up in a grid box, but going to the cells will not update the Edit Box (even though in read-only mode just like a View)
 Still does not work with the keyboard -- moving from cell to cell does not update the edit box.  It only with mouse clicks.

The CTRL-ENTER issue is OK.

(BTW, what happened to the statically built daily releases?) Well, I didn't say it should be editable.  However, the reason IMO you need the read-only edit box is because long cell contents are easier to read that way, rather than directly from the grid cell. Indeed, now ENTER is needed all the time for **both** keyboard and mouse.  (This feels awkward to me.  It's certainly worse for mouse users as they now have to use both mouse and keyboard.)

I'm not sure of the previous mouse behavior but didn't it update the edit box with each mouse click?  If so, then perhaps the mouse click event could be 'manually' called whenever the grid cell is changed by keyboard, no?  (I suppose there is some way to detect that, I don't know QT.)

Regarding multi-selection, the edit box should always show the most recently accessed grid cell contents.  Using 3.8.0, and the nightly build from 6 Jan.
When you add data via the 'browse data' table, when you press Enter to confirm data in a cell (or add new data) the 'edit database cell' window appears.  This didn't occur in 3.7.0.
If you add new data into a cell (eg, 'test') and press Enter to confirm this data, the 'edit database cell' window appears, but it is also blank.  Pressing Cancel closes the window, and the original data entered is correctly stored in the cell.
Additionally, updating the contents of a cell and pressing Enter displays the 'edit database cell' window, but this window has the original data in it.  Clicking OK on this erronous data is actually ignored - the edited data is saved.
 No, 'View' -> 'Edit Cell' has the same error, but the dialog doesn't appear.  Focus is changed though...
Now if a cell contains 'test' and I overwrite it with 'test2', and press Enter, 'test2' is saved to the cell, but 'test' appears in the window underneath.  The dialog doesn't appear though.
 Additionally, the 'Edit Cell' pane at the bottom is labelled 'Edit &cell'...

 Thank you, please merge~  :+1: 
  Windows DATE is a date formatted as double, with origin at 1/1/1900. This modification allows to display doubles interpreted as a Windows DATE, similar to the unix epoch display option.
 @MKleusberg 
The fractional part of DATE is the hour/min/sec representation.
eg.: 42372.4709375 represents 2016-01-03 11:18:09.
I propose to add both a date and a datetime format.
date ('1899-12-30', `Date` || " days" ) 
would indeed be shown as 
2016-01-03.
  Adding to readme since that's where most people will look for this information.
  If you have the edit boxed docked, and close the DB, whatever was last displayed in the Edit Box remains visible.

  I have a table 'A' with Primary Key on 'ID' column. I have some data inside, however there is no record with ID = 1.

I have a table 'B' with AID marked as Foreign Key from table 'A'.

If I try to add new record in B i get:
DB Browser for SQLite
Error adding record:
CHECK constraint failed: B (INSERT INTO `B` (AID) VALUES (1, ...);)
 I found out that the problem is not caused by foreign keys but constraints added to columns.

It seems that when adding new row, it is added with 'default' values and then edited with values given by user.

This is for version I downloaded today, so 3.8.0. The same applies for 3.7.0. I'm running windows, downloaded x64 version.

  Corrected overlooked problem suggested by @tonypdmtr on issue [#453](https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/pull/453). I make new issue because [#453](https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/pull/453) is already merged.
 @MilosSubotic 
This is a very nice feature, but I believe it can be made a bit more powerful.
1. When pasting a BLOB field, instead of getting the actual content of the blob, I simply get the string 'BLOB'.  (I don't know if this should be considered a bug or an enhancement request.)
2. An enhancement I see to this copy/paste to make it even more flexible is a one-to-many ability.
   That is, if I have a single cell copied to the clipboard, but I have multiple cells selected when pasting, I would like the single value copied to each selected cell.  (It's quite common that one wants to copy a single value to a range of cells -- like in a spreadsheet.)
3. It can be made even more powerful (many-to-many) by pasting each copied cell in sequence to all selected cells.  That way, if I have copied two cells with contents 'A' and 'B', and paste to a range of five cells, I should get 'A', 'B', 'A', 'B', 'A'.  (So, the source can be more than one cell, and the destination more than one cell, but the two numbers do not need to be equal.)  This will also take care of [2] above automatically as it is a sub-case of this one.

Thanks for your great work, and Merry Christmas to all.
 1. I don't thing this cannot be much better, because clipboard is in text format.
2. and 3. I'm not sure that have enough time to make that (I lack time a lot), but you could do it. Guys here are really nice and quite open for contribution.
   Also consider to use SQL for such advance things. Because that I choose sqlitebrowser over spreadsheets.
   Merry Christmas to you too.
  When editing the table, and adding any column does not check that the name is already in use, resulting in the loss column added when saving table and fall program attempting to move a column with duplicate names

to repeat
1. Create a table with columns (Field2, Field3, Field4)
2. open it for editing
3. add a new column, it name will duplicate (Field4)
4.1 when saving last column will be lost without warning
4.2 when trying to move the last column will happen fall program

add:
if you use non-standard column names, the name of the column will be repeating the standard
 That will not be enough
you need to add a check of repeatability column names in edit mode when you change the order of columns and save.
Not only standard column  names
 to repeat
1. Create a table with columns (a1, a2, a3)
2. open it for editing
3. add a new column, it name will duplicate (a3)
4.1 when saving last collum will be saved as 'Field4'
 to repeat
1. Create a table with columns (Field1, Field2, Field3)
2. open it for editing
3. add a new column, it name will duplicate (Field3)
4 when saving last collum will be lost (second 'Field3')
 to repeat
1. Create a table with columns (Field1, Field2, Field3)
2. open it for editing
3. add a new column, it name will duplicate (Field3)
4 trying to move last collum (second Field3) upper  -> program will crash
 These examples are not just for the standard column names.
No checks the correctness of the table in the editing mode structure
 as I understand:
commit only affects moment to add a new column but there is no verification of column names before executing a user-entered changes

  May I suggest (hopefully for the upcoming release, as it is a tiny change) the 'Browse Data' tab moves first in the order of tabs so it is immediately available when opening the app.

I'm quite confident the majority of users, most of the time they enter the app, they want to go straight to viewing/editing data, instead of the database structure.

Hopefully you agree, and Merry Christmas to all.
  When you try to open a Sqlite database which uses indexes on expressions then DB4S only shows a message box "invalid file format".

Quote from [https://www.sqlite.org/expridx.html]

> The ability to index expressions was added to SQLite with version 3.9.0 in October of 2015. A database that uses an index on expressions will not be usable by earlier versions of SQLite.
 I don't think it's a bug since the SQLite team clearly states that using that new 3.9.x feature makes the database incompatible with previous versions. That's why I'm asking for an updated version.

I'm using the newest available setup for Windows (8.1), 3.7.0 which includes SQLite 3.8.10.2.

The "problem" (=incompatibility) starts after creating an index (by using another tool) which includes an expression: `create index PixelCount on Images (Width * Height)` and the database again becomes compatible after dropping such index.
  [Some "complex" queries do work in latest command line version, but not in the sqlitebrowser](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/34391632/how-can-i-add-row-position-to-a-query-with-a-sum-column-from-subquery?noredirect=1#comment56524568_34391632)

```
$ sqlite3 -version
3.8.10.2 2015-05-20 18:17:19 2ef4f3a5b1d1d0c4338f8243d40a2452cc1f7fe4
```
 ```
Version 3.7.0
Qt Version 4.8.7
SQLCipher Version 3.8.6
```

on OS X 10.11.2

On 18 December 2015 at 17:53, Justin Clift notifications@github.com wrote:

> Hmmm, changing field names should work. In the dialog for either creating
> a new table, or modifying an existing one, just double click on the name of
> the field you want to change. eg Double click on "Field1".
> 
> In theory, that should let you then change it's name to whatever you want.
> If that's not working, let us know as something's wrong. [image: :wink:]
> 
> For the field types, we list SQLite's in built types.
> 
> ```
> https://www.sqlite.org/datatype3.html
> ```
> 
> (Please read that page, as it should help a lot [image: :wink:])
> 
> The course material you're using might benefit from getting a note added
> about the various data types available across different databases,
> depending on which software they expect people to be using.
> 
> Is it practical for you to have a chat with your course instructor, or the
> creator of the course material, or ask about this? [image: :smile:]

  In table view I added a filter for a column. The column contains a text representation of a date as yyyy-mm-dd (e. g. 2013-04-27).

**Example 1** 
Filter `>2010`
SQL-Log: `SELECT rowid,* FROM msgs_view WHERE 1=1 AND date > 2010 ORDER BY date DESC LIMIT 0, 50000;`
Problem: It's a text field but filtering is done numeric. 

**Example 2**
Filter `>2010-10-01`
SQL-Log: `SELECT rowid,* FROM msgs_view WHERE 1=1 AND date LIKE '>2010-10-01' ORDER BY date DESC LIMIT 0, 50000;`
Problem: It's executed as LIKE filter and not as GREATER THAN

**Remark**
There is always an additional sql execution to detect the number of rows
`SELECT COUNT(*) FROM (SELECT rowid,* FROM msgs_view WHERE 1=1 AND date LIKE '>2010-10-01' ORDER BY date DESC);`
Shouldnt ORDERY BY be omitted for performance reasons?
  This isn't an issue with sqlitebrowser -- I didn't know the appropriate way to reach you.

When I look at the OSX .app Frameworks folder of sqlitebrowser, I noticed that your project is much smaller than my Qt app -- you utilize less Qt framework bundles. How did you get your application to support that? For instance, I'm not using QtQuick or QML in my Qt/C++ application. However, when I run my project through macdeployqt, it includes these frameworks in my app bundle. When I try to remove them, my application won't load.
 I found what's going on in my Qt/C++ app. Once I included QtWebKit, it
increased the size by several MB and forced the adding of QtQML and
QtQuick, even though I'm not using those. If I don't add that, the other
frameworks don't get deployed by macdeployqt.

 I suggest you try searching the internet for "Exception code: 0xc0000005" which returns all sorts of possible causes from bad memory to corrupt video drivers, if you add in "ntdll.dll" then you might find something more specific or helpful. However I am sorry to say this suggests the problem is with your computer and not DB Browser for SQLite.   See https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1282792 :

"In the browse data tab, add new row, then double click a field. The popup window appeared to edit the field, and it froze."

Problem is that during synchronization of the plaintextedit and hexedit, the updated editor emits the changed signal which then triggers another syncronization, and so on, resulting in a stack overflow due to infinite recursion:

```
[...]
#42 0x00005555555a169f in EditDialog::editTextChanged() (this=0x55555598b510) at /usr/src/debug/sqlitebrowser-3.7.0/src/EditDialog.cpp:140

#45 0x00007ffff55012ca in QMetaObject::activate(QObject*, int, int, void**) () at /lib64/libQt5Core.so.5

- SQLite 3 seems to use affinity types - ( https://www.sqlite.org/datatype3.html#affinity ) - and has baked in support for column types such as 'DATETIME' etc.

In SQLite Browser, if I execute the SQL that creates a columntype of DATETIME, SQLite supports it, and DATETIME is shown for the column type.

However, when trying to add / edit a column type, these types are not supported, even if I type them in manually.

Perhaps the default column types could be listed, but the add / edit dropdown will accept custom types as well.

I feel this qualifies as a bug - as I can't use your tool to access a built-in function of SQLite.

  I just worked through getting it to build on Qt 4.6.2, on a locked down Linux machine.

It struggled with a few errors when building v3.5.1.

Here are the errors:

```
main.cpp: In function 'int main(int, char**)':
main.cpp:115: error: 'QFile' has not been declared
main.cpp:123: error: 'QFile' has not been declared
main.cpp:148: error: 'QFile' was not declared in this scope
main.cpp:148: error: expected ';' before 'file'
main.cpp:149: error: 'file' was not declared in this scope

MainWindow.cpp:32:25: error: QElapsedTimer: No such file or directory
MainWindow.cpp: In member function 'void MainWindow::executeQuery()':
MainWindow.cpp:749: error: 'QElapsedTimer' was not declared in this scope
MainWindow.cpp:749: error: expected ';' before 'timer'
MainWindow.cpp:750: error: 'timer' was not declared in this scope

EditTableDialog.cpp: In constructor 'EditTableDialog::EditTableDialog(DBBrowserDB*, const QString&, bool, QWidget*)':
EditTableDialog.cpp:20: error: 'currentMSecsSinceEpoch' is not a member of 'QDateTime'

ImportCsvDialog.cpp: In member function 'virtual void ImportCsvDialog::accept()':
ImportCsvDialog.cpp:199: error: 'currentMSecsSinceEpoch' is not a member of 'QDateTime'

FilterTableHeader.cpp: In constructor 'FilterLineEdit::FilterLineEdit(QWidget*, QList<FilterLineEdit*>*, int)':
FilterTableHeader.cpp:14: error: 'setPlaceholderText' was not declared in this scope
```

I'll see about doing a pull request sometime with the fixes.

Fixes basically were:

Add `#include <QFile>` to main.cpp

Wrap includes for `QElaspedTimer` with:

```
#if (QT_VERSION < QT_VERSION_CHECK(4, 7, 0))
# include <QTime>
typedef QTime QElapsedTimer;
#else
# include <QElapsedTimer>
#endif
```

Wrap calls to `QDateTime::currentMSecsToEpoch()` with

```
#if QT_VERSION < QT_VERSION_CHECK(4, 7, 0)
    QDateTime::currentDateTime().toTime_t() * 1000
#else
    QDateTime::currentMSecsSinceEpoch()
#endif
```

Wrap call to `QLineEdit::setPlaceHolderText()` with

```
#if (QT_VERSION < QT_VERSION_CHECK(4, 7, 0))
    // setPlaceHolderText(tr("Filter"));
#else
    setPlaceHolderText(tr("Filter"));
#endif
```

Hope that helps someone.  These fixes should make it backwards compatible with Qt 4.6.
 I'll try rebuilding it with 4.6 on a home computer this weekend. I found
those errors on a locked down computer without internet access.  Sorry
about the late response.  Does it still build easily with 4.8 since
supporting qt 5?
 This is an old thread, but I'll just add that yesterday it saved my hide.  Qt-4.6 may be ancient, but it's what's in use in RedHat 6.8, which is still widely used in industry.  This patch is not irrelevant to me.  Just for jollies, and to be informative, my company-standard installation has qt-1:4.6.2-28 and qt3-3.3.8b-30 installed.  (If you thought Qt-4.6 was old...)  I have qt5-5.6.1-3 available but not installed - apparently nothing "standard" has called for it.  The preparations are beginning to upgrade to RedHat 6.9, but I'm not sure what Qt code levels that will entail or when it will happen. Awesome!  Glad it was useful.  The biggest thing to watch for with older versions of RedHat is support for OpenGL or the MesaGL libraries and xcb support.  If those are fully installed and supported, then Qt 5 will play nice.  Otherwise some gotchas come up.  Qt 4.8.x doesn't need OpenGL, and Qt Lite (in Qt 5.8+) also doesn't need OpenGL.    I have a question regarding the built-in plotting function. I observed that for larger databases (~ 2M entries) the plots look quite different compared to plots made with e.g. python. I also observed that the plots very much depend on the ordering of the entries in the database. 
Since the plots are extremely fast, I assume that you perform some kind of "thinning" before doing the plot? I am right about this? Could you elaborate about the details of how the plots are done?

Thanks,
Christoph Niehoff
 I don't understand what you mean with look different?
The plots depend on what x and y axis(columns) you select,
and of course how your current select statement looks like.

And no there shouldn't be any data left out for plotting, all data that is returned from the select should be used to plot
 Dear Rene,

thank you for you reply!

Let me give you an example.
When I perform the two following select's:
1) select dataA, dataB from DataBase order by dataA
2) select dataA, dataB from DataBase order by dataB
I assume that in both cases I have the same datapoints (or am I wrong here? I am quite new to SQL... ).
But when I make plots with dataA on the x-axis and dataB on the y-axis, I get totally different outcomes  for both cases (different distributions of datapoints and different plot ranges).

Also, I can make a plot with all points. Then I can perform a select that only returns entries, which are in a region, where the plot with all points didn't have any points. This select then shows that there are entries in the database, that the plot did not show...

I assume that this very much depends on the structure of my data. My database contains ~2M entries generated by ~500 different Markov Chains, so the data is pretty much "clustered"...

Thanks very much,
Christoph
 I had a look at the code(some time has past since I wrote it) and I think I have not really accounted such order by statements and the plotting is still more or less some kind of prototype. So this is more or less a bug or missing functionality.

But I can say that we pass all the data returned from the statement to the plotting widget (qcustomplot), but as you noticed it may happen that some data is not shown, thats because it's not possible to draw every datapoint if the x-axis is too large and the plotting widget has to skip data.
 Dear Rene,

thank you very much for taking the time to look into the code.  I think, this pretty much explains it. Thanks, that helped a lot.

All the best,
Christoph

  With monospace fonts query editor rendering seems to be ignoring the proper space width. Screenshots below are both of the exact same text using 10pt Courier New with the red line 1px after the select keyword.

How it should look: Notepad++ 6.7.9
![notepad _6 7 9](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12277525/10455659/f57223a2-7192-11e5-80ed-f36572dcbca8.png)

How it looks: DBBrowser 3.7.0
![dbbrowser_3 7 0](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/12277525/10455658/f5519a1a-7192-11e5-9b12-7a376d017c46.png)

Please note that spaces might not be the only characters involved and **_formatting_** might also affect the result.

Here is the text:

```
select sum(ValorNeto) as Neto, sum(ValorIVA + ValorNeto) as Total
  from NV
 inner join Entidad
    on NV.IdEntidad = Entidad.IdEntidad
 inner join NVEstado
    on NV.IdNVEstado = NVEstado.IdNVEstado
 where NV.IdNVEstado = {0}
       {1};
```

 Sorry for the late reply...I was taking my usual annual SQL cleanse...thanks for the ping, looks like it's fixed!

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/121520/13132196/b5e32b56-d5a5-11e5-8da4-57812a243700.png)

Thanks! I'm closing the ticket now as the issue has been resolved. Don't know if it's worth mentioning that the **output** font remains uniformly small...but maybe that's intended? Or in an option that I've missed (is it not the SQL Log Font Size, which I've set to be 32 in the screenshot above, the same as in the SQL Editor Font Size setting)? 

If I have one more interface suggestion to make, based on my experience in using SQLite Browser for live demos and teaching SQL in-class, it's that that bottom output panel can be very easy to miss, even for me, but especially for new users/SQL novices who don't realize that it's related to the execution of the query...which gets confusing for novices who struggle with knowing the difference between an empty query set and an actual error. Configuring the font-size would be helpful, but even a little color flash upon update, or a red-highlight border around the output box in the event of an error, would be really helpful.

Thanks again!
  I'm happy to see the usage of qhexedit in the wild. I would be more happy, if you add a reference to
 https://github.com/Simsys/qhexedit2
 yes we use qhexedit, it was introduced while @MKleusberg reworked the value editor dialog a long time ago.

https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/tree/master/libs/qhexedit

  Hello,

is there any way to Interrupt a (far too) long running query. Actually I kill the process, but that's not the nice way to do.

 Ralf
 Hello Martin,
I understand your concerns. Perhaps just as information: SQLite Studio shows up an interrupt button when a query is engaged, works fine, so far no problems, but not heavily used anyway.

I came to this, because by un(for)seen changes at my collected measurement data I run into troubles with my (old) queries: SQLite Studio could interrupt them, SQLite Browser I had to kill each time ...

Personally I much more like SQLite Browser; I use SQLite Studio for some work because here I can attach a bunch of databases by a set of query statements, which SQLite Browser cannot.

Regards
 Ralf

  Bob
  That version number sounds like a release one, @justinclift was suggesting you look at the latest nightly build. If you go to https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser and scroll down you will find some explanation and a link to the nightly build. Try that and see.
 Now using 3.7.99 and I see many NEW   options for changing the font and font size - but none for the row   height.¬† Even when I use a very small font size the row height   remains unchanged, and too big. I tried a smaller font size, just to  see if that would reduce the row height. Nope.
  I want to have shorter row heights - primarily to see more rows on   a single screen.
 A friendly +1 for this.
I just updated from 2.0b1 to 3.9.1, I was very excited by all the progress‚Ä¶ but then I became very sad when I saw how bigger the rows have become‚Ä¶ Yes, there is an improvement. Here are some screenshots:
* [3.9.1](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/544424/24899798/e49ba6a8-1ea1-11e7-9791-507eb501d9bd.png)
* [nightly 2017-04-11](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/544424/24899801/e7bc9bb2-1ea1-11e7-9112-7081f7c3e6a3.png)

Personally I'd prefer even narrower rows, like in the "Database Structure" tab. But it's highly subjective, I use quite denser layouts than most people do.

So, it should be fine as it is now. Thanks! Hi Justin,

While I recently got a Win64 PC, I also have my old Win32 PC.  I tried both 2017-04-11 versions (what is the difference? what is sqlcipher? ) on the Win32 PC and both worked really well. There are certainly many more features now which are not apparent how to use. I'm sure the online Help will follow.

I thought there was going to be something under Preferences that specifically addressed row height. Changing the browser font size will change the row height indirectly but I saw nothing that would change the row height directly. For example, a smaller row height with no change in font size would reduce the white space between each line.

One minor change I noticed. File names in the new version use forward slashes / instead of back slashes \ . It just looks unusual to see some of the files with back slashes and some with forward slashes when I view the most recent files in the Files menu. I think the Windows default is back slashes, although I believe either will work. As a PC user, this is something I've never paid much attention to.

Bob

  I tried to delete the content of a table "myTable" in an attached database "myDB":

DELETE FROM myDB.myTable;

And got the following error:

(Where "Tablename" is the name of a table in the main database)

The table itself exists, so a query on that table works:
SELECT \* FROM myDB.myTable;

DELETE FROM main.myTable;

  When a field contains line feeds, in the Browse Data tab, the contents are displayed on the same line but without any space between the lines.  I propose you replace line feeds with a space so as to look better as single line.  For example:

If fields contains:
Hello<CRLF>
World

It now displays as:
HelloWorld

(no space between Hello and World)

After my suggestion:
Hello World
 That would work also (even better, actually).  However, still a space should surround the special character or else again it will look as one word when printed as a single line.
  I would like an option for Filter to automatically enclose whatever typed text in %% so as to not to have to type the % all the time.  This is because I have found that practically always I need a ‚Äú%text%‚Äù type search instead of just ‚Äútext‚Äù.
 That's why I thought of it as a settable option (View/Preferences)

Better yet, a checkbox right next to the filters row where one can immediately change the default, and also verify its current state.
 Hi,

another problematic point here is the immediate activation of the filter while still typing. With big data it took relevant time to complete the intendet filter phrase, and the program does filtering again and again with every of the next typed in characters.

Alternative solutions might be:
1) drop this auto activation behaviour (not that conveniant)
2) make it optional by Setting (a bit better)
3) define a certain amount of time to wait that no further Input is done in the filter field and only then start filter Action (my best bet, i.e. 400ms might be a good starting point)

Regards
 Ralf
 This seems unrelated to this proposal as the only difference is that the LIKE argument will be automatically embraced by % characters.  None of the remaining functionality is affected.

As for appropriate solutions to the other issue, I'd go with 3.
 I appreciate all the work put into this, and the result is very good.

However, there is one issue with this always-on use of % that may be a problem.  It fails to handle the case where a string is also found as a sub-string of another string.  For example, the names: John and Johnson

If I'm looking for John, typing John will give me both and there may be cases where I only need to see just John without Johnson.  And, there is no way to make it not find Johnson.

I think some kind of on/off switch for this option is needed.

(BTW, one minor note about the implementation.  I looked at the code and when the string is empty it is replaced by '%%' when just one '%' is sufficient.  Not important in that it does not change the behavior.)
 I didn't know about the = option.  That will work just as well. Thanks.
 It's OK as far as I'm concerned!
  Hi,
Thanks for a great product.

My Name is Svein Berger (mr.) I'm a Norwegian software developer.
First I want to apologize for my limited knowledge of English. So please try to understand my note.

We are using an technical application that saves data to a SQLite database.
The first version of the program was written in Delphi. Later I rewrote the program in C#.
The character set back then was Windows western europe (same as CP1252)
When I rewrote the program to C# i kept the old character set. That was because it was to complicated to convert the data to UTF-8.

As a Norwegian (it applies to most countries in Europe), we use letters that are outside A..Z like √∏√¶√• √∂ √º etc. 
At the time we startet to use our database UTF-8 was not the common character sets. The transition to UTF-8 is no problem for those who only use the letters A..Z. But for us who live in countries that have an extended alphabet, the transition to UTF-8 is a challenge for some older systems. The letters A..Z kept the same places in the new character set, but the letters that we use was "shuffled around". 
So the result it that when we use a program, liker yours great app, the letters √∏√¶√• is displayed wrong.
An example: Pressure test is in Norwegian Trykkpr√∏ving. But it is like this TrykkprÔøΩving in DB Browser for SQLite. For all charaters √ò√Ü√Ö √∏√¶√• is displayed like ÔøΩ. Not very nice.

Pleas see attatched screen shot.

If I had written the program to day, I would of course used UFT-8, and everyone would be happy.

I fully understand that you do not add an additional interpretations of the character set in the program. But if you have the opportunity and see this as a challenge, I would be more than happy to test the solution for you.

If I make my self unclear, please ask me and I will try my best to answer you.

Kind regards

Svein Berger
IT Manager
TTC NORGE AS
sveinb@ttc.no

  There was a previous problem (https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/issues/394) in the Window's version that was fixed on August 19th 2015. Later it got broken, which I mentioned in that thread, but here's a new report with up-to-date information. :smiley: 
Now, the Edit-window is alternating between two places depending on the position of the main form. First it appears in one place, then the other next time it's opened. If the main window is moved, it's two different places. Sometimes half way outside the screen border.

The position of the main form is stored when the application is closed, so wouldn't it be a good idea if you added a setting in Preferences to also store the position of the Edit-window? Those who don't have any problems can leave that setting unchecked and will have the applications default behaviour. :smile:

![default](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6053197/9262130/3dff4e4e-421b-11e5-88c2-2d985f555a5e.png)
 I would say the bug is that UI is unable to display names with escaped special symbols. There is nothing bad in having special symbols escaped in the names of fields/tables, isn't it?

However, there are some more issues with at least this particular special symbol.
In the same circumstances if we will rename column 'example' to 'exa`mple' it will be renamed (from the first look). However, attempt to move column up/down will lead to "renameColumn: cannot find column " error.
Also, on exit through "ok" button changed name will be not saved if alphanumeric sequence is used. In case of numbers only we will see situation which was initially reported here

  I installed SqliteBrowser recently, and to my surprise found that the program tries to make a https connection to an IP automatically at launch. With the amount of open-source involvement in this, I realize this probably something innocuous like Checking for updates or something, but even then, connecting to some IP without any form of notification to the user raises immediate red flags to me.

If it is indeed about automatic updates, please allow the user to choose it consciously, rather than doing it behind the curtains. With a simple dialogue at first launch, saying "Automatic updates are enabled and will ensure DB4S is at the latest version" - with a prominent OK button and a "Change setting" text link that takes you to the Preferences page - you can also ensure that only those who really wish to disable auto-updates do that. Currently, even if the user wishes not to allow external connections (for whatever reason), a connection is going to happen at the very first launch, before (s)he has a chance to change the Preferences.

And whenever update check is going on, you could also give a simple notification, putting to use the several unused pixels at the bottom of the window. I consider this necessary because, given that DB4S is a desktop program that one doesn't expect to connect to the Internet, making external connections is an unusual state for the program and something that deserves a user notification. Putting it at the bottom left also keeps it similar to browser status messages, which would make it easier for users to grok.

  would love if we were able to edit(UPDATE) the returned SQL records from a SELECT query without having to manually issue an UPDATE statement or switching back to the data editor tab.

  ... and how to use them?
 Of course ^^ Thanks for your help @justinclift @MKleusberg :+1: 
  UTF16 = Case sensitive compare
UTF16CI = Case insensitive compare

comparison is performed by QString functions.

AFAIK the Byte order of QStrings are CPU dependent. This means, that the collation does not work if the byte order of QString does not match the byte order of the database. 
 The reason to choose this collating sequence was the need for a Unicode collation that really matched the in-memory comparison. Especially regarding  non-UCS2 chars and Unicode normalization. The performance should be OK as we're not copying any data here.

  Sometimes I use YYYYMMDD format as the user_version in a database to know when it was last modified. It is stored and displayed correctly when using the SQLite3 command line:

```
sqlite> PRAGMA user_version = 20150623;
sqlite> PRAGMA user_version;
20150623
```

However, when viewing the database from DB4S, the User_Version will not be displayed correctly (it will be 10000) if the value is higher than 10000.

According to SQLite3 (https://www.sqlite.org/pragma.html#pragma_schema_version) the user_version is a 32-bit signed integer (maximum value is 2,147,483,647).

```
sqlite> PRAGMA user_version = 2147483647;
sqlite> PRAGMA user_version;
2147483647
```
 Thanks for the quick reply and fix. I will test it tomorrow and get back to you.
 Yes, it is working. The User_Version is displayed correctly now. Thanks a lot.
  Function `setFont()`, without params, sets font for all lexems types. .
To set default font color to black I used `sqlLexer->setColor(Qt::black, QsciLexerSQL::Default)`.
That's also keeps numbers color with aquablue color

And it doesn't  looks very clever now, it thinks that every not special english SQL word is table or column name.

  There is some old bug which presented from version 3.6. Look at this picture (first line) that's how it looks now, cyrillic characters (out of comments and quotes) are drawn with different font:
![image 10](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5500999/8280145/0e3f9ea2-190d-11e5-84ce-87f600c57cda.png)

There is the test string:

``` SQL
–∞–±–≤–≥–¥–µ–∏–π–∫–ª–º–Ω–æ–ø—Ä—Å—Ç—É—Ñ—Ö—Ü—á—à—â—ä—ã—å—ç—é—è
-- –∞–±–≤–≥–¥–µ–∏–π–∫–ª–º–Ω–æ–ø—Ä—Å—Ç—É—Ñ—Ö—Ü—á—à—â—ä—ã—å—ç—é—è
SELECT *
FROM Student
WHERE name like '–ê–ª–µ–∫—Å–∞–Ω–¥—Ä%'
```
 This problem is presented also on windows and linux. Also changing font size doesn't affect size of this characters. Looks like It's also affect arithmetic characters and digits:
![db browser for sqlite - -home-m-mmk-_akarin-lessons-lessons- -students dbs_058](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5500999/8283570/383d5aa4-1922-11e5-9d4d-816f290e2124.png)

Maybe this is some special UTF8 digits, here the another test string:

``` SQL
–∞–±–≤–≥–¥–µ–∏–π–∫–ª–º–Ω–æ–ø—Ä—Å—Ç—É—Ñ—Ö—Ü—á—à—â—ä—ã—å—ç—é—èqwerty
-- –∞–±–≤–≥–¥–µ–∏–π–∫–ª–º–Ω–æ–ø—Ä—Å—Ç—É—Ñ—Ö—Ü—á—à—â—ä—ã—å—ç—é—è
SELECT 1234567890-=/+,.\|
FROM Student 
WHERE name like '–ê–ª–µ–∫—Å–∞–Ω–¥—Ä%'
```
 I have tried to compile binded example, changed font. 

``` cpp
...
textEdit->setUtf8(true);
QsciLexerSQL *lex = new QsciLexerSQL(this);
lex->setFont(QFont("Andale Mono", 20));
textEdit->setLexer(lex);
...
```

 I found out that if make this small fix in SqlTextEdit::reloadSettings() function, everything starts to work, but I'm not sure will it broke something or not...

``` cpp
...
defaultfont.setPointSize(PreferencesDialog::getSettingsValue("editor", "fontsize").toInt());

// sqlLexer->setDefaultFont(defaultfont); // comment this line
sqlLexer->setFont(defaultfont); // and replace with this line
setupSyntaxHighlightingFormat("comment", QsciLexerSQL::Comment);
...
```

 Ok, let me try =)
  I tried to delete a column via the "Modify Table" popup. Selecting the column and clicking on "Remove" brought up a popup that said "No error", but the column remained. The SQL log for the app shows:

SAVEPOINT sqlitebrowser_rename_column
CREATE TABLE `sqlitebrowser_rena... <string can not be logged, contains binary data> ...
INSERT INTO sqlitebrowser_rename_column_new_table SELECT`_ID`,`name`,`local_path_template`,`is_localized`,`is_automatic`,`file_set_id`FROM`FileInfo`;
DROP TABLE`FileInfo`;
ROLLBACK TO SAVEPOINT sqlitebrowser_rename_column;

which I interpret to mean that a) the rollback means that the operation failed, despite the "No error" popup, and b) perhaps binary data in the CREATE TABLE statement is not helping, either? (Could this be a side-effect of the new UTF-8 support?)
 Yes, I do have tables that reference FileInfo with foreign keys. It would have been nice to get clearer error messages or logs, but... you get what you pay for :-}
 Thanks for asking. I'm making an assumption here (yes, I could try it out, but... :-) that the sqlite API reports an error message if you try to delete a table, or rows in a table, that can't be deleted due to a FK constraint. So if sqlite's error message(s) could be displayed in the popup, instead of it displaying "No error", that would be a big help. If that's not feasible, then even "Unknown Error" would be better. As it was, the "No error" lulled me into thinking that indeed no error had occurred. (Maybe "No error" was displayed not to mean that no error had occurred, but rather that an error _had_ occurred but the browser couldn't determine what the error was.)

I realize this is asking quite a bit more, but: It would be great if, when I try to delete a table or column that's referenced by a foreign key, the browser could tell me in advance of execution "You can't do that; it's got foreign keys pointing to it."
 Thank you! Hi, all,

  I've used the SQLCipher instructions to allow my iOS app to create an encrypted database.  When I try to open it in sqlitebrowser I just continuously get prompted to enter the password.  I'm not sure what I'm doing wrong.  Any ideas?

 Thanks for your help, I found the problem.  You mentioned building sqlitebrowser with a newer version of SQLCipher, well that's what I needed to do.  Spot on ... prominent with the Centos build.  Thanks.  
 I‚Äôm using a Cinnamon shell over GNOME (v.v. GTK3+ based), so yes there could be a source of divergence.
  http://stackoverflow.com/questions/30643061/sqlite-db-browser-invalid-operand-for-regexp 

I use DB Browser for SQLite version 3.6.0; SQLite Version 3.8.9. If I use regexp on a nullable column `revision` then `invalid operand` error is happened.

``` sql
    SELECT brand,revision FROM TDevice WHERE TDevice.revision regexp '^ASUS$';
```

Below is the schema:

``` sql
    CREATE TABLE `TDevice` (
    `id`    INTEGER NOT NULL,
    `brand` varchar(128) NOT NULL,
    `model` varchar(128) NOT NULL,
    `revision`  TEXT,
    PRIMARY KEY(id)
    );
```

After I replaced the NULL `revision` with empty string, then this issue fixed.

``` sql
    UPDATE TDevice SET revision='' WHERE revision IS NULL
```

I assume `regexp` should behave as `LIKE` operator, because `LIKE` operator can accept NULL text.
  When a table is empty an you export, (suing the first 2 checkbox)
it will export an additional ); just after the create table.
Consequently, It makes an error  when you import,
 It works with the latest nightly build.
Thanks !!!!
  Using File > Export > Database to SQL File:
Tables containing some data, are written correctly. But for empty tables, an extra ); is added on a new line, after the table.

Example:
correct:
CREATE TABLE "Table_with_data" (
  "object_id" INTEGER NOT NULL,
  "value" REAL NULL);
INSERT INTO `Table_with_data` VALUES (1,40.0);
INSERT INTO `Table_with_data` VALUES (2,90.0);

incorrect:
CREATE TABLE "Empty_table" (
  "object_id" INTEGER NOT NULL,
  "value" REAL NULL);
); <<<<<<<<<< redundant closing bracket

AFAICS, this occurs since v3.6.0 (export was correct in 3.5.1)
 OK, I will. I'll let you know if it works. Thanks for fixing!
 Hi Justin,

Just tested with the nightly build and confirm fixed. Export is correct. 
Thanks,

Best regards
Anton

select \* from refer where namecn like '%??%'
