  Since sqlitebrowser is oriented towards end-users, it would be optimal if it could be executed from the command line to open a specific database, switch to a specific tab (e.g. Browse Data), open a specific table, and (if feasible) do so either "read-only" or "editing enabled".  

Example: 

"C:\Program Files (x86)\SqliteBrowser3\bin\sqlitebrowser.exe  --path=x:\mydb.db   --tab=browse   --table=mytable   --action=edit  "

This capability would enable sqlitebrowser to be executed from other applications within a specific context for a specific purpose while ensuring that the end-user gets exactly where they need to be.

  At the end of installation, you are given an option to run the program. However the program is run as an administrator user, rather than the user that initially launched the installer.

  When you enter a query in "Execute SQL" tab with line-break, your query is not logged properly :
The first line is logged then
&lt;string can not be logged, contains binary data&gt;

Maybe replacing line-breaks with whitespaces could solve the issue.
 DB4S 3.6.0 under Windows 8.1 pro x64
 Just checked 3.7.0, not solved.
 a query which don't need a working database :

```
WITH RECURSIVE
  cnt(x) AS (VALUES(1) UNION ALL SELECT x+1 FROM cnt WHERE x<1000000)
SELECT x FROM cnt;
```

taken from [Recursive Query Examples](https://www.sqlite.org/lang_with.html)
 Every line is logged correctly, no longer truncated and no
&lt;string can not be logged, contains binary data&gt;
in log
but...
a side effect appeared: empty lines are logged in User log
if you add 5 empty lines at the end of you sql command, User log will contains 5 empty lines

this is not the case in Application log
this issue is not present in 3.7.0 release

I notice the Application log is sightly different than User log
is this 2 different processes ?
 Just to be sure I explained the behavior clearly:
Consider this 4 lines query (3 lines + 1 empty)

```
WITH RECURSIVE
  cnt(x) AS (VALUES(1) UNION ALL SELECT x+1 FROM cnt WHERE x<1000000)
SELECT x FROM cnt;

```

With v3.7.0 this query creates 2 lines in User log:

```
WITH RECURSIVE
  cnt(x) AS (VAL... <string can not be logged, contains binary data> ...
```

and 3 lines in Application log:

```
SELECT COUNT(*) FROM (WITH RECUR... <string can not be logged, contains binary data> ...
WITH RECURSIVE
  cnt(x) AS (VAL... <string can not be logged, contains binary data> ...
```

With nightly build, the 4 lines of the query are copy/paste in User log:

```
WITH RECURSIVE
  cnt(x) AS (VALUES(1) UNION ALL SELECT x+1 FROM cnt WHERE x<1000000)
SELECT x FROM cnt;

```

And 6 lines in Application log:

```
SELECT COUNT(*) FROM (WITH RECURSIVE
  cnt(x) AS (VALUES(1) UNION ALL SELECT x+1 FROM cnt WHERE x<1000000)
SELECT x FROM cnt);
WITH RECURSIVE
  cnt(x) AS (VALUES(1) UNION ALL SELECT x+1 FROM cnt WHERE x<1000000)
SELECT x FROM cnt LIMIT 0, 50000;
```

I would really like to help improve DB4S but I'm unable to build the source code actually.
 I checked the latest nightly,
the commit from @MKleusberg is working perfectly.

  The new 64-bit version is obviously not an update but a completely separate program to any existing 32-bit installation. Certainly not a bug by any means, but perhaps a note could be included somewhere for unaware users.

I was unaware of sqlitebrowser's 32-bit-only history and just assumed it had always come in 64-bit offerings when I saw the 64-bit download. As a result, my head got scratched a few times when it kept asking me to install 3.60 even after updating. It only dawned on me when I uninstalled 3.60 and still saw 3.40 sitting in my x86 folder :)
 Well, I can think of at least two ideas.

The most useful spot would be in the 'There is a new version, please download' pop-up alert that appears, since it's what triggers most users to download the new version in the first place. Having such a note would clutter up the alert window though, and wouldn't be relevant to someone updating to a 32-bit version or (eventually) from a 64-bit version.

The neater solution is to have the installer detect existing 32-bit installations as well and uninstall them before continuing. This turns into a much bigger implementation though, with the need to migrate user configs/etc to the new directory in addition to the 32-bit detection.

Not a critical issue now but maybe something to think of down the line? I'm sure this happens in countless other projects too- maybe others have addressed the issue elegantly before.
 Can do! Need to work on some projects at the moment but will be sure to
find some time this weekend for you. Great to hear about your progress :)

  Self-explanatory: I'm using sqlitebrowser to examine data but only the affiliated software must be permitted to modify the DB in any way! Lest a slip of the mouse occur, I respectfully request that you folks implement an Open Read-Only capability down the road or ASAP. Hey, THANKS!

 I have just tried opening a database, issuing some queries and then doing a binary diff, nothing changes, which is good. I then marked the database file read-only and when I tried to add a row I got an error message. So, DB Browser for SQLite does seem to do the write thing. As a workaround I would mark the file read-only to avoid problems. However it would still be good for us to add an enhancement displaying "read only mode" and also handling the UI better.

I tested on Windows by the way.

  Previous versions were all build statically. So I could have exe file in one directory.. The 3.6.0 is build dynamically with a bunch of files which is not very nice. You should also link to the msvcrt statically.
  As the title says I'm having trouble registering the `*.db` file extension. When I double click such a file I'm asked to select the program to open it with. When I navigate to `C:\Program Files\sqlitebrowser3\bin` and choose `sqlitebrowser.exe` it is not added to the "Open with" window and thus I can't select it as the default option.
 It seems like the same issue, but I didn't find it using the search. I'll attempt the solution later this week and let you know.
 Yes that solution has worked for me. I changed the value of `HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\Applications\sqlitebrowser.exe\shell\open\command` from `"C:\Program Files (x86)\SqliteBrowser3\bin\sqlitebrowser.exe" "%1"` to `"C:\Program Files\SqliteBrowser3\bin\sqlitebrowser.exe" "%1"` and the extension can once again be registered. Thanks for the help.

  Hi guys,
I've got tables with fields marked as NotNull. Tried to add a new record which returns "Error adding record: NOT NULL constraint failed".
I'm guessing the logic defaults everything to NULL for the user to change.

Current workaround: uncheck not null fields, add new record, populate with requisite data, recheck not null fields

  In the 'structure' as well as the 'DB Schema' (aren't those two not the same ref to the table called 'sqlite_master' and therefore can better carry only one of aforementioned names [my suggestion 'Schema', bc it's called like that in most books and RFC's] ?) window is a column 'type' (may be one of the four on the left - 'table', 'view', 'index', 'trigger' [ eventually 'meta', but in practice I've never seen such a type... ] so to save space and avoid confusion to others and me you may safely remove it. With large CREATE TABLE statements, the interface kinda messes up in those two interfaces (Database Structure tab, and the right side window, DB Schema), as it tries to show the full CREATE TABLE statement with all the newlines, tabs and spaces included. These CREATE TABLE statements are created by SQLAlchemy, so thats why they are formatted that way, but it theoretically could happen with manual written statements too if people like them to look pretty in the code.

Easier to show a screenshot: http://i.imgur.com/8bCmexZ.png

I would suggest making it so that the Database Structure tab, all the 'tables' are not so far apart (as it shows the large Create Table statement by default, and maybe have that as a drop down arrow as a child of the table, so it doesn't mess up the formatting/spacing of the table by default? 

And also for the DB Schema side window on the right, i dont think there is a need to show the full CREATE TABLE statement anyway, as you are already parsing out the individual columns anyway and showing the relevant part (per the column) right next to the column anyway. Maybe add entries for Foreign Keys and you won't need the whole CREATE TABLE statement?
 That option does exist! thanks.

I guess i just don't understand why we even have the 'text' schema there at all, what does 'column_name VARCHAR(200)' tell us that already parsed columns with the 'name' and 'type' information in the respective columns don't? I would support just getting rid of the text schema (except for maybe one place), and just have everything be available in the graphical tree view, including foreign keys, NOT NULL constraints, etc
 Another picture, this of MySQLWorkbench, a program that is basically like sqlitebrowser only for mysql, and it sorta has what i'm envisioning for the schema views, where everything is available in a tree like fashion and we don't really need the giant CREATE TABLE string...

http://i.imgur.com/KGfYq4m.png
  Copyin text from sql-results with non-ascii (cyrillic symbols) it displays wtih ????

  On the 32-bit version of sqlitebrowser for Windows (W7P x64), I can set sqlite files to automatically open with sqlitebrowser. However, I was unable to do this for the 64-bit version. Just letting you know. Thanks!
 I right click, "open with...", "Browse...", then select the sqlitebrowser executable "C:\Program Files\SqliteBrowser3\bin\sqlitebrowser3.exe". Normally, the application would then appear back in the application selection screen. In this case, however, it doesn't appear, so I can't select it. It would be useful to get confirmation.

p.s. I also just tried using the "Default Programs" route, but same issue.
 Had the same issue for the 64 bit version. I figured that the registry entry is still pointing to the wrong directory. So in HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\Applications\sqlitebrowser3.exe\shell\open\command the value needs to be changed from "C:\Program Files (x86)..." to  "C:\Program Files..."
 If I remove HKCR\Applications\sqlitebrowser.exe and then associate with "c:\Program Files\sqlitebrowser3\bin\sqlitebroswer.exe" windows keeps the association. But if there is an exisiting shell\open\command (with an incorrect path) for the application it does not.
Maybe the installer made by cmake nsis generator works in a similar way. Without an explicit removal of that key it just leaves the exisiting?
 I had the same issue (Couldn't register the 64-bit as the default program after having the 32-bit).
The [solution](https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/issues/279#issuecomment-98643971) by @hko-gh worked for me.
 Well its _very_ basic but here's a start. I didn't know how to do a pull request on a wiki so https://github.com/maxslimmer/sqlitebrowser/wiki/Windows-File-Associations
 Having first edited @maxslimmer copy of the Wiki I have now coped this to the sqlitebrowser wiki and added the link.

@justinclift let me know if we need anything else doing but I think we can close this issue now like #296 
 I have seen other software do one of two things:
- put a check box in the installer, so users can opt in to file association if they want
- options in the preferences for file association

Pretty sure this is possible either way, another option is both. However I think we need to support multiple and possibly custom file extensions given sqlite files don't have a standard extension
 I guess we need a good wiki page and a Tweet? Or something like that anyway. Maybe http://sqlitebrowser.org/ should link direct to the wiki, as well as GitHub, some people might not know there is documentation in the form of the wiki on the GitHub site.
 Thanks, an option in the installer sounds excellent.  This would also help the users who had created associations by hand that subsequently got broken with renaming.

You will need to decide what extensions to use.  As a starting point for that, according to http://stackoverflow.com/questions/808499/what-is-the-best-extension-name-sqlite-database-files 

> Emacs expects one of db, sqlite, sqlite2 or sqlite3 in the default configuration for sql-sqlite mode
 A user preference in the program would be convenient.  However it needs to be done carefully because changing file associated settings needs temporary escalation to Administrator access.

I feel that the developers should choose either install time or a subsequent preference depending on implementation factors.  As a user, I would welcome and can adapt to either.
 Excellent.  One other thought - if possible please can the installer allow a reconfigure option to change the setting of any config options without forcing a reinstall.  Often when I am evaluating software, I don't want to take over existing extensions.  But then when I decide to use it to replace my existing software, I want to go back and enable the extensions.
  See bellow results of query.

  Running Windows 7, 64-bit OS.

I had a 32-bit version of 3.5.1. This time around I decided to go 64-bit for 3.6.0v2. I uninstalled the 32-bit version (which wasn't registered in Windows 7's Add/Remove Programs list, so I had to find it and use uninstall.exe), but unfortunately it didn't get everything. 

I installed 64-bit, and double clicked on a .db file. It brought up the 32-bit version that I thought I had just uninstalled. I did this a couple times and then uninstalled 64-bit, searched my hard drive manually deleting every sqlitebrowser.exe I could find.  I re-installed 64-bit, but now I could not double click on my .db files and make them open in sqlite browser. It associated with the next program on the list (just happened to be 7zip, and 7zip choked...). 

In any case, digging into the registry, I found that the key HKEY_CLASSES_ROOT\Applications\sqlitebrowser.exe\shell\open\command\Default was still set to  "C:\Program Files **(x86)**\SqliteBrowser3\bin\sqlitebrowser.exe" "%1". This confused Windows 7 and would not let it associate the new, 64-bit install with .db. Once I whacked that and re-installed 64-bit, it was shiny.

tl;dr: Make sure that the uninstall whacks that reg key so an install with a different target (32/64/ia/etc) will not confuse Windows.

Other than that, great job with 3.6.0v2. I like it. :-)
 Ah. That's why it didn't unset them. :-)
My bad.

  Perhaps a feature rather than a bug.

I used an open-source conversion program to go from an SQL file to a SQLlite file.  That program left the data types in the table schema in their original SQL form.  One was a "bit" type.  Your browser seems to interpret that reasonably.  It displays as either 0 or 1.  When I run an sql command in your browser to select for 0 or 1, it works as expected.

But when I run the same command in SQLlite3, it never selects regardless of the bit value.

It appears that the browser is interpreting data types in a different way than SQLlite3.  So while the browser's liberal behavior is a nice convenience, it is misleading.  Perhaps the browser should display the type being used?  Or warn?

Otherwise, I'm very happy with it in my rather limited experience to date.

 I am having the same problem. I have tried the same directory approach , and no dice..

Win7 x64    db version  3.8.0
 I ran into this same issue and I finally got it to work. It has to do with the library search paths on Windows because `mod_spatialite` in turn loads its own dependent DLLs that reside in the same directory as `mod_spatialite.dll`.

I got it working 2 different ways:

1.) Add the directory containing the spatialite `.dll` files to your `%PATH%`. Windows searches `%PATH%` for dll files so it will be able to locate it.
2.) Copy the `.dll` files to the same directory containing `DB Browser for SQLite.exe`. e.g. `C:\Program Files\DB Browser for SQLite` or `C:\Program Files (x86)\DB Browser for SQLite` whichever version you have installed (32bit or 64bit). You will also want to make sure you use the correct x86 or x64 dll files that correspond to the version of sqlitebrowser you have.

This works because Windows searches for .dll files in `%PATH%` and the current application directory. So putting them in either place works.

If `mod_spatialite` were shipped as fat binary containing _everything_ in a single dll file I don't believe this would be necessary and it would just work pointing it at the dll, but until then we have to make sure all of the .dll's are located somewhere Windows will search when loading shared libs. I added a new page.

https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/wiki/SpatiaLite-on-Windows I think this issue can be closed because it's definitely not an issue with DB4S. I don't believe there's anything to be done other than making a more location-independent build of `mod_spatialite`.  The FileOpenDialog show all files in all formats. The SQLite formats are: *.db, *.sqlite, *.sqlite3, *.db3. Is it possible to add the filter?

  To perhaps clarify a bit more outside of the twitter character limit!  We have a SQLite DB in our Unity project, and a requirement was encryption.  sqlcipher wasn't supported by the SQLite Unity plugin we used (https://www.assetstore.unity3d.com/en/#!/content/4334), so we had to use their "PRAGMA key = X" to encrypt the DB on devices.  We would love a way to then use sqlitebrowser to decrypt the contents of this DB after pulling it off a device and entering our key.  I grabbed the latest nightly build of sqlitebrowser as well as the cipher-enabled version, but neither of them will decrypt our DB. (though i'm unsure if changing the "page size" value in sqlcipher version would help, I have no idea what value I'd use there)  

The format of key we're using is:  0x5c516e4e21a65b8fee841db84b462367

 @justinclift Has been made any progress on this?   This is occurring in the latest nightly Windows build.

When modifying the order of fields, the 'move up/down' buttons are disabled when at the top/bottom of the list. But if you click on another row, then hold down the mouse button and drag to one of the end rows, the movement buttons are not properly disabled. So you can click to move the top row up and the bottom row down, both of which crash the application.

The inverse also works, so if you click the bottom row, then drag up one row, the "move down" button will be disabled even though you should be able to move the field. So basically it seems like the listener for disabling those buttons triggers on the mouse click, not the actual final selection after dragging around.

On Wed, Apr 15, 2015 at 12:32 PM, Justin Clift notifications@github.com
wrote:

> ## Hmmmm, in theory (!) if the first command line argument you pass is a database file name... it should open it.  Isn't that what Automator should be doing?
> 
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub:
> https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/issues/259#issuecomment-93494022
 Okay. I figured out how to do this. Create an Automator service that runs a shell script. I even included a notification center to prompt with the filename as it opens. But that's not necessary.

```
for f in "$@"
do
    osascript -e "display notification \"$f\" with title \"Opening file:\""
    open -a "sqlitebrowser" "$1"
done
```

  It would be convenient of pressing 'tab' in the SQL editor when multiple lines of text were selected indented all of the lines. The current behavior replaces the selection with a tab.

This could be useful when incrementally building complex queries and subqueries.
  EXPLAIN QUERY PLAN SELECT BlahField FROM BladDb WHERE foo=0;

begins a transaction when one is not required.

When using the DB browser to execute certain queries it enables the "write changes" and "revert changes" options when this is not required. This means DB Browser creates a transaction that is awaiting a COMMIT or ROLLBACK but no such thing is required in this case since the explain verb does not write anything. In journal DELETE mode an empty journal is created.

SELECT BlahField FROM BladDb WHERE foo=0;

works as expected and no transaction is creating awaiting a COMMIT or ROLLBACK.
 Thanks for the quick response.
Adding "END TRANSACTION" can have catastrophic consequences if my main app is running at the same time which sadly is how I found this problem in the first place.

But what are your thoughts on one of these fixes:

Option 1: It appears the sqlitebrowser understands that there are times when a transaction is not required.
SELECT BlahField FROM BladDb WHERE foo=0;
executes without enabling the "write changes" and "revert changes" buttons. So since sqlitebrowser knows not to start a transaction in that case why not add statements like "EXPLAIN" to the list of cases where a transaction is not created similar to how "SELECT" is handled? In fact instead of having a hard-coded list, as I am suggesting, why not call
int sqlite3_stmt_readonly(sqlite3_stmt *pStmt);
on the prepared statement to determine if changes will be made by that statement. Then only start a transaction in the cases where changes will be made.

Option 2: Since Transactions cant be nested perhaps DB Browser should consider using (SAVEPOINT, RELEASE, ROLLBACK TO) instead of (BEGIN, COMMIT, ROLLBACK). This might work better in the cases where I am using sqlitebrowser to look up something in the DB while my main app is running. Note to self: I should perhaps make this same switch in my app too.

Option 3: Let the user control the creation of transactions. Add an option to disable the current transaction approach built into sqlitebrowser thus forcing us users, who choose that option, to manually create transactions via the BEGIN or SAVEPOINT in those cases where we feel it is required. And if we don't then we get the default SQLite automatic transactions on every statement.

Forgive me is any of this is already in place or has already been discounted as crazy. I have not looked through the code.
 @rp- I have always thought that SQLite handled multiple processes accessing the DB perfectly fine. But after fooling around with the explain query in SQLiteBrowser I eventually wound up at a place where my main app stopped running complaining that it could not prepare a SQL statement. Closing the DB in SqliteBrowser resolved the issue and allowed my app to continue. Maybe this is something unrelated to the unrequired transactions topic so I should do some further investigation.

  Desktop shortcuts were being copy to /usr/local/share/ instead of /usr/share/. According to the FreeDesktop.org specification (see http://standards.freedesktop.org/menu-spec/latest/ar01s02.html) it should not be a problem since it uses $XDG_DATA_DIRS environment variable, but it does not really work in GNOME. In their help files (see https://developer.gnome.org/integration-guide/stable/desktop-files.html.en) they guide developers to drop desktop files in /usr/share/ or ~/.local/share/.
 I am running CentOS 7, with GNOME and the current directory works just fine for me. I don't object to the change of directory just saying it might not be needed or might be different for different distributions
 @glawrence Although I tested only tested Linux Mint 17.1 (which uses Cinnamon), it seems to be a Gnome related problem. Did you check if there are cached desktop/icon files in your Gnome? (maybe from previous sqlitebrowser installations, dunno)

Also, it is important to note that, after this change, the sqlitebrowser icon just disappeared in my computer. If that happens to someone, just run "sudo gtk-update-icon-cache -f /usr/share/icons/hicolor/" to force the icon cache to update.
 @justinclift Yes, the problem is with the current git master, I did not use the package manager from the distro because it is outdated. Also, I tested the installation with this proposed change, and everything worked as expected.

According to FHS (see http://refspecs.linuxfoundation.org/FHS_2.3/fhs-2.3.html#USRLOCALLOCALHIERARCHY), the correct place to store sqlitebrowser is /usr/local, and according to the FreeDesktop.org specification (see http://standards.freedesktop.org/menu-spec/latest/ar01s02.html) it should be also OK to store desktop files under /usr/local/share if it is listed on $XDG_DATA_DIRS variable (which is usually True).

So sqlitebrowser seems to be following the specification.

But, despite what these specifications says, Linux Mint 17.1 Cinnamon does not show desktop files stored under /usr/local/share in the menu (fortunately I installed the system yesterday, so I am with a clean installation). We still need to confirm if this issue affects other Debian based distros, or just Linux Mint.

Anyway, I am reporting this issue to Cinnamon developers, so we can track the source of it.
 @DiegoQueiroz when I tested this I renamed sqlitebrowser.desktop to sqlitebrowser.xxxx when I did this the menu entry disappeared, when I changed the name back the menu entry returned. So I think this is probably a Mint issue. I don't have another GNOME install to hand, my openSUSE is running KDE.
 I just confirmed that this issue also affects Ubuntu with Gnome (thanks to Professor J. Kinoshita, USP who kindly gave me access to his computer to test), so I think it's safe to say that this problem is not related only with Cinnamon or Linux Mint.
 Hmm, sounds to me like some GNOME installs are adhering to the standard and others are not. So whilst DB4S is doing the right thing, it might be as well to take the pragmatic view and make the change
 Well. If there is a set of systems that do not use
/usr/local/share/applications folder and a set that use it, so we need to
check the OS first and decide based on this.

Anyway, I am still not sure what systems really use
/usr/local/share/applications folder. Although I described it as possible
according to FreeDesktop standard, all tutorials and documentations I can
find around the web say to store .desktop files under
/usr/share/applications.

Diego Queiroz

 @justinclift Do you mean about the hardcoded path? I don't think there is anything wrong with the Makefile, since it ok to copy application files to /usr/local, no?

I'm not sure, but it seems to be also hardcoded somewhere when Gnome is installed (at least on Debian based systems).
 I think the best workaround is to hardcode the path.

I understand it is a bad solution, but it should treated as a workaround, since some systems appear to be checking /usr/share folder only. We won nothing keeping the "right" relative path, if it does not work in Debian-based systems.

Another possible solution is to check if the /etc/debian_version file exists, if so, use the hardcoded path.
 @justinclift just a thought, if problems are related to different base systems, we can check it via running "dpkg" command or "rpm" command to detect the base system (debian or redhat, but for other can be applied too). If cmand returns non-zero code means we are on wrong system. We can use nested if else with it.

But as I can see the problem is related to desktop entry, 
1.  do we update cache after adding file to applications folder?? 
2. Permissions of. desktop file must be set to (acc to my knowledge 755).
3. ~/.local/share/applications is the diectory where only one user can have access to that entry, on the other hand /usr/share/applications will creare a global entry for all users.

For 1. Refer to below commands 

desktop-file-edit
is used to modify an existing desktop file entry.
desktop-file-install
is used to install a new desktop file entry. It is also used to rebuild or modify the MIME-types application database.
desktop-file-validate
is used to verify the integrity of a desktop file.
update-desktop-database
is used to update the MIME-types application database.

  Create a file "header" containing licence header .
Then : 
for file in *.cpp *.h
do
cat header $file > $file.new
mv $file.new $file
done
~     
 Not needed, except (perhaps) in cases where the header is already present in a file you take in whole or in part from some other project. There are arguments for and against per-source-file notices; practice around this issue varies quite widely.
  According to README.md, "DB Browser for SQLite is bi-licensed under the Mozilla Public License Version 2, as well as the GNU General Public License Version 3 or later." - it is not clear if this means that conditions of both licenses must be met at same time or that one or other license must be followed.

  Create Sample Table using "Import/Database from SQL file" function

> CREATE TABLE foo (x DOUBLE);
> INSERT INTO foo VALUES (9e999); -- +Inf
> INSERT INTO foo VALUES (-9e999); -- -Inf
> INSERT INTO foo VALUES (9e999 / 9e999); -- NaN: gets converted to NULL

This foo table has these values

> 'Inf'
> '-Inf'
> 'NULL'

Export foo table to SQL using "Export/Database to SQL file" function. This SQL Statement generates error on "Inf".

> CREATE TABLE foo (x DOUBLE);
> INSERT INTO `foo` VALUES (Inf);
> INSERT INTO `foo` VALUES (-Inf);
> INSERT INTO `foo` VALUES (NULL);

I think that this is right. What do you think about this?

> CREATE TABLE foo (x DOUBLE);
> INSERT INTO `foo` VALUES ('Inf');
> INSERT INTO `foo` VALUES ('-Inf');
> INSERT INTO `foo` VALUES (NULL);

  It would be great if the column order during csv import could be changed. If the order of the columns in the target database doesn't match the source database, swapping the columns around manually is somewhat difficult.
 Well, the problem is that csv import ignores column names in the csv file
and assumes the order is the same. In my situation this was not so. I
resorted to fixing the sql export as fixing the csv file was too much work.
But as a csv importer is already present, a dialog allowing the user to
arrange the csv columns before import would make sense.
 I'm able to change the column order during a csv import in the latest master.
  When exporting the database to SQL with the purpose of importing the data from one of the tables via SQL to another database, it would be extremely helpful if the columns were named in the INSERT statement. This would make the insert work even if the columns were in a different order in the target database (my situation),

I can solve it by replacing the INSERT word like this:

INSERT INTO `SomeData` VALUES (1,34,37,463);
to:
INSERT INTO `SomeData` (col1,col2,col3,col4) VALUES (1,34,37,463);

I would be nice if this tool could do this automatically.

SQLite does not have this limitation:

  BLOB data imported from file is not typed BLOB but TEXT.
We can replicate by following way.
1. create table

``` sql
    CREATE TABLE 'Sample' ('ID' INTEGER, 'Image' BLOB, PRIMARY KEY(ID))
```
1. add new record on "Browse Data" tab
2. update 'Image' data by importing image file(e.g. jpg file) on 'Edit database cell'
3. query type of 'Image' data, and get TEXT type

``` sql
    SELECT typeof(Image) FROM Sample
```

Maybe, the reason of this issue is DBBrowserDB::updateRecord(sqlitedb.cpp) method.
Imported data for update bind by sqlite3_bind_text without reference to actual (or estimated) data type.
 Thanks for response.
Yes, I guess #229 is caused by same problem, too.
 Thanks. That solves my problem, completely.

But, I worry about column that has multiple data type.
Now, we cannot insert TEXT data to BLOB column.
yes, this is the issue @schdub points on PS.

I think that use of such column is not good practice.
But, SQLite accepts such column by right.

For example, if we execute following SQL to last DB,

``` sql
INSERT INTO 'Sample' (ID, Image) Values(2, 'some text');
```

We get text value on Image column.

I think best solution is data type is switched according to 'Edit database cells' dialog.
Maybe, data type should not be decided by column type, but user's decision.

PS : I'm trying such a solution on my local code.

  Running the query:

`SELECT * FROM address WHERE house_number LIKE '%3';`
runs a query like
`SELECT * FROM address WHERE house_number LIKE '20';`

The number that %3 gets turned into seems somewhat random, but usually less than 20.

Note that %1 and %2 are also broken, but %4 and up work.

 @justinclift We rely on there being no alpha padding around the screenshot so we can scale it to fit the application area. This means the screenshots have to be taken without any kind of "fuzzy border" -- or you can remedy this in GIMP/Photoshop. Also, the screenshot is supposed to be what it looks like on Linux :) See http://people.freedesktop.org/~hughsient/appdata/#screenshots for more details; thanks.
 @justinclift Any screenshot is better than no screenshot, but I'd really like the application installer to look sexy and coherent.   There are some issues with the paging arrows in the bottom left.  One thing is just a little confusing at first.  You are doing something that is not typical UI.  I've never seen software that lets you scroll, and also tells you which lines are being displayed in just the viewable window, and also lets you page through the scrollable view.  Once I figured out what was going on, it is actually pretty cool.  But then I found that if I change the window size, then use those paging arrows, they don't give me correct results.  They seem to skip large amounts of records.  I would suggest first, of course, to fix that errant behaviour.  And then maybe add the word 'Viewing' before the range of rows displayed, or something to make it clear the user can either scroll to see more records, or use the arrows to jump scroll.
 V3.5.1
OSX Yosemite 10.10.2
 I think it might be a OS X thing, because I couldn't reproduce on Fedora. Will try on OS X when I get home as well. :)
 Yeah, the buttons are supposed to scroll 100 records up/downwards, no matter the size of the window. So if the window is very small, it will appear to skip a lot of records, but it's just moving the selection by 100 records.
  The arrows in the column headings to indicate sort direction are incorrect.  They are the opposite of what they should be.  An upward facing arrow means the sort is from smaller to bigger (or alphabetic).  A downward facing arrow means the sort is from bigger to smaller (or reverse alphabetic).  
Take a look at the arrows in the column headers of folders on a PC or a Mac, or in Outlook, or any other common software that allows sorting by columns, and you will see they are using them the way I am describing, which is the opposite of how you are.
 ![screen shot 2015-03-19 at 10 03 04 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5605944/6746358/11ddd606-ce84-11e4-948f-348d0863c272.png)
![screen shot 2015-03-19 at 10 03 30 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5605944/6746359/11f58364-ce84-11e4-8e35-23688efddb50.png)
 ![screen shot 2015-03-20 at 5 36 46 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5605944/6751612/2c247f4e-cec3-11e4-8719-f4b73205fc4f.png)
 INT = short for INTEGER it's written full in 'list_id' to make it (synonym) of ROWID

ref. https://www.sqlite.org/lang_createtable.html#rowid
 It is sorting incorrectly for list_id too

![screen shot 2015-03-20 at 6 59 39 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5605944/6752832/b94f72f6-cece-11e4-842a-3b5dad50dabb.png)
 The arrow shows the order you can change the current one to so the opposite of what is the "status quo"

 So this is really a [bug in Qt](https://bugreports.qt.io/browse/QTBUG-38427) on OS X. It also affects older versions like 4.8.5, although it's not mentioned in the bug report.
 The files become clickable if you leave and enter the directory again after changing the filter.
Another workaround is not use the native file dialog. That works, but it will look a little bit weird.
Or perhaps subclass QFileDialog and force a refresh when changing filter, but might be too much for something not so critical.

  Hello,

Start with a new DB and go to SQL tab and execute:

CREATE TABLE customer(
         id INTEGER,
         firstName TEXT,
         middleName TEXT,
         lastName   TEXT,
         address TEXT,
         contactNum TEXT
);

 CREATE TABLE item(
        id INTEGER,
        name TEXT,
        description TEXT
 );

 CREATE TABLE orders(
        id INTEGER,
        customerID INTEGER,
        date TEXT,
        FOREIGN KEY(customerId) REFERENCES customer(id)
 );

 CREATE TABLE item_order(
        id INTEGER,
        orderID INTEGER,
        itemId  INTEGER,
        quantity INTEGER,
        FOREIGN KEY(orderId) REFERENCES orders(Id),
        FOREIGN KEY(itemId) REFERENCES item(Id)
 );

After you execute this, save the db.

Now switch to the "Database structure" tab, and SQLite Browser will simply close!

Now anytime you try to open that DB, the browser crashes!

  After Opening a DB, then Opening an additional DB the Browser should start from the directory where the last Successful Open occurred
 Your default directory will be opened by default. Works for me. Another way is to open one of the last five opened databases.

 --[[z4us|bb--]]
sqlite3 nw.sqb
SQLite version 3.8.8.3 2015-02-25 13:29:11
Enter ".help" for usage hints.
sqlite> select \* from Customers where CustomerID like 'AN%';
ANATR|Ana Trujillo Emparedados y helados|Ana Trujillo|Owner|Avda. de la Constituci√≥n 2222|M√©xico D.F.||05021|Mexico|(5) 555-4729|(5) 555-3745
ANTON|Antonio Moreno Taquer√≠a|Antonio Moreno|Owner|Mataderos  2312|M√©xico D.F.||05023|Mexico|(5) 555-3932|
 I agree with https://github.com/rp- 

Perhaps the uploader used some pre-UTF8 codePage 

To check go to http://mysharepoint.org/Accounting/Lists/Client%20List/AllItems.aspx 
 This is really a problem with the data. In the header of the file it says UTF-8, but the characters are encoded in Windows-1252 or ISO 8859-1. Navicat probably uses one of them as fallback or something. But the specification states that only 3 encodings are valid, namely UTF-8, UTF-16le and UTF-16be.
 Hmm I don't know much about encoding, but it's possible to detect invalid UTF-8 characters, yes. It could then default to some other encoding instead of invalidating them (which is what I think is currently happening). So I think it's doable, however it will probably require a lot of changes.
 It's indeed rather tricky to make an educated guess. There are so many ways to encode/encrypt data. Navicat was lucky since 8859-1 (Latin-1?) is (almost was) one of the most common. If the developers are able to detect let's say four of five of those, they deserve a prize. I don't think it's worth all the effort though besides an increase in size...
  Allow copying of info in About DB Browser, so it can be copied and pasted when sending bug and enhancement requests 351, 486, SQLCipher386 version and 351, 486, SQLite 3.8.8.2.

Also should in SQLCipher Version mention OPENSSL version?

 @atoregozh can you try the nightly build tomorrow to see if the issue is fixed? The problem was that some of the values end with the CR character ('\r'), which was not escaped when exporting. Because we now accept it as a line ending character, I've changed the code to also escape them.

 Hmm I think that folder it's hidden by default.
Run this on Terminal:
`mkdir ~/Downloads/cores`
then
`cp -R /cores/* ~/Downloads/cores`
Then check your Downloads folder, a new `cores` folder should be there with the interesting files. If you could upload them somewhere and send the link it would be great :smiley:

  Hi,
it would be very relieving if there was the possiblity to store/load table definitions which then can be applied to tables which are imported from csv files. 
It suits to my use case where a bunch of people are managing data in a csv file on google drive (since concurrent access is possible) which then needs to be imported in a certain sqlite databse. The data belongs to a certain table of that databse but everytime I import the csv file I also need to modify the table definition fitting to the original definition (and of course rename that table and remove the older table, to perform the replacement). This is a tedious progress :(
One alternative solution would be to somehow enable importing of csv data directly in a already existing table (column name matches needs to be checked and eventually duplicates omitted of course).
 You can use the first line of a CSV-file as table definition with column names. No need to worry about types since SQLite does it "autodramaticcaly"

https://www.sqlite.org/cli.html#csv

 @rp standard line ending of Mac is LF since the beginning of 21st century :-)

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Newline#Representations

Perhaps for next milestone you may create an option in the menu where users may choose the EOL symbol of their system?
 I forgot to add that this bug wasn't just for csv files but also for text files as well. When I tried importing a text file, I had the same 1 row with many fields instead of several rows and several columns.
 @atoregozh could you provide a sample file?
The code works with LF and CRLF line endings, even if the file uses both. However, as @rp- mentioned it doesn't work with the old CR line endings, so perhaps your editor has that as default. TextWrangler, for instance, offers the ability to save with the three.
 @samir-aguiar I'm not sure how to upload the file in this discussion but you can download "handle.csv" from here: http://web.mit.edu/aizhan/www/twitter_api_workshop/docs/

Also, could anyone enlighten me and explain how to know what line endings were used in a csv file? In order to create the file, I just manually typed the rows in excel and saved it As .csv file.
 Yes, that's using only CR.
The easiest way to check is to use a editor that shows that information (Sublime Text does and IIRC so does TextWrangler) or open Terminal and run:
`$ file <filename>`

The output for your file is:
`handle.csv: ASCII text, with CR line terminators`

However, apparently this is a bug (or a feature?) of Office for Mac when exporting to CSV. I don't know if there is a setting to change that, but you can convert the line endings to a more common format by using a text editor that supports it (like the ones I've mentioned) or checking [here](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Newline#Conversion_utilities) for some command line tricks.
 Hmm I did some searches and apparently there's no setting in Excel to change that. Don't know why would they choose this behavior though...

Anyway, from what I've seen it would be easy to also accept only CR as the line-ending character. What do you guys think?
 @samir-aguiar thanks! that did fix it, but why would the sqlitebrowser code not work with CR endings? because they are "old" and no one uses them? I guess there would be some people who would view their csv files using excel, and if they save it, the file will be saved with CR endings.
 @samir-aguiar this might be off-topic re sqlitebrowser issue: I used both options of checking the line endings you suggested and terminal does say that I have CR endings, but when I opened the file in Sublime Text2, and viewed the file's line endings, the tick was on Mac OS9 and not on Windows. Would that imply that sublime text is not recognizing the correct line endings?
 @atoregozh It doesn't work probably because they are not common and are not accepted by the RFC, but I don't know for sure, I've only recently joined the project :smile: 

As for Sublime, it's showing correctly: Windows uses CRLF. CR was used by Mac OS until version 9 and starting with OS X it switched to Unix line endings (LF).
 I think it should be working now.
By mistake I referenced and commented in the other CSV issue... it's right next to this one :smile: 

@justinclift we already cover cases where there's a non-empty string between the separators :wink: 
 @samir-aguiar great you already added support for CR? Does that mean that I should reinstall sqlitebrowser? Again off-topic: I actually have Mac OS X, why would sublime show that I have Mac OS 9 and thus I have CR endings? 
 @atoregozh Yeah, you can test tomorrow with the nightly build. It won't be in the stable version though -- if everything works out it should be in the next release.
The line endings are actually part of the file contents, so Sublime is telling you that this file uses the character '\r' to indicate a line break. OS 9 text editors added that character to the files when saving them to represent a newline. OS X editors now add '\n' instead, which is the same character used by Unix systems. So Sublime just shows what character(s) the file contains that represent a newline, along with the most common OS family to first set that character as the default for files read/written by that OS family tools.
 @justinclift sure I'll install it later tonight. Per link you gave, what's the difference between sqlitebrowser vs sqlitebrowser-cipher? And which one should I install (sorry maybe that's not a relevant question)

  As a non-native English speaker I don't understand "a real to have" as if 'rea;' is a noun as well?

On a more serious and on-topic note: increasing user-friendliness is always a good plan for any software OS, commercial or something in between.
  The registry key HKCU/Software/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/checkversion/disable doesn't seem to have any effect for every release I've been using in the last year -- the program always checks and always throws an annoying popup if something new is available. Clicking "Don't show again" does seem to change the registry value, so I guess that works. Just kind of annoying.

Also, it'd be nice if you used a flat file (.sqlitebrowser perhaps?) or INI file in the AppData folder for user selected preferences to make installations more portable. I don't mind the last window size and version number being in the registry, but I'd prefer to be able to backup chosen preferences without exporting registry keys.
 Great response; thanks for the update.

The INI thing was just me nitpicking after realizing that the checkversion flag was in the registry. It's always helpful if user preferences are easy to migrate to another system; registry keys/hierarchy are usually not published by developers. Sqlitebrowser is very light on user preferences, but it's a burden with some Windows programs. I didn't realize that Qt libs are handling configuration persistence, so I understand now that it's not worth the hassle. Thanks for looking into it. 

Keep up the good work!

  Table:

BEGIN TRANSACTION;
CREATE TABLE `table1` (
    `Field1`    TEXT
);
INSERT INTO `table1` VALUES ('testing');
INSERT INTO `table1` VALUES ('123');
INSERT INTO `table1` VALUES ('87654');
COMMIT;

Query:
select \* from table1 where CAST(Field1 AS Text) LIKE '%2%'

1 Rows returned from: select \* from table1 where CAST(Field1 AS Text) LIKE '2%' (took %3ms)

The % in front of '2%' is dropped and no results are returned.

Ver 3.5.1
SQlLite version: 3.8.8.2
 Did another test and ran from the sqlite3 cli - working fine.

sqlite> select \* from table1 where CAST(Field1 AS Text) LIKE '%2%';
123

Running Win 10 Preview build if it helps. (10.0.9926) - 64 bit.
 Some more info which hopefully points to where the problem could be:

like '%6% - working.
like '%3% - is changed to like '6%';
like '%2%'; - is changed to like '2%';
like '%1%'; - is changed to like '7%';

Very odd. :) Also tried on Win7 - same issue so it doesnt seem to be OS related.
 I think I've got it. :smile: 
The "%2" was being seen as a placeholder by QString::arg() when doing replacements.
 Great stuff. That was quick - thanks. Will check in the nightly tomorrow.
 Tested on the latest nightly. Now working. Thanks a lot guys!

It is as the title suggests, null value is become empty string when I tried to import from CSV file which has a null value (etc,10,,10,). I tried to import using other SQLite app the null value (etc,10,,10,) become <i>NULL</i> instead of empty string. Oh, and the preview when importing a CSV file (after choosing the CSV file) btw, also display an empty string rather than <i>NULL</i> value. I have already checked when I import using SQLitebrowser and open with another app it becomes empty string for the <i>NULL</i> value.

I don't know if this is a feature or not, but maybe you can add an option when trying to import you give a checkbox and textfield for the <i>NULL</i> value, so when the user check the box but leaves the textfield empty the <i>NULL</i> value becomes empty string or the value of the textfield if any. And when the user does not check the box, the textfield is disabled and the null value becomes <i>NULL</i> when imported.

  In addition, the new tab that I created also holds the "default location" option as suggested by @MKleusberg.

I've also renamed the Chinese translation file because the program was not finding it (see [QTranslator::load()](http://doc.qt.io/qt-5/qtranslator.html#load) for the patterns used when looking for translation files).
 Hmm the initial code had a "System Language" entry, but I removed it for some reason I cannot recall now. But I'll put it back, I think it makes sense to have it.
 (closed by accident) :grin: 
 Oh, I remember the doubts I had when I removed this option.
Tell me what you think:
I thought about two cases, one where the user's locale has a corresponding translation and the other where it doesn't.

For the first case, supposing that the language is German, I thought that it would be more informative to just show "German" selected instead of "System Language", because there's a German translation and the application would be in German. For the second case, I thought that showing "English" right away instead of "System Language" would also be more informative because it indicates clearly that there's no translation in the user's language and that it has defaulted to English.

And the language names will always be in English. This was meant to prevent cases where the users couldn't find their languages because the program somehow started in a strange language (perhaps it would be better to show the name of the languages in the native version?).

(BTW, I have to add some comments to the code about this).
 @rp- I reverted the changes but unfortunately using the native version turned out to be a no can do. That would break compatibility as the methods were introduced in Qt 4.8.

  The argument count (first parameter) is a reference, and thus must be kept alive for the whole lifetime of the QCoreApplication instance, as also the Qt apidocs say.

Also properly create a "string array" for the actual args, instead of badly casting a string to that.

This fixes sporadic crashes in this test, for example as seen for some architectures in the Debian build of 3.4.0: https://buildd.debian.org/status/logs.php?pkg=sqlitebrowser&ver=3.4.0-1 & http://buildd.debian-ports.org/status/logs.php?pkg=sqlitebrowser&ver=3.4.0-1 (click on texts in the "Result" column to see the logs).
  I've noticed that the types available when creating a new field in a table are limited.  Is there any goal to support datetime?
 SQLite does not have a storage class set aside for storing dates and/or times.
  "Error adding new record: near ")":syntax error". I don't know where to search the problem.
Please make a repair function, fix this or show the position of the illegal record. https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/13673400/test.sqlite

After "compact database" the button "write changes" is disabled.
 The problem is probably in your schema SQLite does not recognize the types 'BOOL' nor 'DATETIME

sqlite> select \* from spieleliste;
Name                                      Hersteller    Genre             F  installiert       Pl  durchgespiel  Sonstiges /   Bewertung   Erscheinungsdatum

---

Command & Conquer - Die ersten 10 Jahre   EA / Westwoo  Strategie         O  1                 PC  kA  
Command & Conquer 3                       EA            Strategie         O  1                 PC  kA  
Portal                                                  Knobel / Action   S  0                 PC  kA  
sqlite> 

"installiert" BOOL DEFAULT (0) 
"Erscheinungsdatum" DATETIME

See https://www.sqlite.org/lang_createtable.html#tablecoldef
 and https://www.sqlite.org/datatype3.html#affinity

 Well, I guess it's done.
The system and default language (when the former is not American English) now have a suffix appended to them and the chosen language stays on top.

I've done a lot of testing with those flags and couldn't get them to look nice when building with small resolutions, so I've just built 320x240 images and manually rescaled them with Gimp.

I've tested under OSX and Linux, but I couldn't find a setting that would make it look aligned with the QLineEdit above it, so I increased the minimum size of the QLineEdit.  Done with a patch for translations: using Datadir (/usr/local/share/sqlitebrowser/) when installing instead of binary dir (/usr/local/bin).

Waiting for approval https://bugs.freebsd.org/bugzilla/show_bug.cgi?id=197253
 Hello, I do not think that this patch is to be applied in the code base, it was necessary for me to make a clean install on FreeBSD. Nevertheless, it may be possible to perform a modification of the code to be compatible with all systems. Indeed, SqliteBrowser search the directory "translations" where it is installed (local dir or install dir /usr/[local]/bin). 
Now it is in my view a mistake when it is installed, it must be in the directory of application-related documents (/usr/[local]/share). If the patch is to be applied, it should probably create a variable in CMake replacing %%DATADIR%% the right path (/usr/share/sqlitebrowser, /usr/local/share/ sqlitebrowser/, ./ etc.)
What did you think?

  <pre>
  CREATE TABLE "a" (

  );
  </pre>

  Please consider writing and installing an AppData file with the application description and some screenshots, else sqlitebrowser looks really bad in the GNOME and KDE Software Centers. We'd love to showcase more applications, but without the extra data file we can't.

See http://people.freedesktop.org/~hughsient/appdata/ for details; thanks!

Richard
 I believe you can do this yourself via a pull request, so why not do it yourself, you seem to know what is required?

Rather than use developer time on this, I reckon someone else could help with this, if you. I would be happy to give it a go if there are no other volunteers and it is agreed this is a good thing.
 Right, I could indeed do a pull request. There are three main reason I've asked upstream maintainers to do this rather than just submit something myself:
- You probably know the application inside out, e.g. how to take screenshots to fully show off all the features that would take many weeks of me using to find out.
- You can update the description and screenshots yourself when you add new features or port the UI to a new toolkit.
- Time; so far 473 upstream projects[1] have written AppData files, and I simple can't scale myself to do all that.

Also, according to https://alt.fedoraproject.org/pub/alt/screenshots/f22/matrix.html sqlitebrowser doesn't have any keywords in the .desktop file, which means that searching for it in the software center is going to be harder.

[1] https://alt.fedoraproject.org/pub/alt/screenshots/f22/status.html -- warning, BIG HTML page
 Yes, ok, I will give this a go. Do you have a target date for the next release?
 I have created a pull request, please see my comments in the request as I believe it needs to be checked.

@hughsie could you take a quick look too please?

  Hello,

Before:

    key_remote_jid,
    key_from_me,
    key_id
)

(
    key_remote_jid, ASC,
    key_from_me, ASC,

  I know that the preferred method for compiling is cmake, but I tried to compile through Qt Creator with qmake and had problems with the libraries because I was using shadow build.
Besides, of course, disabling shadow build, another solution I found was to use the OUT_PWD variable instead of the PWD variable when declaring the libs path. The code looks like this:

``` qmake
LIBPATH_QHEXEDIT=$$OUT_PWD/../libs/qhexedit
LIBPATH_ANTLR=$$OUT_PWD/../libs/antlr-2.7.7
LIBPATH_QCUSTOMPLOT=$$OUT_PWD/../libs/qcustomplot-source
```

This variable is equal to PWD when shadow build is disabled and equals to the build directory when it‚Äôs enabled, so it should keep the current behavior but add support for shadow build.

Of course, although it worked on OS 10.9.5 with Qt 5.4, I‚Äôm not sure whether this variable is always valid in every version. This would require some checking (if empty, if valid, etc.).

Anyway, what are your thoughts about this change?
 If this works only for higher versions of OSX (I for one have 10.6.8) DB browser for SQLite can't claim anymore to be compatible for 10.6 thru 10.10; in and of itself not a bad idea. Happy holidays y'all!
 The age old problem of moving forward and remaining backward compatible, which has no simple answer! Personally I would vote for sticking with one release branch, ie not maintaining multiple major versions, moving forward to Qt5.4 etc and maybe leaving an old release available for those that need it. Allowing easy building in QtCreator might actually help with development and new comers getting started.
 @MKleusberg if everything is good, here it goes :)

 SQLite by default uses 64-bit: https://www.sqlite.org/lang_createtable.html

<quote>
ROWIDs and the INTEGER PRIMARY KEY

Except for WITHOUT ROWID tables, all rows within SQLite tables have a 64-bit signed integer key that uniquely identifies the row within its table. This integer is usually called the "rowid". 
</quote>
 @MKleusberg ok, spanx, I'll test this out later today then =) Or a little later then that =/
 Seem to work fine, GJ.
  The problem is that the CMakeLists.txt for the unit tests doesn't include the PreferencesDialog class files. I think that including them there would probably cause issues because they include the `ui_PreferencesDialog.h`, which is automatically generated.

I don't know if there are better options, but what could be done is either pass the NULL color to the model once it's set or surround the code that calls `PreferencesDialog::getSettingsValue()` with preprocessor checks, where the checked macro would be defined in the unit tests CMakeLists.txt (e.g. check if this is not a unit test build).

But the code to change the color worked nice here. :+1: 

(A fix that I propose: according to the [Qt documentation](http://qt-project.org/doc/qt-4.8/qt.html#ItemDataRole-enum), BackgroundColorRole is obsolete and BackgroundRole should be used instead.)

  Hola,
¬øhay alguna forma de introducir funciones como valor DEFAULT para un campo?
Lo que necesito es el valor de hora UTC como entero con este esquema:

```
 `timestamp` INTEGER NOT NULL DEFAULT (strftime('%s','now'))
```

veo el c√≥digo y parece que no es posible.

Ser√≠a √∫til una ampliaci√≥n que aceptara esta funcionalidad.
Por ejemplo, Visual FoxPro usa el "=()" para reconocer funciones:

```
=(expresion)
```

en mi caso en particular podr√≠a entrar

```
=(strftime('%s','now'))
```

Un cambio en EditTableDialog.cpp (lineas 347 y 348) podr√≠a ser este:

```
QChar ch = new_value.trimmed().at(0);
if(!( (ch == '\'' || ch == '"') && new_value.trimmed().endsWith(ch)  ))
{
    if ( ch == '=' && new_value.trimmed().endsWith(')') && new_value.trimmed().at(1) == '(' )
          new_value = new_value.trimmed().substring_function_I_dont_know(1);  // get rid of '='
    else
    //...
```

No conozco QT ni C++, pero es algo as√≠.

He modificado el formato para darle claridad al c√≥digo, tambi√©n emparejo comillas simples con simples y dobles con dobles (la implementaci√≥n actual acepta entradas como 'mydefault").

Bueno, la idea est√° all√≠.
Gracias.
 Hello
(sorry, my "english" is very poor, i edited my post without backtick quotes, for google compat)

DB Browser (DBB) supports default values, i.e. values as defaults, but NOT functions (expressions).

In the example I post, the column name is "timestamp", type INT, and must defaults to the current datetime in UTC, _as integer_. Because type affinity, SQLite converts this expression to integer with this SQL form:

```
CREATE TABLE foo (
timestamp INTEGER NOT NULL DEFAULT (strftime('%s','now'))
....
```

But, when I enter the expression `strftime('%s', 'now')` in the "default" column of the DBB **Table Editor** (not in the "Execute SQL" tab), DBB converts this to the text `'(strftime(''%s'', ''now''))'` and then generate this SQL:

```
CREATE TABLE foo (
timestamp INTEGER NOT NULL DEFAULT '(strftime(''%s'',''now''))'
```

of course, SQLite replaces the timestamp field with the literal string (strftime('%s','now')), and not the _numeric_ value returned by this function.

I hope I have been clear,
thanks.
 MKleusberg, justinclift
Sorry, perd√≥n por la demora.
Acabo de probar la versi√≥n en desarrollo de 13-Dec-2014 02:14
Tiene un peque√±o detalle: al abrir la tabla para _modificar_ la estructura, el signo '=' no se lee. Si el esquema se guarda sin editar un campo calculado, el campo se mantiene; pero si se modifica, hay que agregarle el caracter '=' nuevamente para que el editor lo reconozca como una funci√≥n.
Aparte de eso, que supongo ser√° sencillo de corregir, al parecer funciona perfecto :thumbsup:

 Hi.
If you mean that it is necessary "=()" to indicate that the default value is a function, I think so.
The point is: When the schema (of the table) is re-open for edit, the SB analyzer does not recover the equal sign, and if the developer changes the default field, he/she must reenter the sign for the analyzer recognizes the changed default value as a function. It is not serious, but it is uncomfortable.
The first time it happened to me I did a quick change to the default for the strtest field, and the query did not returns the results I expected. When I checked the schema, I realized that SB had kept the default value as text, and I to re-edit the schema to add the '=' and remove the duplicate quotes.
 ok, I test it tomorrow
 @justinclift / @MKleusberg, it is working like a charm :+1:

  KEY "topic_id" ("topic_id"),
  KEY "poster_ip" ("poster_ip"),
  KEY "poster_id" ("poster_id"),
  KEY "post_username" ("post_username"),
  KEY "tid_post_time" ("topic_id","post_time"),
  KEY "post_visibility" ("post_visibility")
) AUTO_INCREMENT=51587 ;
```

It would help if some of the example screens had empty strings as well as NULL so we can compare.

Personally I would like to see something in the NULL column, maybe this: {NULL}
Or some other brackets, and shading also helps but I am not sure I want this leaping out at me in red, it is not the most important thing on the screen and is certainly not a crisis!

I guess in an ideal world we would have the following, roughly, in Preferences:
- show NULL in results
- text to indicate NULL
- foreground colour
- background colour

That way we can all be happy, some with their bold red, others more subtle and others keeping the status quo.

 Something that I thought:

- On Windows it would download and run the installer, that should remove the previous version and install the new files.

- On Linux I think the package manager should take care of this.

 Just a status update: I've managed to integrate Sparkle into the app, but not without adding code. I needed to add a small Object-C++ source file to call the Sparkle methods. Sparkle also requires packages to be signed and does a bunch of checks to avoid tampered updates so the .plist files required some changes as well.
Anyway, it was just the basic integration; I still need to look at Sparkle's code to see what options they provide and run more tests.

  Opening a db file with a table like this crashes SqliteBrowser:

``` sql
CREATE TABLE table1 (
    id1,
    id2,
    PRIMARY KEY(id1, id2)
) WITHOUT ROWID;
```

The crash happens at `sqlitetypes.cpp:391`. That line fails because `tab.findPk()` returns `-1` as it can't find a single primary key column.

``` cpp
Table CreateTableWalker::table()
{
    Table tab("");

    if( m_root ) //CREATE TABLE
    {
        ‚Ä¶
        while(s != antlr::nullAST)
        {
            // Is this a 'without rowid' definiton?
            if(s->getType() != sqlite3TokenTypes::WITHOUT)
            {
                ‚Ä¶
            } else {
                tab.setRowidColumn(tab.fields().at(tab.findPk())->name()); // <-- Line 391, Probably faulty
            }
        }
    }

    return tab;
}
```

```

1   setRowidColumn  sqlitetypes.h   97  0x4c1506

18  ??  /usr/lib/libglib-2.0.so.0       0x7ffff559df68  
19  g_main_context_iteration    /usr/lib/libglib-2.0.so.0       0x7ffff559e01c  
20  QEventDispatcherGlib::processEvents(QFlags<QEventLoop::ProcessEventsFlag>)  /usr/lib/libQtCore.so.4     0x7ffff6ab62a5              
```
 Looks like it crashes with a table like this as well:

``` sql
CREATE TABLE table1 (
    id1,
    PRIMARY KEY(id1)
) WITHOUT ROWID;
```

This however works:

``` sql
CREATE TABLE table1 (
    id1 PRIMARY KEY
) WITHOUT ROWID;
```
 A lot of the code seems to depend on the existence of a single column primary key. When there's no rowid, the software kind of emulates one using the primary key (it only supports integer primary keys because of that behaviour). This obviously fails with composite primary keys.

I reckon quite some code would have to be redesigned in order to fix this issue.
 So @justinclift unfortunately I don't have enough understanding of SqliteBrowser's inner workings to efficiently tackle this. This may be better done by someone who's familiar with the codebase, as it doesn't look like a simple fix.

I hope I could help you by pointing out the source of the malfunction.
 I tried 3.4.0 on Windows (two different machines) and Linux, and the current master branch @1ce33792c534f7228fd888d0b27f5abdc51c8c28 on Linux.

Hm‚Ä¶ Are you sure you used a table having without rowid _and_ a multi-column primary key? As far as I can see, the code doesn't handle this case at all.
 Weird‚Ä¶ Now I can't reproduce it with the examples I posted any more. I still have a db file that crashes though, I'll see if I can strip it.
 So I can't reproduce the crash with my examples any more. The following table however still crashes:

``` sql
CREATE TABLE test (
    key TEXT NOT NULL,
    value TEXT NOT NULL, 
    PRIMARY KEY(key)
) WITHOUT ROWID;
```

That's most likely due to the keyword `key` being used without quotes. The following variations work:

``` sql
CREATE TABLE test (
    key TEXT NOT NULL PRIMARY KEY,
    value TEXT NOT NULL
) WITHOUT ROWID;
```

``` sql
CREATE TABLE test (
    key TEXT NOT NULL,
    value TEXT NOT NULL, 
    PRIMARY KEY(key)
);
```
 Yes that fixed it. I'm still sure I had crashes with the first examples I posted, but the last one is fixed, and I can't reproduce the others. Thanks!

  Every time I start the app, I get a new version available even though I've clicked "Don't show again"

  This is a feature request to allow Insert/Update/Delete user interface capability for Views on Browse Data tab.

Views are normally read-only in SQLite, however, SQLite supports using triggers on Views, which handle the write operations attempted against the View. When this is the case, the absence of a user interface for editing the view means you have to write SQL code to do so.

To avoid confusion, you might consider interrogating existing triggers for an "...INSTEAD OF [INSERT/UPDATE/DELETE] on <Viewname>..." trigger to determine what user interface options to expose. But if this is too complex, it might just be better to expose the options and return the result from the database engine, whether that's an error (because the view is read-only and doesn't have a trigger for the action) or otherwise. Of course this may conflict with your easy-to-use design philosophy (some users might dislike having the user interface indicate that edits are possible when they are not), in which case I guess the enhancement should be rejected.
 It is been two Years, can we reopen this issue? 

Consider this database: 

```
BEGIN TRANSACTION;
CREATE TABLE Foo (a, b, c);
INSERT INTO `Foo` (a,b,c) VALUES (1,2,3);
CREATE TRIGGER update_bar
INSTEAD OF UPDATE OF a ON Bar
BEGIN
  UPDATE Foo SET a = NEW.a
  WHERE b=NEW.b;
END;
CREATE VIEW Bar AS SELECT a, b FROM Foo ORDER BY b;
COMMIT;
```

With `sqlite3` It is legit to write: 

```
UPDATE Bar SET a = 23 WHERE b = 2;
```

However, it is not possible to do it so on a View on `DB Browser for SQLite`. 

It would be a huge plus for me.  What amount of work this feature would represent? What are the concerned files? If I wanna build DB Browser for SQLite on Windows is there a VS project? It's tough, but well documented ^^ Great!   Wooh that's nice. I should give a try  Hi,

I've been using your SQLite Browser software for about some months and just updated to your new program version. Generally I enjoy your software a lot, but recently I've been a bit disappointed about editing options for views:

Your new program version shows the CREATE VIEW SQL on "Database Structure" tab, but doesn't allow to copy or edit it like in your previous versions. I just wanted to copy the SQL I've recently used for creating a view to my clipboard or something like that.

I would suggest you to implement a context menu option "CREATE TO" (similar to SQL Server) that creates a SQL file with CREATE VIEW SQL. Alternatively you could add options "Copy CREATE VIEW to Clipboard" or "Copy CREATE VIEW to new Query Tab".

Kind regards

Marco Tr√∂ster

  some items are very long, such as "Schema" in "Database Structure" tab, items in "Browse Data" tab.
 :smiley: yes, it's better now with 3.4.0. Thanks. But maybe "tooltip" can make it much more better?
 Here is what I mean for "Database Structure" tab. Just change `role == Qt::DisplayRole` to `role == Qt::DisplayRole || role == Qt::ToolTipRole`. That's the tooltip I mean. Sorry for my bad English. :smiley: 

``` cpp
QVariant DbStructureModel::data(const QModelIndex& index, int role) const
{
    if(!index.isValid())
    return QVariant();
    // Get the item the index points at
    QTreeWidgetItem* item = static_cast<QTreeWidgetItem*>(index.internalPointer());
    // Depending on the role either return the text or the icon
    if(role == Qt::DisplayRole)
        return PreferencesDialog::getSettingsValue("db", "hideschemalinebreaks").toBool() ? item->text(index.column()).replace("\n", " ") : item->text(index.column());
    else if(role == Qt::DecorationRole)
        return item->icon(index.column());
    else
        return QVariant();
}
```
 That's what I need. Thanks a lot!! :+1:

  I want to export a reference table from a development environment and import it into the production database.

When I export a TEXT field that contains a string that can be interpreted as a number it is exported without quotation marks. Unfortunately that means that leading '0' characters are lost when I execute the resulting SQL to import it again. The string is changed. 

Example of an exported table below. Note: the sensor_id column is TEXT and the value in the first row is '0000000000000001', but during the export the quotation marks are lost and during a subsequent import (executing the SQL) the value changes to '1', which is a very different string. The second row works fine, since it has the string '28C078480500001B' properly within quotation marks.
CREATE TABLE "sensor_descr" (
        `sensor_id`     TEXT,
        `sensor_descr`  TEXT,
        `sensor_nick`   TEXT
);
INSERT INTO `sensor_descr` VALUES(0000000000000001,'Broken Example','broken');
INSERT INTO `sensor_descr` VALUES('28C078480500001B','Working Example','works');
COMMIT;

This problem occurs both in version 3.0.2 that is available in the OpenSuse repository and in the latest source downloaded and compiled from scratch just now (23rd Oct 2014). 
 Thanks a lot for looking into this so quickly. That's a good motivation to keep putting effort into meaningful bug reports. Thanks for a great little tool! 
    While editing a table definition, I set a default value and later I wanted to stop using that default value and deleted the content of it, but there's no way to "clear" the default flag, it continues using the DEFAULT clause with empty string as default value. I understand that under determined conditions you could need a empty string value as default, but what if you want to remove that default value?

I see two solutions:
- a new flag column should be added to determine if the user wants to use the default value (and activate it automatically if a default value is added, and stop using the default flag when it's unchecked
- add a context menu so you can revert the default value to undefined via right click over the field

Any other solution is welcome, of course :) I am just brainstorming a little

Workaround: remove the field and add it again (it's not much info to remember, but it's a little bothering if you have data on the table :)
 I think this issue can be flagged as enhancement
 Sure, will try along the weekend
Cheers

 Hi

I come back to you with a long time later after the request. I am very sorry, I have been busy and forgot to look after this.

So, to remind the request was to create a simple form view for SQLite browser.

I spoke a bout Glom (Gnome) and Bento (Mac OS X).

They are working almost the same way, but with a simpler way for Bento with a little more graphic features, so I made screenshots of it with Skitch that let me comment them.
Bento has been discontinued, and Mac users are angry about this FileMaker decision, it was also an SQLite based database set, so a Bento database could maybe even imported in SQLite browser.
It could so fill the need, and also give a mire powerful free product available as a multi-plateforme On Linux, Mac and Windows. Glom for Windows is outdated, the Mac version needs to compiled with Mac Ports, it is unstable and not easy at all ‚Ä¶
SQLite browser comes there has a better simple product and powerful anyway. It has a nice GUI, and it is very stable and easy to use or to install. So it could be the way to make everybody happy.

The idea is to have a simple view form to manage the datas and having a GUI which is simple and pleasant to enter the datas for the end user.
It should be possible to organize easily the way the fields are displayed and which ones could be visible.
It should be able to manage multiple forms.
It shouldn't let you manage complex features.

you can contact me for questions.

There are available as a download in here, the link will remain available for 15 days from now.
http://freebox-aymeric.no-ip.org/share/tFVcEKqNG4GqE00e/

Best regards

M-Rick

Steve
 Hi, no sorry it doesn't fix the issue. Ignore what I said originally though. After looking at it again I think  it's actually just the second issue I mentioned, all other faults updating the table seem to stem from that.

When opening a table sqlitebrowser adds single quotes to default values: adding a second pair of single quotes if they exist already. I don't know how things work under the hood yet but if sql is being executed it's failing because of the extra single quotes ( eg. DEFAULT ''any data''), giving a binary data error.

Removing the default value or it's original quotes _fixes_ the sql generated so the table can be updated.

Should I delete the misleading info from the OP? 
 Hi, yep, I can do that :)
 Hi, the latest build fixes this issue. However a new problem has been introduced. If you delete a default value then the SQL generated still includes the _DEFAULT_ keyword and an empty value, for columns that have had default values removed. 

CREATE TABLE `TestTable` (
    `No`    TEXT,
    `Nationality`   TEXT DEFAULT '',
    `Position`  TEXT,
    `Firstname` TEXT DEFAULT '',
    `Surname`   TEXT,
    `Loan`  TEXT,
    `asde`  INTEGER DEFAULT ''
);.

In the textbox that had the default value removed, empty single quotes are inserted by the app.

---

On writing the changes and opening the table for modification again, not all the default values have been persisted...

CREATE TABLE `TestTable` (
    `No`    TEXT,
    `Nationality`   TEXT DEFAULT '',
    `Position`  TEXT,
    _`Firstname`    TEXT, missing default_
    `Surname`   TEXT,
    `Loan`  TEXT,
    `asde`  INTEGER DEFAULT ''
);

As you can see, _Firstname_ is missing the app generated default.

  The discussion on this reminded me of Python, so I have read https://docs.python.org/3/library/csv.html and they refer to the same RFC4180 from IETF, so that's a good start. However they have an Excel dialect, so clearly acknowledge that you have to do stuff differently with Excel. This might be a useful reference when investigating this issue.
 Yes, so my guess is you would have an initial choice of "Standard CSV", "MS Excel Compatible", "Custom", where the custom option allows you to change delimiter, row terminator, etc for those that need it and the first two are easy for most people.

Oh and last I looked when numbers get over 15 digits Excel truncates, so you might need to handle that twist!

Sorry if it seems like I am being a pain but I have had pain in the past so just sharing my experience to hopefully benefit all. For me Python is a good place to look as it is cross platform and well established.
 Guys, it‚Äôs your call but I think keeping things simple and not overdoing it would be a wise strategy.
- ```
       First and foremost the goal should be producing the same default result as sqlite3 does ‚Äì that is the reference most people would expect
  ```
- ```
       I did not experience Excel breaking the standard CSV, the only problem I ever encountered is that Excel does not auto-detect 64 bit Integers correctly, it treats them as Double. For these cases you can do a custom import in Excel.
  ```
- ```
       The 15 digits truncation may only happen with manually created content ‚Äì if you export a double and read it back in that problem does not exist.
  ```
- ```
       The double quote character is defined as ‚Äú, so you don‚Äôt really need to have a selection box for it if you elect to make them optional (means only use them when necessary for the field content)
  ```
- ```
       Same goes for line ending. Just stick to CRLF.
  ```

Thanks

Jens
