  I would like to have a Date field, but it's not possible, as the types are limited to these on the combobox

Need custom types, please!!
 SQLite does not need a field with date affinity. It's either edited and text like e.g.  '2014-09-20' or numeric (int if you prefer) 20140920. or even epoch. 

All about it is in http://sqlite.org/lang_datefunc.html

Perhaps the developers of this awesome browser are willing if they have time to introduce some helping hand for you, but there are more issues with a certain form of priority. 
 I know how data types work in SQLite, the thing is that my database engine uses the field type to know how to treat/convert types to native data

Allowing you to write the field type instead of provide a non editable combobox with fixed values is not a big change at all

Priorities are relative to the importance of the problem to each one, and for me this has a certain form of priority. I also know that I have different workarounds to address this, but aren't straightforward at all
 It's curious because on version 2, the product had a [...] button to add custom types! so seems that this feature was dropped somewhere :)

About adding it myself, I feel a little lost with the used tools, I already downloaded the code and QTCreator, but couldn't make it compile, need to investigate a little. I have two long holiday weeks ahead, so I will consider it if I can fight against this laziness :D

 I am not at home, coming back con Tuesday. I will validate it on the latest
night build as soon as I am back and let you know

  It appears that the table export to CSV builds the export file content first in RAM before writing it to the specified file. If the table is very large the process is hitting the 2GB RAM limit of Windows 32bit applications. Then it crashes. No file gets written at all.
 Where do I find the nightly builds?
 Ok, I did run the test and the crash is resolved. Monitored the memory usage in task manager all looks good.

However, I see now a different problem: All fields regardless of actual column type are exported as text, means in ‚Äúquotes‚Äù. That could cause trouble when reimporting the generated file in other tools, e.g. Excel but also increases file size substantially. In my case the same export run with sqlite3.exe produces a 341MB csv file while using sqlitebrowser produces 420MB. Other than that the content appears identical.

Example:

Sqlite3:
1,0,10.1349167,48.0175202,2.758584499,-0.0005592033267,10.1414681,48.01049,2.500045538,0.0,924.6688232,0.0005592033267,1,9,0
1,1,10.1414681,48.01049,2.5000453,0.0,10.1471049,48.0047975,2.675153971,0.0004602147965,760.9866943,0.0004602147965,1,9,0

Sqlitebrowser:
"1","0","10.1349167","48.0175202","2.758584499","-0.0005592033267","10.1414681","48.01049","2.500045538","0.0","924.6688232","0.0005592033267","1","9","0"
"1","1","10.1414681","48.01049","2.5000453","0.0","10.1471049","48.0047975","2.675153971","0.0004602147965","760.9866943","0.0004602147965","1","9","0"

Jens
 Yes, that works for my specific case because all fields are numbers. If I remember the CSV spec correctly, the quote character should only be used for fields which contain the separator character, so that the column structure is kept intact. I also just noticed that the line ending of the produced files are Unix style ‚Äì only \n. Should be platform default.

Thanks

Jens
 I think the document should be right, but I am not 100% sure.
1. Double quotes issue:

The spec says double quotes are optional as long as no special chars are in the field. So the current version is strictly correct, yet it creates trouble with Excel (it prevents automatic field type detection). Since Excel is a widely used tool AND avoiding unnecessary double quotes creates smaller files I would recommend removing them.
1.  Each field may or may not be enclosed in double quotes (however
      some programs, such as Microsoft Excel, do not use double quotes
      at all).  If fields are not enclosed with double quotes, then
      double quotes may not appear inside the fields.  For example:
   
      "aaa","bbb","ccc" CRLF
      zzz,yyy,xxx
2.  Fields containing line breaks (CRLF), double quotes, and commas
      should be enclosed in double-quotes.  For example:
   
      "aaa","b CRLF
      bb","ccc" CRLF
      zzz,yyy,xxx
3.  If double-quotes are used to enclose fields, then a double-quote
      appearing inside a field must be escaped by preceding it with
      another double quote.  For example:
   
      "aaa","b""bb","ccc"
1. CRLF issue:
   The spec says all files should be CRLF ‚Äì means Windows style. There is no ambiguity here. That should be an easy fix.

Thanks

Jens
   On the Browse Data tab: It would really enhance keyboard navigation to have either (or) both the 'enter' and 'tab' keys move input focus to the next filter field. Currently 'tab' moves to the next data cell and 'enter' does nothing.

 The file sqlitebrowser.exe.xz is actually an archive file, so you need to extract the exe from the archive before running. I suggest something like 7-Zip (http://www.7-zip.org/) for doing the extract. I just tried this and it worked fine for me.
 I didn't recognize the suffix and somehow my brain went to it being an
obfuscation to fool virus scanners.
Bottom line, tabbing between filter field works as I'd expect. Enter still
does nothing, not sure if that's important.
Thank you for making these kinds of improvements, it makes the tool awesome.
 I could go either way. The filter gets applied on each character keypress so it's not like <enter> is required to start the filter. Plus back tabbing is supported with shift + Tab whereas using Enter to move between fields would imply Shift + Enter for moving backward and that does not seem idomatic.
I guess I lean toward leaving Enter unmapped.

  Will it be possible to access more than one file in a session?

I tried an 'attach', but B4S (Browser for SQLite) seems not to support it. Perhaps in a future version?
Standard one can attach nine more databases and even 124 with runtime-options.

 Thanks! Solved this issue.
  Import table from a CSV file does not handle linebreaks in a field: If a field in the csv file contains a linebreak, the import function handles it as the start of a new record. A solution might be to take the number of fields per record into account as well.

I noticed this while importing a csv file from a third party.

ps. I find the "Import table from a CSV file" function brilliant anyways!
 Hi Justin,

Thanks for mentioning this #84, I saw the same thing (spaces being removed) and I thought it had something to do with me Find-And-Replacing linebreaks.

Thinking of #84: it is removing all empty spaces where LEADING and TRAILING spaces is probably meant (and the latter is very usefull!).

Anyways, thanks a lot for this wonderful tool, I find myself using it a lot lately while making my (free!) apps.

Cheers,

Niels Cup
 Niels Cup wrote: LEADING and TRAILING spaces is probably meant (and the latter is very usefull!).

I agree, however according to the standard _no_ (i.e.0, the digit) spaces at all should be removed. To be absolutely sure all text fields should be quoted either by ' or "

One time I noticed a CSV-file I copied and changed all commas by |, but there was a field with an unexoected | inside [luckily just exactly one record :-)] in order to create a SQLite-database.  
 Event better! trimming fields might not be the standard but I noticed many fields in my 3rd party csv file with lots of white spaces in them, so it‚Äôs very useful.
 Hi Justin,

I  tried the build below and I had some problems with it: I received a message: ‚ÄúError importing data. Message from database engine: table table1 has 39 columns but 40 values were supplied‚Äù. I would like to see the record number in this message so I am able to correct the csv file. I received this message with the original CSV file formatted like this: ‚Äúfield1‚Äù,‚Äùfield2‚Äù,‚Äùfield3‚Äù, ‚Äúetc‚Ä¶‚Äù.

I also have a version of this csv file which I have changed to a pipe separated file (field1|field2|field3|etc‚Ä¶) and I didn‚Äôt receive the error on this file, but I noticed the import is now very slow. I have a very large (third party) csv file, 104000 records. I started import, went away and came back after half an hour and the import was only at 52%. The previous version took only 2 or 3 minutes. Performance might not be an issue for smaller files (which would normally be the case).

I know CSV files are often unreliable, I have bumped into these same issues when writing my own import tools. For me the previous version (without the remove all spaces bug) was more workable than this version. In the previous version the import went pretty fast and succeeded. Afterwards I was able to see where the import jumped columns and I could manually remove the linebreaks in Excel.

Cheers,

Niels.
 Hi Rene, the ‚ÄúDecoding CSV file..‚Äù is very slow. I have just tested (the decoding part) again, with my csv file 104000 records:
- Version 3.3.1 = fast meaning approx. 20 seconds for 104000 records
- Version master_git = slow meaning at 20% after 5 minutes

I have created a test.csv file, with only 10 records and a header (I cant attach the full file, it is 100mb‚Ä¶), just copy the records until you have 50.000 or 100.000 records .

I can‚Äôt send you the original file either because it is not my data, but the result is the same with this test file.

 Hi, the hail0-2002.csv works fine with me too. I guess it‚Äôs the csv file I am trying to import causing the problems: Below I copied 10 (identical) records including the header.  Hi Justin,

You will find the translated file with this mail.
I made a review of the file : sqlb_fr.ts (XML file)

Please, take care... The file is coded with UTF-8. All entities are coded with
this option.
I mean, for example :
l&apos;ouverture
will be, in the file
l'ouverture
The html source data (line 28) has his entites encoded*
style=&quot; font-size:small; text-decoration: underline;
color:#0000ff;&quot;&gt;
will be :
style=" font-size:small; text-decoration: underline; color:#0000ff;">

I got the file from github (sqlitebrowser-master/src/translation

have a good day overseas ;)

Michel

  Hi! When I import a csv-file into a table every single space was deleted (v 3.3.0). Special characters are not displayed correctly even though in v 2.0 it worked fine. What happened? Is it my fault? Can I make any settings to avoid at least the space-deleting? Thanks a lot for your help!
 In fact there is: http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc4180

As is written there spaces should not be ignored and use of double quotes
depends on system/application; M$ExCel goes it's own way...

On Sun, Aug 31, 2014 at 8:38 AM, Peinthor Rene notifications@github.com
wrote:

> Right now I can only give you 2 workarounds, until those bugs are fixed.
> 1. save your CSV file in the UTF-8 encoding, e..g with libreoffice
>    calc (character encoding can be set on export)
> 2. Quote all your strings with whitespaces in it, I don't know if
>    there is a CSV rfc or how strings in fields should really be handled, but i
>    guess we shouldn't throw away whitespace between field separaters if they
>    don't mess up the file format.

 Original code that created that is
```sql
CREATE VIRTUAL TABLE Search USING FTS3 (
	_id,
	name,
	location
);
```
you can probably find the same in the .sqlite file if you open it with a text editor/grep it.

@MKleusberg I would agree that it's acceptable to close this issue if those unrecognized/warned tables are read-only and will be written in the same way even if other recognized tables or data are modified.  Create a table with

```
CREATE TABLE "test"(rowid INTEGER PRIMARY KEY)
```

Attempting to open the corresponding sqlite file will result in 

```
line 1:47: unexpected token: rowid
```

  Hello folks,

After the excellent service on my last request, I have a couple more:
1. On the 'Database Structure' tab, could the schema be made to collapse along with the field list? As it is, the benefit of collapsing is rather lost when the schema is long and you can only see a few (or only one) tables on your window anyway.
2. On the results from running an SQL query, long fields (varchar and friends) should only be displayed up to some maximum length. Otherwise you have to do massive horizontal scrolling to see all your fields.
3. On SQL query results and table browsing, how about a right-click option to copy the value of the field into the copy buffer. At the moment you can accomplish this with browse data by double-clicking and copying from the 'Edit database cell' window, but you can't do it at all with query results.

Many thanks for your help. And let me know if it makes sense that I work on the code myself - I could do it, but would ultimately prefer to avoid one more learning curve!

Cheers, Jonathan
 > makes sense to remove newlines while collapsed.

> ```
> On the results from running an SQL query, long fields (varchar and
> friends) should only be displayed up to some maximum length.
> Otherwise you have to do massive horizontal scrolling to see all
> your fields.
> ```
> 
> Maybe we can add saving of column width like we do for the browse table,
> but there is no easy general solution for this.

> and copying from the 'Edit database cell' window, but you can't do

> ```

But a context menu would be nice to have. Besides copying, you could 
also filter on the content of the field, paste over the content, edit 
the field, and I'm sure others could think of more.
  rp: "makes sense to remove newlines while collapsed."

I would say the contrary. Thanks to <Cr><LF> we can see data that's hidden and replaced by ...

Indeed copy and paste to a local text editor helps. Would be nice if the developers replace some whitespace by 0x0d0a internally [of course not in the database file ;-)] to get the same effect.
  Hello,

Since version 3.2, sqlitebrowser reports an error on tables with the 'ASC' keyword in its primary key definition. For example, the a database consisting of the following table (created with sqlite3):

CREATE TABLE [Test]([Field] [int] NOT NULL, CONSTRAINT [Test_Constraint] PRIMARY KEY %28 [Field] ASC %29);

cannot be browsed or modified with sqlitebrowser. That is, browsing the table shows the correct number of records but no data in the records. Attempting to modify the table reveals that the entire table definition (apart from the table name) has been lost. Running sqlitebrowser from the command line returns:

line 1:98: expecting RPAREN, found 'ASC'
line 1:103: unexpected token: )
line 1:98: expecting RPAREN, found 'ASC'
line 1:103: unexpected token: )
line 1:98: expecting RPAREN, found 'ASC'
line 1:103: unexpected token: )

I hope that's enough info to help someone diagnose the problem.

Thanks!

The file causing it: http://temp.twisterrob.net/share/MagicHomeInventory.sqlite
The DB has no data in it, just the schema: tables, triggers, views.

Opening it with _android-sdk-windows\platform-tools\sqlite3.exe_ works, so I tried to narrow it down.

If I drop these:

``` sql
drop table Category_Name_Cache;
drop table Item_Path;
```

I tried dropping only the triggers of these tables, but it was still crashing. So I suspect there must be something in the `CREATE TABLE`s.
 Are you sure about that AUTOINCREMENT being the culprit?
The tables I dropped to make it not crash didn't have a PRIMARY KEY like that!

Note: I use `PRIMARY KEY(...)` format instead of `name type PRIMARY KEY` to be consistent among tables with singular/multiple keys. And because of this I don't know if I can put the AUTOINCREMENT anywhere else.

`ALTER TABLE ... RENAME TO` should take care of those contstraints, I don't think it's a good idea to restrict. http://www.sqlite.org/lang_altertable.html however renaming a table and updating `VIEW`s and `TRIGGER` bodies would be a nice feature if not already implemented.
 @justinclift
Sure I'll try tomorrow, when will it be available (with timezone)?

> Maybe n "Novice mode" option set in preferences, would let us keep stuff simple for novices.

That's not a good idea in general, lot of features will be used by a really small userbase (hard to discover), for example Visual Studio has a nicely hidden "Advanced UI" option in a non-intuitive place: http://i.msdn.microsoft.com/dynimg/IC429789.jpg

I'd suggest an expander for advanced features if you decide to go ahead: http://qt-apps.org/content/show.php/ExpanderWidget?content=163843 novice users will see an "Advanced" header of the closed expand and think "Advanced features, beware", others will expand confidently and won't be scared.

  It'd be a lot easier to write SQL if you could see the schema while you're in the Execute SQL tab. This could be achieved with another pane (like the Plot pane) that shows the current DB schema as a treeview.

  I just realized that when I try to modify a table after a default value has been introduced, following changes are just ignored. They appear in the modify table window and the "query" on the bottom is updated, but if you hit OK, nothing else happens. I also realized that you usually get a little window after any change that dissapears very fast (I think that it reads "executing SQL" or something like that) but once you introduce a default value, that window doesn't appear anymore.

If you remove that default value, everything is working fine

I also realized that if you open the modify table again after setting a default value, it now appears as 'value' instead of just value (I mean, quoted)

Here you can see an example
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5297845/3649297/1411fd66-1111-11e4-9248-468a12a2eb51.png)

I have multiple fields with default values and whenever I try to add a new field, the field is always 'Field7' and cannot be renamed. I just tried the Nightly Mac build 09-24-2014.  @nealpaze I think it's the same issue, once there's a default value, seems that any further updating stops (maybe some kind of exception is caught later is breaking the execution flow?). The thing is that if you have more than one default value (maybe because you are using an existing database), you will not even be able to remove them to allow it working again

Cornelis.
 This table is created with Doctrine2/ORM running on PHP5.6 PDO SQLite. I've just updated the table (using PHP5.4 PDO SQLite3 3.7.7.1) with new data without a problem.

Here's the table schema:

```
C:\teki\_downloads\sqlite>sqlite3.exe C:\teki\_data\PhpStorm\projects\thaisubtitle\backup.sql3
SQLite version 3.8.5 2014-06-04 14:06:34                                                      
Enter ".help" for usage hints.                                                                
sqlite> .schema                                                                               
CREATE TABLE "movie" (                                                                        
"id"  INTEGER NOT NULL,                                                                       
"imdb"  INTEGER,                                                                              
"status"  REAL NOT NULL,                                                                      
"serie"  INTEGER,                                                                             
"added"  INTEGER,                                                                             
"updated"  INTEGER,                                                                           
"watched"  INTEGER,                                                                           
"title"  TEXT NOT NULL,                                                                       
PRIMARY KEY ("id" ASC)                                                                        
);                                                                                            
sqlite>  
```

I've tested some other databases and none of them has the weird characters, so you're right that that has something to do with it. I've tried to replicate the weird characters without any luck. I've done some operations with PHP and Navicat but also no weird characters.

My conclusion is that most likely there's something wrong with my table, although PHP and Navicat has no problems with it. I believe that this issue can be closed.

Thank you very much for mentioning the weird characters!
 About the weird characters in my database, that are just CR and LF instead of spaces in other SQLite3 databases I have inspected. It can be seen on this screenshot:

![weirdcharacters](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/670271/3638028/e8ff7c78-1031-11e4-9af1-5bf367a1afaa.png)

I took a quick look at the file format on http://www.sqlite.org/fileformat2.html but couldn't find any specifications there about the allowed characters in the creation text.

Maybe someone knows where to find more exact specifications of the file format?
 I came across some other databases, tested and inspected them. Table creation text with LF and TAB characters works, data can be seen in the `Browser Data` tab.

Please ask if more screenshots would be helpful and also if you like to examine the database file itself. It's only 1MB.
   Thanks for your words! I tried. I hope that I will make still something useful to the project :smiley:

  homebrew has been updated with a brew of sqlitebrowser 3.2.0

All that is required to install from brew now is:
`brew install sqlitebrowser`

```
$ brew info sqlitebrowser
sqlitebrowser: stable 3.2.0, HEAD
http://sqlitebrowser.org
/usr/local/Cellar/sqlitebrowser/3.2.0 (4 files, 2.2M) *
  Built from source
From: https://github.com/Homebrew/homebrew/blob/master/Library/Formula/sqlitebrowser.rb
==> Dependencies
Build: cmake ‚úî
Required: qt ‚úî, sqlite ‚úî
```

```
$ brew install sqlitebrowser
==> Downloading https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser/archive/sqlb-3.2.0.t

==> cmake . -DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=/usr/local/Cellar/sqlitebrowser/3.2.0 -DCMAKE_BU
==> make install
üç∫  /usr/local/Cellar/sqlitebrowser/3.2.0: 4 files, 2.2M, built in 57 seconds
```

  When you try to add a record, it does not use the specified default value for the fields, that are not being entered. To see an example of how this could be accomplished take a look at the firefox plugin SQLite manager (Screenshot added below)
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8113476/3523976/d0586672-0761-11e4-89dc-a66a2a57adfe.png)

  Would love to be able to upgrade my sqlitebrowser 3.1 for PortableApps :-)
 Done. I see this morning it's now a work in progress (John building...)
  Up until now, the DBBrowserDB:decodeCSV used to load the csv-file character by character using the getChar() method of the QFile-class.
Unfortunatelly, this approach caused multibyte-chars as used for UTF-8 encoding to be split and displayed incorrectly.

The fix uses the QTextStream-class to load the file line by line.
Every line is then again iterated character by character, before the old algorithm is applied. Using this approach, the characters are loaded and encoded properly. Splitting multibyte-chars is thus prevented.
 Thank you for the feedback. I am happy that I can contribute something usefull to the project. As my schedule permits I will try to add and test your proposed changes and push them up this afternoon.

@rp- I don't think this would be the case. As far as I know the file pointer is not moved line-wise. Even if there is only one line, it should return false as the pointer is at the begining of the line. Do-While seems to be risky, as an empty file might cause the loop-block to execute once before the condition detects it.
 You are right, this might turn into a problem later. I must admit that I haven't worked with QT for a long time, so I might be a bit rusty ;-)
Exchanging it with inStream.readLine() should do the trick, thought.
 I might have found a first bug. A colleague of mine build the program on a mac, and there it seemed to have messed up the separators, as columns are not separated properly anymore. As I've only tested on a windows-machine I didn't know before, but I will investigate the problem asap.
 Ok, I've pushed a few more changes.
The line is now loaded using the readLine() command instead of the stream-operator. Also I've cleaned the code a bit up by removing unnecessary if-clauses and moved some of the variables into the outer-loop (as per request).
Finally, I've introduced an additional condition into the algorithm to detect blanks between separator and quote. 

EDIT: Made a quick test on my Mac and everything seems to work. Even files with only one line are imported properly.

  This is similar to issue #34, except using the construction `NOT LIKE`. Please note that using a regular `LIKE`, i.e. without negation, does work.

Example:

```
CREATE TABLE not_working(
    value TEXT CONSTRAINT "value" CHECK(value NOT LIKE "prefix%")
);

CREATE TABLE working(
    value TEXT CONSTRAINT "value" CHECK(value LIKE "prefix%")
);

INSERT INTO not_working( value ) VALUES( "a" );
INSERT INTO    working( value ) VALUES( "prefixa" );
-- INSERT INTO NotWorking( value ) VALUES( "prefixb" );
-- INSERT INTO    Working( value ) VALUES( "b" );
```

I'm using the test build posted in the comment by @justinclift in issue #34 on Windows 7.
 Confirmed working now, also on my larger database :)

However, it appears to me that the underlying issue is that you are not fully implementing the grammar as specified by SQLite. For example, looking at the possible definitions for table constraints (http://www.sqlite.org/lang_createtable.html -> column-def -> column-constraint -> expr), it seems to me that the same (specific) problem holds for "GLOB", "REGEXP" and "MATCH". Indeed, the following example again fails to display properly:

```
CREATE TABLE not_working(
    value TEXT CONSTRAINT "value" CHECK(value NOT GLOB "foo")
);

CREATE TABLE working(
    value TEXT CONSTRAINT "value" CHECK(value GLOB "foo")
);

INSERT INTO not_working( value ) VALUES( "bar" );
INSERT INTO    working( value ) VALUES( "foo" );
```

The issue is that all of these expressions (and possibly more in the other comparison operators) may be prefixed by an optional "NOT" operator. However your current fix just allows "NOT LIKE" in addition to regular "LIKE" conditions, but it does not add the generic ability to say "NOT <expression>".

The same holds for the fix for issue #34, modifying the example leads to e.g.:

```
CREATE TABLE not_working(
    value TEXT CONSTRAINT "value" CHECK(value NOT IN( "foo" ) )
);

CREATE TABLE working(
    value TEXT CONSTRAINT "value" CHECK(value IN( "foo" ) )
);

INSERT INTO not_working( value ) VALUES( "bar" );
INSERT INTO    working( value ) VALUES( "foo" );
```

Which again does not display properly.

I'm wondering whether this is intentional? (and how many more of these examples I can come up with ;)
  Oh I see. I do notice that when I open the sqlite file again those shm and wal files reappear. Thanks for your answer!

Thanks!
 Thanks so much for the help, Peinthor! Indeed there is, would this main db reflect the data in the Write-Ahead log before the commit to purge it? If not, is there any way at all to see what this data is before it has been added to the main db?
 @sammarcus wrote 'stupid question'. With the sole exception of the unasked there is no such thing as a 'stupid question'. Stupid answers however there are unfortunately too many...

Back on-topic: like someone said: by opening more than one session (e.g. more TerminalTabs) one can easily have more WA-L and/or SHM-files and investigate them with any tool/language (Perl is an easy example) capable of handling binary files. With the help of SQLite's doc you're able to analyze them and search for nugs and other reasons of corrupted databases.

WARNING: Ignored (not found) '/Users/username/Documents/sqlitebrowser/src/sqlitebrowser.xcodeproj'
```

but this suggestion helped:

``` bash
qmake -spec macx-llvm
make
```

  Cool! :thumbsup:
 How about "auto open last project" and "open project from command line" :question:
  When using a CHECK constraint on a column of a table which uses the IN( ... ) syntax to check that the value exists in a known set of values, the resulting table does not appear to have any columns when viewed at the "Database Structure" tab. Inserting values will still work, as will querying the table manually, but the "Browse Data" tab will show rows without any columns or data.

Example:

```
CREATE TABLE not_working(
    _id PRIMARY KEY NOT NULL,
    value NVARCHAR(5) CHECK (value IN ('a', 'b', 'c'))
);

CREATE TABLE working(
    _id PRIMARY KEY NOT NULL,
    value NVARCHAR(5) CHECK (value = 'a' OR value = 'b' OR value = 'c')
);

INSERT INTO not_working( _id, value ) VALUES ( 1, 'a' ), ( 2, 'b' ), ( 3, 'c' );
INSERT INTO working( _id, value ) VALUES ( 4, 'a' ), ( 5, 'b' ), ( 6, 'c' );
```

I'm using version 3.1.0 on Windows 7.
 Thanks for the quick fix! It now seems to work fine on my database :)
  table is create with episodenb ::  
 integer not null
but show as 
TEXT
in
sqlitebrowser (version 3.1.0, Qt 4.8.5, QSLite 3.7.17).

This is what I use :
create table if not exists episode (
episodeid integer primary key references filmitem (filmid),
serieid integer not null references filmitem (filmid),
seasonnb integer not null,
episodenb integer no null,
title varchar[max],
foreign key (serieid) references serie (serieid)
);"

This is what is dumped by sqlite3 command line:
sqlite> .dump episode
PRAGMA foreign_keys=OFF;
BEGIN TRANSACTION;
CREATE TABLE episode (episodeid integer primary key references filmitem (filmid),serieid integer not null references filmitem (filmid),seasonnb integer not null,episodenb integer no null,title varchar[max],foreign key (serieid) references serie (serieid));
COMMIT;

But sqlitebrowser tells me that:

CREATE TABLE "episode" (
    `episodeid` integer,
    `serieid`   integer NOT NULL,
    `seasonnb`  integer NOT NULL,
    `episodenb` TEXT,
    `title` varchar[max],
    PRIMARY KEY(episodeid)
)
 Indeed this was my mistake (no vs not), I'm glad that you were actually able to turn this in something helpful for the project.

  I recently added a partial index (a new SQLite 3.8 feature) to my database and noticed that SQLite Browser was no longer able to read it. I'm assuming that this is because the 3.1 Windows binary version is still using SQLite 3.7.17.

 @justinclift: Sure. I just tried opening and browsing the same file (with partial indexes) that didn't work under 3.1 and everything seems to be working as expected. That's about the extent of the testing I can do at the moment, as I happen to be out of town, but it looks good to me....
  Is there any reason sqlb does not contain a compiled osx sqlitebrowser.app in its release distribution?

Was thinking maybe a license issue or possibly a security signing which may prevent it running on other machines issue maybe?
 You basically can copy the Qt framework files to your app bundle, and that's it. Examine the package for the older (sourceforge) app and you will see how it is done. I think I had some automated routines at one time to do this, but they were for Qt3, probably very different.
 One note: in the previous version I used to include the sqlite3 source in the tree, and compile it with the program. But I see now that this has changed (reading cmake). So you are correct that you also need to include the lib. 
But, in general, OSX bundles have this ability: you can include the libs inside the bundle directory and they will be searched first, and take precedence over the ones installed in the system. 
For the Qt libs, you can use the included tool to simplify this:
http://qt-project.org/doc/qt-5/macosx-deployment.html
 Awesome, glad I got a ball rolling. I have forked the repo and uploaded a release OSX build for a friend but I didn't hear back from him if it worked. Going to assume it wont streight off the bat but glad to hear that it may at some point :)

USB Device: Bluetooth USB Host Controller, apple_vendor_id, 0x8213, 0x06110000 / 4
 Same issue here with both versions. The problem seems to be in libsqlite3.0.dylib. How did you generate it? Did you do this on a machine running Mavericks? 
Maybe this lib needs to be compiled/linked against an older version of the system frameworks in order to work on older OSX releases.
 I am pretty sure the processor does not matter, XCode targets abstract this. The problem is most likely that you used/bundled a system version of libsqlite3 that is incompatible with what I have here. Did you copy this from your sytem folder, or compile it?
That is one of the reasons I used to add sqlite3.c to the builds, so you would have a static version on all platforms. Of course, it makes it difficult to update Sqlite and benefit from fixes (specially in the case of LInux builds). For OSX and Win this is really not an issue as you would have to replace the lib anyway.
 Justin, try not including libsqlite3 in the archive, and instead linking to the system framework in XCode. Here are some pointers (the first link is for ios but it should also apply to osx):

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/12411208/app-rejected-for-using-libsqlite3-dylib

http://www.ajaxapp.com/2011/08/30/how-to-add-sqlite-framework-into-xcode-4-for-your-ios-app/
 The latest one works perfectly here.
  make install (invoked in the top level directory, containing BUILDING, ...) doesn't seem to do anything except produce output; no files are installed anywhere.  The program has already been build using make, and seems to work fine.
 On Tue, 2014-05-27 at 11:20 -0700, Martin Kleusberg wrote:

> You're using qmake, I suppose? Because we had some difficulties when
> it came to using extended features with qmake we've made the decision
> to move to cmake. We try to keep qmake support but only for a quick
> build; when it comes to a release build or things like make install
> I'd suggest using cmake. I hope this is an option for you :)

I downloaded sqlite-browser using the command:

```
    $ git clone https://github.com/sqlitebrowser/sqlitebrowser.git
```

and invoked make (not cmake or qmake) on sqlitebrowser/Makefile.  The

## sqlitebrowser binary generated seems to run OK.

All the best - jon

For I am a Bear of Very Little Brain, and 
long words bother me. -- Winnie the Pooh
 On Wed, 2014-05-28 at 15:28 -0700, Justin Clift wrote:

> Sounds like we should add build instructions for Linux too.

I suspect there's a typo in BUILDING, which reads, in part:

```
    Provided you have Qt and cmake  installed and configured, simply
    run

    qmake

    followed by

    make
```

When I find a Makefile in a build directory, I assume that the packager
has already run whatever is needed to generate it, and that they have
probably done a better job than I will (at least for a first cut), so in
this cas I didn't run qmake.  If you want sqlitebrowser to be built
using cmake rather than make, the above should read:

```
    Provided you have Qt and cmake  installed and configured, simply
    run

    qmake

    followed by

    cmake
```

If you want me to be sure to regenerate the Makefile using cmake, you

## need to say so very explicitly.

All the best - jon

  This is more a comment than a bug report, but I noticed this when testing the fix for issue #16. 
Suppose you have a BLOB containing multiple null-terminated strings. When you edit the blob, everything is fine as type:Binary, but if you change the type to "Text" in the EditDialog the length of the data remains the same but only the data up to the first null is shown (understandable, but not what the user might expect). Switching back to type:Binary shows all the data again.
However, if you change the data in the type:Text view it is immediately truncated at the first null (the new length shown at the bottom of the EditDialog window), and switching back to type:Binary only shows the truncated data.
I do think it's a valuable facility to be able to edit text within a blob - editing UTF-8 encoded text in hex mode is only fun once :-)
 Yes, it seems to be a very difficult area.  Full function UTF8-aware hex/text editors seem very few and far between.
Perhaps it would be reasonable to settle for disabling Text editing for blobs :-(
By the way, I only discovered by accident that the binary edit mode has the text displayed on the right hand side - it's completely hidden when the EditDialog opens at its default size!
Maybe make the default width enough to show the 16 bytes in both hex and text?
 @MKleusberg both commits appear to have achieved what was intended - looks good, thanks!
May I make a couple more (final?) comments? (although I understand you may have better things to do than attend to this level of detail)
1. there is no visible representation of a null byte in the text view, and 
2."Select all" highlights all the text, but "copy" only copies up to the first null

Seeing where there is a null means I'm less likely to remove it by mistake.
Being able to copy the entire blob value at least gives me the opportunity to take the data for processing elsewhere (and a really nice feature of the EditDialog is that I can get my binary data back into sqlitebrowser by pasting it as hex pairs).
 Here's what I see on Windows 8.1:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7688713/3209796/2d42edac-ee8b-11e3-9574-fbe521985263.png)
To my mind, the best solution is, as you suggest, to extend the hex editor widget if possible to allow input on the right side.
By the way, the hex editor doesn't appear to make any attempt to display multi-byte UTF-8 characters ("caf√©" will appear as "caf.."). Another Qt constraint?

Not sure what the previous PortableApps version was, but it displayed text values as text all the way up to my longest string of about 13K.
Is this a limit that you could consider raising/removing? (browsing/editing BLOB data is a tad less friendly than TEXT data!)

Many thanks for the super quick fix!
  The tool of choice to translate pure Qt applications (like sqlitebrowser) is Qt Linguist. As Rene said, the code is mostly ready for it, as it uses tr() to display strings. If possible I would like to stay away from Launchpad, as it is too specific to Ubuntu/Canonical. We had a lot of problems in the past in KDE, with Launchpad translations taking precedence over upstream ones in some cases. 
 In issue #57 I made translation to Russian.
  I can't seem to figure out how to open an encrypted sqlite database?  If this is not currently possible, I think it would be an appropriate enhancement.

Thanks!
 It is a nice enhancement, but be aware that by itself SQLite does not include an encryption library. One is available from HWCI (http://www.hwaci.com/sw/sqlite/see.html), for a fee. 
As sqlitebrowser is distributed with source we can not include SEE with sqlitebrowser. You can, however, license the extension and compile your own binary with SEE included (I have done this in the past for the Arca Database Browser, the product from which sqlitebrowser was derived from).

Yes, please add support for SQLCipher.

 Hi, 
I will try my best to explain in detail my build set: 
- Miscrosoft visual studio c++ 2013, but I think any version is ok, link download: https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=517284
- SQLCipher: I just try to link with 2 differents versions, and it works all fine: 
  - 1st one is SQLCipher C/C++ DLL for Windows that I requested for a 30 days trial on their main site (https://www.zetetic.net/sqlcipher/trial/)
  - 2nd one is a self compilation (mingw32 + code source: https://www.zetetic.net/sqlcipher/open-source), here's a guide link: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/29196087/step-by-step-guide-to-build-qt-sql-driver-plugin-for-sqlite-db-with-sqlcipher-ex (part 5)
- These variables in CMakeLists.txt must be modified to match your preferences: 
  
  ```
   + QT5_PATH
   + SQLITE3_PATH (path to foremost folder of SQL Cipher)
   + OPENSSL_PATH
   + VSREDIST
   + LIBSQLITE_NAME (sqlcipher or sqlite3 depends on the name of your .dll file)
   + SQLITE3_INCLUDE_DIRS (sqlite3.h)
   + SQLITE3_LIBS (name of your .dll file)
  ```
- Then everything left is just open sqlitebrowser MSVC solution then build
  I'm sure that I might miss something, so if there anything wrong, just ask here, I will look back at my build and answer, for now that's all I remember.
  
    Cheers, 
 Link to 64-bit windows version is broken.
 You can try with SQLCipher setup on Ubuntu mentioned here in [SO thread](http://stackoverflow.com/a/25132478/2624806).
